description:
While visiting Pier 39 I decided to Check out the quaint little Aquarium of the Bay.
The aquarium had multiple floors that played home to a variety of aquatic life. They even had an area where you could walk through a large tank that arched over your head. By far my favorite part of the aquarium was the jelly fish room. They had multiple large tanks with a variety of species. They were lit with changing lights that gave the jelly fish an otherworldly feel. 
My second favorite part of the museum was the otter habitat. I could stand there and watch it enjoy itself for hours. Overall it was fun experience that i'll definitely remember.
author: Christian D.

description:
This is a small aquarium located in pier 39 so a nice spot for all the tourists walking around. It has 2 levels but due to it's size, you really don't get to see much. 
They have an under water tunnel that's pretty cool but not a lot of interesting fish to hold your attention unfortunately. The sea otters were no where in sight so that was quite disappointing.
The price for the aquarium is pretty steep ($75 for 2 adults and 1 kid) considering you can only spend 30-45 min in there and that's going pretty slow.
author: Janet Y.

description:
We went here for my daughters 5th birthday and she had a blast.. we all did!!
After lots of reviews saying it was small and falls short compared to the other options near by I wasnt expecting to be there long or to be amazed but that was so wrong. My daughter was set on seeing the Otters which is last but the best part is, you can walk thru over and over as much as you want all day long. Our 1st trip thru we were with so many other people it was hard to obsorb and to get the little kids up front to see stuff (which is why I gave 4 and not the full 5 stars, would be nice if they only let a certain amount in at a time) but our 2nd trip thru was much better and we truly enjoyed every single exhibit and got to stand in the tunnel while scuba divers swam thru cleaning and feeding. So fun!!
I highly recommend this aquarium, we spent 2 and a half hours with 3 kids (ages 7, 4 and 2) but if you want to go faster you can. Everything was beautiful and set up nicely to keep their interest, we probably would have went thru the tunnel and stopped at the otters again if we didnt have a party to host back home.
Also, the little shops were great, the front one has better options for kids!!
author: Caitlin D.

description:
I've been to many aquariums throughout California but this one is a tiny one that you can get through in an hour or less. 

I paid about $20/ticket because of the travelzoo online third party discount. You can get a local resident discount for less than $23 with your id or it's about $27 for general admission. You get in and out privileges for the whole day on case you wanted to come back for a show/timed event.

I think what makes this aquarium different than the others I've been to in California is the tunnel that you can walk through and see fish from all angles. They have a decent variety of sharks, rays, starfish, and other fish. The jellyfish exhibit was very pretty cool but again, not as diverse as Monterey. There were even pools of starfish and stingrays that you can touch along with a small otter exhibit.

Overall, I'd rather go to the Monterey Bay Aquarium instead but this is a place to visit at least once if you're in the area or from the bay area.
author: Steph F.

description: Yes it is a smaller aquarium that you can get through pretty quickly. Perfect for younger kids, priced accordingly, and let's you go explore either the rest of pier 39, and or other parts of San Francisco to fill your day. A friend of mine and I brought our daughters here after getting discounted tickets (even more worth it). They had a great time seeing the rays and sharks swim all around them as we went down the moving walkway, they loved petting the Rays in the Ray pool, touching and playing with creatures in the tide pool and really loved the screen where it looks like you are interacting with a bunch of other animals. Afterwards we went and played on pier 39, trampoline, merry go round, watched sea lions, ate lunch, caught a trolly car and explored other parts of San Francisco. We had a fabulous day and this was the perfect jumping point!  Also, you learn a lot about local sea life, which is different than most aquariums.
author: Charles R.

description:
Pros:

*I loved the two tunnels with the fish, sharks and stingrays! True this part of the aquarium feels a little dated/old, but the sea animals were lovely. And we saw 3 divers feeding the fish and cleaning the rocks.

*The best was the otter exhibit, where we got to watch 2 energetic and playful otters chase each other and zip past us in the water! 

*The baby stingray pool was also cool, and I learned that stingrays grow very slowly, and that when they're babies, they're only the size of a ravioli. Loved being able to gently touch the tip of a stingray.

*Staff was friendly and knowledgeable. 
*Bathrooms were clean. 
*Small but well stocked gift shop.
*Beautiful views of the bay on clear days.

Cons:

*It's a very small aquarium, and can easily be toured in 1-1.5 hours, so it's pricey unless you come here as part of a city pass or discount package.

*Parking at the Pier 39 garage is expensive ($10/hour), and street parking is hard to find.
author: Ellen H.

description:
I wish we had a better aquarium. I like visiting once in awhile because it close to me but I wish it was more exciting. It is small in a very prime location.

The gift shop doesn't have much. They have one at the entrance and exit and is not very well stoked or have a good selection.

Will have to travel to Monterey for my next fish fix.
author: Keith A.

description:
The Aquarium of the Bay is pretty small (I can easily go through it in an hour or less) and is definitely not worth the $25 admission fee; however, it's a good place to check out if you're super into marine life and animals and if you're looking for something to do at Fisherman's Wharf.

My favorite parts of the aquarium are the river otters and tanks where you can see the fish, sharks, and sting rays all around and from above. They also have touch pools - super cool and interactive, but remember to use one finger!

I also bought a super cute stuffed penguin here that can turn inside out into a pillow. heheh ^_^
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Aquarium of the Bay is the best place where you should go with your child. I paid about $20-$25 and I was really surprised how big is it. We went through the different room, corridors looking for a lot of fishes. I have never seen such a variety of species. Mostly, I liked the tuna fish, because it is so big and fabulous. The gift shop has some overpriced items so I could not afford to buy anything for my daughter. We spent about 3-4 hours. 
Generally, it was pretty good.
author: Elena L.

description:
People come to explore Pier 39 from all over the world because there is so much to do here. While walking the streets you'll see local street performers. There is a certain charm to Pier 39. All you need to do is find parking and then just walk to all the destinations. If you love people watching then you'll love it here.


One of the most amazing thing about this aquarium are the clear tunnels. Walking through a tunnel while observing aquatic creatures is a pretty magical experience. You can observe River Otters and they have a place where you can touch sea creatures. It is not a big aquarium but the Nearshore Tunnel and the Sharks of Alcatraz Tunnel make it so worth it. You can get so close to a bat ray, sturgeon, and the Giant Sea Bass.
author: Irina V.

description:
We had to rush threw due to the heat being unbearable. Us and the kids were sweating. If they could fix the AC issue it would be worth the Groupon we bought. Definitely not worth the original price listed at the booth. 
The line to get back up from the basement (where the tunnel is) was a 20 min wait. Lots of people were frustrated and sweating lol. A lot of ugly and pissed off looks. I do not recommend this place in the summer. It was 70 degrees outside and windy still was burning up down stairs. 

Get the AC issue fixed!!!!
author: Davd W.

description:
My son visited AOB on a field trip several months ago but was excited to return again. His favorite attraction is the touch pool. I was most impressed by the tunnel and the amount and diversity of sea life that can be viewed. I thought pricing was reasonable for the smaller (as compared to a Monterey Bay Aquarium size) venue. I am removing one star because of the bottlenecks created at the elevators and crowds that form at either side of them. If you are severely claustrophobic you definitely don't want to visit. A child pressed the "stop walkway" button which sounded a bell. This really upset a young woman who was waiting for the elevator who became frantic. I can't imagine what would happen if the fire alarms sounded in that crowded area.
The close-by parking lots were completely full so we had to park at the Ghirardelli square lot, which ended up being a 20 minute drive because of the pedestrian traffic.
author: Paul G.

description: Oh what a bummer! Mostly went to show my eight-year-old stepson a good time, even he wasn't impressed. If you are imagining Monterey Bay aquarium at this place, you will be sadly disappointed. Got a Groupon, only $20 bucks an adult, $10 for children and we still felt like we got ripped off. Yes they have a giant aquarium full of cool fish and sharks and stuff, but that was really the only cool thing about the place. Pretty small, doesn't take long to walk through the whole experience, you get to pet stingrays like in Monterey, but there's only one or two rays and a ton of people trying to touch them, felt sorry for them. Great location in the pier area, we had more fun walking to and from this tiny aquarium with all the things to see then when we actually got inside. There were a few street performers that made the experience worth it in the end. Glad to say I went but will not go back.
author: Prescila B.

description:
Much smaller than the Monterey Bay & Los Angeles aquariums. It's located in a prime location and that's the only positive thing about it. The gift shop's merchandise selection leaves a lot to be desired, the shelves were empty and the gifts were overpriced. The variety of  sharks, starfish, rays and jellyfish was mediocre at best.

I expect an aquarium to be fun and exciting, and that's something that I did not find here. If convenience is the best thing about an aquarium then there must be something wrong about it.
author: Abel K.

description: I haven't been to an aquarium in decades, but this was well worth a wait!! There are different levels with different exhibits and you can spend hours looking at one area and still not see everything offered. I was able to see leopard sharks, anchovies, otters, starfish, sting rays....and so many more. I was even able to touch a starfish and my husband was lucky enough to touch a sting ray. The aquarium offers a behind the scenes tour that takes you through the holding tanks and gives you information of the goings on that the public doesn't usually know about. I HIGHLY recommend making this one of your stops through Pier 39! I know I'll be back
author: Melissa H.

description:
Amazing.  The staff takes such good care of the animals. A big portion of you ticket goes towards a non profit to help teach the future about keeping our oceans clean and other initiatives. 

The octopus and jelly fish were gorgeous. 
The otters are hilarious. 

While you are reading I would like to bring awareness how much plastic goes into our oceans, including straws. Please try to minimize all that plastic during grabbing coffees and take out. 
Reuse. Recycle. And keep these cute animals homes litter free.
author: Zita M.

description:
I took my 3-year-old daughter here during the week and this was her first time at an aquarium. Obviously go during the week to avoid a ton of people, because this place isn't too big. If you go during the week (especially during the school year) you will find crowds of school kids on their field trip. Check out my list of pros and cons below, but over all, i probably won't come back.

Pros: 
- huge underwater fish and shark exhibits 
- jellyfish exhibits are also cool 
- they have a place to touch sting rays & starfish 
- are able to buy tickets online 
- staff are helpful, nice, answer any questions 

Cons: 
- overpriced tickets for a small exhibit overall 
- small/overpriced gift shop
- parking in nearby parking garages can be expensive
author: Anne R.

description:
Don't waste ur money !!!!
Basically there nothing to see. Go to Monterey aquarium instead..
author: Tu L.

description: It's not that bad, but not as impressive as I expected. It is small with not very many exhibits to look at. It gets very cramped as so many people are put into an elevator to tour the tunnels.
author: Samuel F.

description: It's alright, weird how the treadmill like walkway doesn't work. Many fishes but, I think you'd enjoy Cal Academy waaay more. It's pretty limited in here.
author: Jray M.

description:
If you have an hour to spare, visit this aquarium.

With AAA discount you save a couple of bucks.

The main attraction are the tunnels you walk through under the large tanks which house sharks, sturgeons and several other large species of fish.  

There are also a few jelly fish tanks an otter enclosure and a couple of touch-pools, where you can touch anemones, starfish and small rays/skates.  The member of staff orating this exhibit did a good job of explaining different things, great job!

Nice gift shop at the end, but would love to have something more to spend more time at.

Coming from the East coast, this is tiny compared to the New England Aquarium.
author: Cherie D.

description: This is a small aquarium and you could really be done in an hour. I loved the tunnels and the jellyfish and ended up doing that part twice. Friendly and patient staff.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Aquarium of the Bay is the highlight of Fisherman's Wharf.

Even before we moved to San Francisco, we avoided Fisherman's Wharf, with the exception of three things: the sea lions that took over the docks, Scoma's, and the Aquarium of the Bay.

Not nearly on the scale of the aquarium at the Academy of Sciences, but none the less, a nice way to spend a couple of hours.
author: John C.

description:
Price vs attraction. I can't say that it was really worth it. Even with back tracking and having a 3 year old we were able to do the whole attraction in an hour.  It's kind of weird that they have you start at the 3rd floor, take elevator downstairs ant then back up.

I got 50% off admission with my Sac Zoo membership.

I waited 20+ years to visit it and it might be 20+ more before I go back. I remember when it opened when I still lived in SF
author: Sam C.

description: Okay so first of all I have to say that we came from LA so we decided to see this aquarium and it sucked. There was 3 floors, the second was the coolest because of the clear tunnels by t it was sooo short for how expensive it is. Not a lot to do. Literally finished it in like 30 min. And the parking structures was expensive. 12$ the hour, 60$ the max.
author: Kristal K.

description: This aquarium was just average. It is on the smaller side. We were able to walk through in about an hour, even with reading all the signs and seeing all the fish. The "tunnels" were great though. If I were to come back to SF I would probably not visit again.
author: Rachel K.

description: Young or old, yo need to go there and live the experience. highly recommend
author: Mai S.

description: Horrible customer service!!! Does your phone line works? Called numerous time to plan a bday party for my daughter. And they haven't return any phone calls like wth! I know you're busy but still, that's no reason not to return phone calls, I have actually been transferred a couple times and never got a call back!!!
author: Kris J.

description:
A decent amount of fun for such a small package. 

I haven't been to an aquarium for probably 20 years so I was going into this essentially fresh on the whole aquarium thing. Give or take 60 dollars for two adults seemed a bit excessive but I didn't even know what was inside so who knows. 

I know now. This isn't a bad aquarium by any stretch, just take it slow and maybe make a few passes. The aquarium is three floors, floor one is more educational than anything, not a whole lot to take in. The second floor is the winner of the aquarium, it's the part where you go underneath the exhibit and the fish are swimming all around you. It really was quite fun! I was amazed by how dirty the aquarium appeared, I'm sure kids touch the glass all day but there were hand prints EVERYWHERE, including the very top of the tunnel which you can't reach if you're under 5'10. The third floor is the tide pools and the otter exhibit which is all very good fun, I could watch the otters for hours. 

We made two or three passes of the tunnel area and hung out by the otters for a while, we spent two hours in there which really wasn't bad. Just try and go slow, spend as much time as you can observing things. I do have to say it seems like there's more gift store than anything here, I came to see fish, not plush fish. 

The staff was very friendly and polite, no complaints there at all. Just a bit cleaner and a bit more to look at and this would be a really good time.
author: Nick S.

description:
Having been to the Monterey bay aquarium many times, this aquarium was horrible in comparison. It took about 15 minutes to walk through, and didn't have anything that caught my groups attention. 

Maybe add more animals, and visuals to grab the visitors attention
author: Lauren C.

description:
Fun for all ages! The aquarium itself is fairly small but they have a lot to see! There are 3 main exhibits of the aquarium: 

1st-  The underwater tank (so cool!) You walk though a tunnel and can actually see all the fish, rays and sharks swimming around and above you.

2nd - The touch and feel pools, there are 2 pools here  one with rays and another with sea anemones and starfish. 

3rd - The otter exhibit. We could still see them but the otters happened to be sleeping when we came by. The staff informed us that that was actually common as they sleep 75% of the day. 

Overall - a fun and educational experience! It took us only about 30 minutes to walk through he whole aquarium but the nice part is that they give you a stamp on your wrist in  he beginning and you're able to leave and come back at any time throughout the day!
author: Robin C.

description: Aquarium was fun, but might be a bit small for the $27. I did enjoy the cool fish, walk through tank, and it made for a great rainy day activity. There was a $2 discount with AAA membership.
author: Leo A.

description: This aquarium was alright to be honest. There wasnt much to look at besides the jelly fish downstairs and the sharks. 30 for adult admission seems a bit steep. I know shit is expensive at the pier but money can better be spent some where else. I wouldnt recommend unless u must see some marine life.
author: Ethyl M.

description: We came here with our 9 month old son at the time. It was fun my personal favorite was the jelly fish area. They had about 5 different jelly fish from what I can remember. My son really enjoyed the tube you walk through with all the sharks and sting rays swimming above and around you. I'm giving this 4 starts just cause we were excited to see otters at the instillation but when we got to that part there were none around. Over all we have a wonderful experience though!
author: Alexis Vida C.

description: Giving this aquarium 3 stars because the exhibit is very small and not super interesting. We could've walked the whole thing in half an hour. The coolest part of the museum was the shark and stingray tanks that went overhead.
author: Natialliaxoxo ..

description: I went yesterday with my family We really love it. They have very nice tunnels you can see all kind sharks & other fishes. This aquarium has star fishes & very beautiful octopus too. If you have kids they really love this aquarium. We had lot of fun there. I will go back again.
author: Nihad V.

description: My son was excited to go in and we used a Groupon so we didn't have to pay as much... we were disappointed there wasn't too many sharks in the tank and not that much to look at..
author: Andrea R.

description:
Tubular. I could walk in circles through the aquarium tunnels all day, over and over, until I'm in a tizzy. My own feet are entertaining -- the way the prism light reflects through the water and glistens the grounds. Eyes up, we saw the holy mackarel, the small jaws shark, the stingless Mr. Ray, the Mr. Orange fish, the lava lamp-like jellyfish, the sea otter... The only missing attraction is the Sea Horse, which I love at other aquariums. Why you don't represent, San Francisco?!

Some reviews suggest that you can do this whole place in 30 minutes. With kids, it turns into an easy 90-minute cornucopia of excitement. At two hours, it's like, "Enough kids. We have to go home now." The exit through the gift shop makes it harder to leave promptly. The kids want to buy everything that's in there. You might have to threaten to abandon them at The Rock if you don't behave. The Rock being, you know, Alcatraz Island, which is that other attraction just a bit off from Pier 39. Seriously, you might have to come up with ideas to bribe your kids to leave this place on command. #goodtimes
author: Sean C.

description:
Bad things: 

Definitely not as good as many other aquariums in and outside of US. 

It's relatively small.

The Chinese translation sucks really bad. Same English signs, different Chinese translations on different floors. 'Discovery Bay' for example, two total different Chinese translations. It's not professional. 

Good things:

There are employees explaining and guiding when they hear you ask questions. 

The moving belt tunnel is a nice touch.

Those lumpsuckers are cute. Don't remember seeing them in other aquariums.
author: KK R.

description: Was okay, expected a lot more fish for being so close to the ocean. Have seen better aquariums inland. Definitely not worth the price. I wouldn't go back.
author: Kelsey Z.

description:
This aquarium is SMALL. You will be in in 45 min easily.This aquarium is small- you can finish the whole thing in about 45 min. The tickets are pricey- they are $24.95 for an adult. In contrast, the New England Aquarium is way bigger, and costs $27.95 per adult. 

There are 2 floors in Aquarium of the Bay and no penguins.
Here are some of the main attractions:
-Lots of jellyfish. It was cool seeing them swim.
-There is an escalator that goes through a fish tank. You can see sharks and stingrays swim around you.
-There are 2 touch pools, one for touching stingrays, one for touching starfish and sea cucumber. There was a group of students there on a field trip, so I didn't get to touch the stingrays. 
-There were some snakes too.

Not impressed. *Shows not impressed face*
author: Stephanie Q.

description: The aquarium is very small. It took less than 45 min for us to complete from start to finish. The facility is clean, well-maintained and the staff is knowledgeable and friendly. The exhibits are nice, but we expected more from a city like SF. Glad we purchased tickets online and parked in a cheap garage. One visit is enough.
author: Kimmy M.

description: The Aquarium Of The Bay is within walking distance from Pier 39. It's actually a very small aquarium that you can go visit pretty quickly. My boy friend and I took our time exploring around and walking through the tunnels. We fell in love with the underground tank/tunnel because you can see all of the fishes, sharks, and sting rays swimming right above you and around you. Also, it's the best area to take cute photo ops! There's also pools where you can touch and feel different sea animals. Near the end of the aquarium is the otter exhibit as well as the gift shop and bathrooms. Overall, it was a fun experience and great to know that all of the ticket purchases are donated towards saving the sea animals at the Bay.
author: Natasha N.

description:
This aquarium comes across as just a fairly pleasant/interesting way to spend an hour or so away from the bustling crowds at Pier 39. I guess the huge and wonderful Monterey Bay Aquarium has altered my perspectives. The staff here are very friendly and the walkways which provided tunnels under some of the tanks were still pretty cool.

I am not sure if I will return - I think I saw just about everything it had to offer in my relatively short visit. However, families with small children might find this place a restful haven in the midst of a hectic tourist experience.
author: Jack W.

description: This is a REALLY small aquarium.  We got through the whole thing in about 30 minutes.  Hopefully the money went to a good cause.  I wouldn't do this one without a City Pass, and even then, not the best choice.
author: Matt T.

description:
I think it was ok. For the money, I expected a bit more. But, my son wanted to attend and I was happy he had a great time.
I get that it's a tourist attraction, it was more expensive than expected.
author: Tami F.

description:
Nice, small aquarium with interesting animals & lots of tide pools to touch & convenient location on pier 39 with lots of restaurants near by. My two kids (age 6 & 11) enjoyed it. 

It is quite pricy ($27 adult, $17 kids, or $75 family of four). I wouldn't pay full price but we got the SF city pass ($89 adult, $69 kid) which also includes admission to Alcatraz, Exploritorium, Academy of Science, free cable car & bus rides. The SF city pass is a great deal, with it, it's worth the trip to stop by this aquarium.
author: Victoria S.

description: Took our 2 kids (2 and a half and 6 months) and our 14 year old nephew. There were a lot of fun hands on attractions, we got to touch a shark and stingray which was super cool. The best part was the tunnel, you get so see so many fish, sharks and stingrays. It's just a little crowded in there and we had a stroller so it made it a little harder to manuever through but we made it work. The otter habitat was also very cool, I think it's even better that then one In Monterey. This aquarium is small but it's good for younger kids with short attention spans. They also have 2 strategically placed stores in the beginning of the aquarium and on the way out that you have to walk thru to get in and out. Lol but they have cute things and you get to see your pictures from the photo op area they have in the beginning of the aquarium as well. I think this is something we will do again. It was reasonably priced and right on the pier so there a lot of food and other attractions close by. Look for coupon codes for money off tickets! That's what we did! Saved about 20 bucks on our entry.
author: Kelly S.

description: My little family enjoyed it. Great experience!!! Limited things to see but great time killer. #SFGoCard to save money on attractions
author: Maum K.

description:
Great aquarium with several different rooms of exhibits! Our favorites were touching the sting rays, going in the tunnel where fish basically surround you, the jellyfish exhibit, and watching the river otters swim and get fed by staff. At different times throughout the day they do quick interactive lessons. We got to see mini solar robots, which were neat even for kids too young to understand the concept. Not the biggest or most robust aquarium, but definitely a fun several hours for all!

They allow you to leave and return the same day, nice for when you want to take a break for lunch and come back rejuvenated. We arrived right at opening on a weekday and that helped with crowds. Kids 3 and under are free and my kids (3 and 2) really enjoyed it! Teachers get a discount so bring your ID!
author: Christianna S.

description: Don't waste your time or money here. It takes 30 minutes to get through the tunnels of ocean life. Exhibits are small and limited.  Long Beach aquarium is a 10+++ compared to here.
author: Kay K.

description:
I have been so spoiled by the Long Beach Aquarium. I had no idea that other aquariums didn't have the massive exhibits and palatial layout LB Aquarium has - so this was a real letdown. 

Don't get me wrong. The exhibits here are cute and the long tunnel with sharks and other fish are very cool. It's just so -small-. We were in and out in under an hour, even with stopping to read plaques, admire unique fish, etc. I do really like their amphibian and reptile exhibits, that's pretty cool. We didn't stay for any of the talks either, which might have taken up more time, but they didn't particularly interest me. 

Also, the most local parking structure is $10 an hour with a maximum of $50 a day. Say what?! That's outrageous, especially considering this place charges just as much as the Long Beach Aquarium for about... oh, 1/10th as much to look at. 

It was a novel visit but I don't think we'll be back.
author: Rachel N.

description:
I purchased a pass to feed the sharks. Jacob the guide was very helpful and informative. I thought the best part was feeding the sharks themselves but the tour he gave around the back was equally enjoyable. Feed the sharks tour was completely worth the money, I would highly recommend it. 

Some highlights of the tour:

Feeding sharks! Note: don't take as much squid, it's not as popular as the fish!

Touching shark eggs

Seeing baby skates, they're small and translucent!

Seeing all the various tanks at the back and learning about how they care for the fish
author: Phillis Y.

description: I thought it was a little small, we went slow and still only finished in an hour. The bat rays made the whole trip. And the tortious were funny. There's mainly only 2 Flores of exhibits, the bottom floor had two tunnel exhibits, and the first floor had sea otters, bat rays, and touch pool.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Is once of my favorite places I love that my baby love watch the fishes and I love go to walk 
In the week is more cheaper and relax to go with baby's
author: Ruby C.

description:
It's a non profit aquarium so it's very small. I think its worth the $25. Therr are a lot of educational talks during the day and feedings. You get to support the aquarium and get to walk around the tunnel. 

The tunnel itself is very beautiful. There are the smaller fish on one side and the larger deep water fish and sharks on the other.

If you time your trip correctly, you can see multiple feedings during the day. I saw the tunnel feeding and the California touch pool feedings.

They added the sea otters exhibit, which are really cute! They also do feedings for them too. 

The view at this aquarium is incredible. It is right next to a bunch of small shops and you can walk around after the aquarium.

No food inside this aquarium but you can always go outside to the many stores grab something.
author: Kitty Y.

description: Really small aquarium. The only cool things to check out was the otters running around and the shark tanks. I'm pretty sure you will get through everything in 15 minutes.
author: Alan L.

description:
I know this is a non profit establishment... but you do NOT get what you paid for... this has got to be the smallest aquarium by the water I have ever been to and definitely not worth 25$....

There are only 3 small floors, the first floor is pointless with a few tanks, and the only floor worth seeing is the ground floor with the tank tunnels where you see sharks and larger fishes.

If you went to the academy of science, you can save yourself an additional 25$ because the academy has what I feel... a larger selection of things to look at and plenty of tanks and fish as well.
author: Cameron L.

description:
---Atmosphere, Service & Parking--
I visited this aquarium once while living in the Bay Area and perhaps would visit again. It's worthy to check out at least once especially if you're visiting I suppose. It's a smallish aquarium like others have mentioned - I think you can pretty much see everything in under an hour or so, but regardless it's still pretty cool to see various creatures and learn about different things. The aquarium is located on the east marina side of Pier 39 at Fisherman's Wharf. 

The aquarium has three main habitat areas with highlights on the animals living in and around the bay. They have a 300ft tunnel to see some of the many marine animals that they have there. Another segment features various touching pools where you can touch and feel sharks, rays, and sea stars. The last thing I remember seeing is an area that had some otters to look at while they ran around. 

Everyone was friendly who worked here - I'm sure you can talk to them about anything. 

Pier 39 Garage is probably you're best yet to park in although it can get quite expensive besides that there's also a couple close public lots. NOTE: The aquarium does not validate parking at the garage but do ask in case that changes. 

---Prices---
 Buy Online and Save
    $24.95  Adult, $14.95 Child (ages 4-12), $14.95 Seniors (65+), $68.00 Family Rate (2 adults + 2 children)

Check out their site for some various deals and such https://www.aquariumofthebay.org/products/detail/383
author: Aryo S.

description: You can't compare these guys to other world class aquariums, not everyone gets the same funding. They do a great job with what they have and the specimens are well taken care of. Also the staff was really enthusiastic and passionate every time I've been.
author: Elan A.

description:
Beautiful aquarium. But it was slightly disappointing that this place was so small. This place boasts non profit but they charge a pretty hefty fee for entry. then of course you can shell out 30 bucks for some pictures. My daughter had the time of her life. but the trip was short lived. not sure if the price was worth the short walk through the aquarium. 

On the plus side, you get a stamp on your hand upon entry, that way you can come back to the aquarium all day.
author: Kat D.

description:
For my trip to SF, I bought the SF City Pass.  I had an option of going to this aquarium or the Monterey Bay aquarium.  I don't know why, but I thought Monterey was out of they way.   I decided to go to this one and boy, it was kind of a disappointment.

This aquarium is very small.  I managed to see the whole thing in under 30 mins, and I walked extremely slow.  Regardless, it was still nice to see different types of sea life.  I just wished it was more sea stuff to see...
author: Ming T.

description:
Disappointed 
There is just the two tunnels to walk and three touch pools, and sea otter exhibit. 
Which the sea otters are not ocean  
It's nice to be informed but the person there just kept talking and talking and talking. I rather have time to be alone with my kids. 
I wanted to walk away but she wouldn't stop talking. 
I would rather just donate money but not worth the trip to go in.
author: Elia B.

description: The aquarium seemed like an acceptable party-of-one activity to include in my only obligation-free day in this gorgeous city. I'll admit that based upon the price of admission, something larger and more comprehensive was anticipated. Nonetheless, I did enjoy the experience. Moments captured in photos/mind recount the beautiful creatures featured, and continue to lift the corners of my mouth.  : )
author: Janel E.

description:
It was a spur of the moment decision to visit the aquarium because we were hanging out at Pier 39. 

It was very small; I think we were in and out in 30 minutes. Initially it feels no more impressive then a home aquarium but the real attractions here are the 2 tunnel aquariums and the otters. I loved the tunnels but my husband and I got a bit quesy inside. The fish, sharks, and rays were huge and all native to the bay! The otters were, of course, adorable. The giant octopus would've been impressive but it was scrunched as far away as possible from the glass which was a bit sad.

I'd say this place is not a must but I'm ok having gone since the tickets go to helping the bay and aquarium.
author: Christine S.

description:
Okay, so not entirely my fave thing ive done in San Francisco, and unless youve purchased the City Pass, which gives you free entry, i wouldnt really spend money to do this. I mean, in its entirety you could conquer this place in about 30 minutes or less, with more than half of those minutes going to the otter exhibit. 
The only thing that makes this place cool is the underwater fish tunnel thing.
author: Ella A.

description: Needs updates badly. Staff seems to be over their job. Lastly bathroom were clean for the both male and female. But again the space juts felt old as heck.
author: Kevin R.

description: It's a small, non-profit aquarium that's nice to kill some time at. The underwater tunnels are cool and the starfish are fabulous
author: David D.

description: I was shocked how small was this place was  after I paid for the $28 admission. I was completely done in less then an hour.
author: Oanh L.

description: Worst aquarium I have ever been too. It's dirty, very old and smells like dirty feet. Not worth paying a dime to see. PLEASE, PLEASE don't waste your money.
author: Suzie L.

description: Cute little aquarium. My 4 and 5 year old loved it! There are even a couple of touch pools with bat rays, star fish, anenemoes, and other sea creatures that you can touch. Mt favorite exhibit was the river otter exhibit. The kids loved seeing the otters up close. Come early because pier 39 in general gets crowded!
author: Sharine N.

description: Lame! I can't believe how disappointing this place is, and how expensive to boot. It's an aquarium on the ocean. By all means this place should really be something to see. It's not. We got through the whole place in about 20 minutes and there really wasn't much to look at. A few underwater tunes full of little sharks and local fish, a huge octopus in a tragically small tank and a few jelly fish. I wish I could get my $40 back.
author: Desiree T.

description: So so. For 26$ I've expected from this place a little bit more. I thought it will be a huge tunnel, but it's not, and when they said me that I will probably spend 1,5 hours to see everything and I spend 10 minutes. I was quite disappointed.
author: Ratmir K.

description: If you are an aquarium connoisseur then this might not be your forte. But I must give credit for the tanks where you can touch sharks and sting rays, the long under the sea tunnel, and the jellyfish viewing areas. In terms of bringing kids here there is limited interactive things more walking and viewing.
author: Morgan S.

description:
Came here with a work team for an offsite event, and it was a fun visit. While this aquarium is smaller than others in the area, it's a neat experience!

First floor was walking through a jellyfish exhibit, then we shortly moved into a tunnel in a tank itself, with a large variety of fish! I'd never been in one before, and it was pretty cool. I also liked the octopus exhibit and it seems like this aquarium has some unique interactive options: you can put your head up in a bubble in the octopus tank!

The touch and feel pools were also neat, but I felt like I should leave the space for the kids, and walking around the the otters was neat. We went on a weekday afternoon and there were a lot of people, but it didn't feel too crowded, I see that being otherwise on the weekends. 

Overall a fun and interesting experience.
author: Jenni S.

description: Nice people and staff but so tiny!!! It's literally two floors and over. Nice if you have a spare hour, but won't need longer than that. A little expensive at $25 a person for the size.
author: Grace M.

description: This was my first time at an aquarium! I loved the tunnel it was so pretty especially when you see a big sting ray swimming over your head! The workers here are very friendly and willingly to show you around, although one blonde young lady in the the elevator didn't seem too happy about working and had a stank face on the whole elevator ride besides that it was a beautiful aquarium.
author: Trina S.

description:
The Aquarium of the Bay on San Francisco's Pier 39 is focused on marine life in the bay and neighboring waters.  This aquarium comprises two levels; visitor start their tour in the "Discover the Bay" exhibit on level 3, then take an elevator down to the "Under the Bay" exhibit on level 1, where they walk through two underwater glass tunnels.  Finally, via the elevator, they return to level 3, where there are few more exhibits such as "Touch the Bay" and the river otters.
There is no "main hall" to this aquarium, just three passageways separated by the elevator.  The walkthrough of the entire aquarium ends as quickly as it has begun so enjoy while it lasts!  Plus, young children will especially enjoy the "Touch the Bay" exhibit as they get to lay their hands on the living creatures.
The main highlight of my visit was walking through the tunnels, as various sea creatures of swam along and above me as I walked through.  I thought the river otters were highly adorable.  Sadly, my tour through the aquarium ended in less than half an hour.  Prior to the tunnels, I got a cameraman to snap photos of me to highlight my visit; however, when I reached the gift shop to purchase the photos, the clerk told me that I can only obtain hard copies, not digital copies.
For a better aquarium in San Francisco, I would suggest the one in California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park.
author: Akisato S.

description:
Firstly, this is not San Francisco's main aquarium - that is Steinhart Aquarium but it's not nestled in the Pier 39 tourist trap so perhaps not as convenient for some.  The family had been to Steinhart twice this year so we decided to go to the touristy stuff while we hit "Aquarium Of The Bay".  We also hit Ghirardelli Square for a sundae - it's a must.

So... it's pretty small but I would say worth it for the $50 I spent for my two kids and the parental units (myself included).  The several hundred foot long tunnel aquarium was fantastic and is easily the star of the show.  The surprise was the otter exhibit which while we were there had the otters racing around their glassed enclosure like they had just been fed Ritalin stopping intermittently to engage the small children with their faces pressed up on the glass.

Steinhart is the classic aquarium so go there if you want several hours of time to spend but it will be nearly twice as much (love the place) and if you want to go to the Monterey Bay Aquarium it's about 90 minutes drive and thrice the price.  

If your a tourist, just drop the cash and do it already.  Then mosey on over to the Exploratorium and Ferry Building, couple minutes walk to each.
author: Josh D.

description:
One of my favorite things to do is travel and see aquariums. By far I'd have to say this aquarium is a little small but defiantly a great attraction located at pier 39. It's a great place for small kids that would like to see the deep ocean and even get some hands on experience with the animals in the touch pool. 

Of course one of the crowd favorites is the sea otters! Super cute and very playful! The area is a little small for viewing but it clears up every 5 mins or so. Also the viewing area is great for the little ones! It's all glass so you can see them under water too. 

Overall I'd give this place a 4 star rating for family friendly, clean, not too crowded, and excellent curators. You'll always find an answer from the wonderful ocean enthusiasts!
author: Kristine P.

description: This place is terrible. We went today and waited for 20 minutes at the elevator to go to the exhibit to finally be told "oh you have to hold the elevator button down for three seconds". Seriously? A crowd not moving and you don't think to assist ? We paid 50$ to wait 20 mins for elevator to walk to entire exhibit for 10 minutes. If I had paid five dollars I would still be upset, not worth it at all!
author: Karen A.

description: This aquarium was alright. It wasn't very big and if felt very generic. The best part  as the touch pools which were also very generic. Although it wasn't very educational, it was a nice place for a quick sea life fix.
author: Emily M.

description:
I went here because I had a pass from CityPASS San Francisco. The Aquarium of the Bay is located at the entrance of Pier 39 (or the Tourist Hellmouth as I like to call it), on the north-east end of San Francisco. You can easily take a trolly up here from the Embarcadero.

There is one great area in this museum. It's a long clear tunnel with fishes of all sorts swimming all around you. That is the one highlight of this place.

Everything else? Meh. I barely remember anything else. The museum seemed rather unintuitive from a walking standpoint as I figured there might be a set path, but you have to double back and relook at things to get to new exhibits. There are the usual things: jellyfish, petting zoo, some wet wildlife.

I don't really have many words for this place. I'm sure kids will like it.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
The reason for 3 stars is the aquarium is pretty small and tickets are pricy (unless you get something like a Go Card). It probably takes 45 minutes to see everything. 

The aquarium exhibits are really nice.  Especially tunnels you walk thru in the shark tank. And the staff is very knowledgeable and friendly.  Kids seemed to really enjoy it too. 

I'd recommend visiting just look at getting a pass like a Go Card to keep the price reasonable.
author: Brian R.

description: Really enjoyed our time here with the kids. It's relatively inexpensive if you buy tickets as a "package". Overall a very friendly staff and something fun to do. I would recommend anyone to visit the aquarium if they are in the area.
author: Cody D.

description: 26.95 is super expensive for how small this place is.  That's the biggest complaint.  We also bought the Behind The Scenes Tour which was awesome.  The only complaint there is it is 45 minutes long and they stick to that time and stop the tour wherever you are.  The coolest part of the tour is you get to walk above the huge tanks, but our tour guide spent so much time in the kitchen talking about how they prepare and keep track of the feedings, that by the time we got to the cool part we had to walk thru and then the tour was over and she rushed us out.
author: Allison C.

description: Fantastic place went with my family mi mom love the tunnel it's amazing and great place to go, a little bit short but definitely worth it
author: Josue M.

description: When I went (today), this aquarium had dreamy live music in the shark tunnel! It took what was already an amazing immersive experience to another dimension. The music was the highlight, but everything was good, including the customer service, educational information and exhibits.
author: Bea B.

description: As Coloradans and out of town, we were highly disappointed that when we were late from tram delays to the aquarium, we were only given 20 minutes to peruse the exhibits for around $60 for the two of us. That is a rip-off, mainly because we were told at the ticket center that we had as long as we wanted. The supervisor also kicked us out from the gift shop when we were only looking to give them our money and service from the start. How rude, and idiotic is that. They don't deserve our business and they sure as heck don't deserve any of your business.
author: AnnaLeah W.

description:
Warning: Long, educational review to follow! This is a great educational and relaxing place that the whole family will enjoy. 

We entered through the gift shop, immediately going to a few exhibits in cylinders and tanks against the walls. One of those exhibits was the "Trash Tank," where they show what happens when people throw their trash in the ocean. There was a decorator crab in there, so named because they camouflage themselves by decorating their shells with items from the environment. And speaking of "shells," the decorator crab doesn't really have one. It's more like a spider or snake that outgrows its skin, then sheds the "shell," and its outer skin starts hardening up again. Once the skin gets too hard and inhibits growth, the process starts again. Cool! 

Once through the tanks room, you go down the elevator to the jellyfish displays. I learned many things from the employees: the very fine, thread-like appendages are stingers and for protection only; the shorter, more gloppy limbs are actual arms that the jellyfish uses to eat. If you can't see the gloppy arms, that means it's eating. Also, if you see through a jellyfish, there are four circles, like on a sand dollar. These are four stomachs, and when you see colored rings around them, you are seeing its digested food. Awesome. 

On into the tunnels. These tunnels have both a moving sidewalk and a standing/walking part; I'd recommend walking through and going at your own pace, though if you come too late they'll be turned off. The first tunnel contains the native bay fish and real bay water, part fresh, part salt, but it's filtered so it's less murky and you can see through it. Lots of starfish populate this area, which, like jellyfish, have thicker, stringy folds in their centers. In the sea stars, as they call them now, these are mouth and anus parts; the food goes in and out the same spot. If you can't see strings in the center, the sea star/starfish is content. 

The second tunnel contains more deeper, saltwater fish. The ones that look like catfish with "whiskers" are actually sturgeon, and those "whiskers" are growths called barbels. Catfish and sturgeon are not related. I didn't get to explore this second tunnel much, since I had to meet my ferry, but I'd recommend checking out the different rock fish and watching the schools swim by. 

Back up the double-sided elevator and out the back this time. There's a tidepool to touch sting rays, sea stars, and other fish (only with one finger), as well as jumping seals to get your picture taken next to. Don't forget souvineers on your way out. 

Very educational. Go and enjoy a few hours to really see everything.
author: Audra S.

description:
Awesome aquarium.  I would say that it's probably one of the better ones I've been to since their are two levels and the exhibits are pretty massive.  A lot of interactive pools with live animals and attendants not to mention even someone answering questions when you ride the elevators.

The design of this aquarium is probably what makes it somewhat unique.  It is small and about the size of the one in Vegas.

Otter exhibit was probably one of the coolest since that are so active and you can see pretty much everything.
author: Ben H.

description: Overall, the Aquarium wasn't bad. It was on Pier 39 which was our first stop. It was kind of small. The biggest thing I liked about the Aquarium was the tunnel of Sharks. That was cool. Everything else was pretty basic and small. Overall, it's a nice see attraction just to say you have been, but I honestly think if you missed it you wouldn't be hurt.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Don't waste your money.  It's underwhelming and overpriced. There are so many better things to do in the city!
author: Chloe A.

description: We had a fun time here looking at the sea life and seeing all the wonderful things they are doing, from a conservation perspective.  It was quite fun as there was also a field trip and lots of kids there enjoying and seeing nature.  Looking at life through the lens of a child and seeing the wonder there was quite awesome.
author: Jerry V.

description: This was an awesome experience. Cool to see all of the bay animals. And the staff was really knowledgeable. I loved listening to the worker by the otters about his Australia story where the otters would steal from other enclosures. You can tell when people love what they do.
author: Katrina P.

description:
I'm from San Mateo so I bought a local discounted ticket for $18. 

I got here really early, probably 9:30am and it was almost empty. I recommend going early because it can get pretty crowded especially in the tanks that have sharks and the exhibits where you can touch the animals.

I really enjoyed all of their exhibits and I thofuhr I got my money's worth by being able to go through all of the exhibits twice. I left around 10:30am and that's when I noticed a lot more people coming in.
author: Patty C.

description:
I'm from the Bay Area but this was my 1st visit to the Aquarium of the Bay. If you haven't been, it's definitely worth the trip! But it's pricey & small...hence the four stars.

$23 per adult & the whole visit took less than 2 hours, including searching the two gift shops.

Elvators take you up & down the different levels. Jellyfish, a huge octopus, a couple sharks, turtles, crabs, & otters. Also, a couple pools to touch the starfish, sea cucumbers, & manta rays. Typical aquarium stuff. The gift shops had a lot of cool things. Nothing really for babies, so our 1 year old didn't leave with anything except for a wooden puzzle. But he still had fun so no big deal.

Overall, we had a great time & the $46 to get in was well worth it!
author: Savy B.

description:
My wife and I were looking for something to do today because it was a little chilly out... We stumbled  upon this!

It was very reasonably priced and some really interesting sea life!  The staff was super friendly and helpful!

The exhibits for the most part were really cool especially the tank where you get to touch a sting ray and a shark!  The one draw back was the sea otter was taking a nap... We really wanted to see him.

Not the aquariums fault by any means but only reason I can't give 5 stars... Really fun way to spent an hour though we have some great pictures!
author: James C.

description: Do not waste your money! You pay almost $30 for 30 minutes of subpar tanks/aquariums. The conveyer belt wasn't even working to go through the tunnels. I have a better aquarium in my living room...
author: Kyle C.

description: I had low expectations for this place so I was happily surprised to see so many cool jellies, a tunnel tank, and river otters. It's a nice getaway from the hustle and bustle of Pier 39. I'll definitely come again to get lost in jellyfish heaven.
author: Fiona Y.

description: I really enjoyed this Equarium! Seeing other reviews states its small, yes it is a bit small, but i think its beautiful all the fish and sea erchands you see. Its a great place to take family and especially if you have kids theyd really enjoy it and have a good time. They have a petting area too. The tunnels are pretty cool you can see the sharks, stingrays and other fish. I love the pretty star fish. The octopus are beautiful!!definitely recommend if you're in the area!
author: Heather O.

description: This was exactly what I expected based on other Yelp reviews. We (two adults) were in and out of here in an hour. We went for the new otter who was asleep! Still cute. I thought the price was a bit steep but I understand it's non-profit with what I imagine are high operating costs. I wouldn't recommend this place to my family/friends when they visit.
author: Emma B.

description: Very brief and lots of the exhibits are showing their age. The moving walkway through the tunnels were not operating when we were there. The tunnel was always dead silent - no ambient music or anything. The exhibits are also not very long. I'm the type who likes to stop and read everything but I made it through in two or three hours.
author: William C.

description: It's definitely a lot smaller than the Monterey bay aquarium but it's not a bad aquarium to spend an hour in.
author: Katie H.

description:
This was a pretty good aquarium! By no means is it like Monterey Bay, but it is still very fun and great for little kids. They have an opening section where it is mostly a petting area so kids can see a lot of critters more up close and personal. However, my favorite part was the tunnel. You walk through a tunnel that has hundreds of fish, sharks, and more and there is an employee there that can answer most any questions you have about the wildlife. Also, the otter section was really cool to see.

It's conveniently located just off of Fisherman's Wharf. So if you have some extra time to kill, want to experience as much of SF as possible, this could be a good stop for you. It is also a pier or two (so a block or two) away from Alcatraz and the Saturday Farmer's Trade Market. 

I would recommend buying tickets here in a package, it makes it more cost effective. Otherwise, I am not sure the $30 bucks is necessarily worth it for the size of the aquarium (though it is very well maintained and is still a neat experience). I am a baller on a budget, so I really try to have the most bang for my buck. We had military discount, so it helped a bit. 

3 stars because I've had better for my money, but honestly it is on the verge of 4 stars because it is pretty cool. I wouldn't go back again, it was kind of a one time deal for me. I think if you have kids it would be a much better experience!
author: Rebecca A.

description: I have been calling since you guys since you opened and it is now 2 pm still no answer. Had a few questions before we go but I guess we will not be. Please work on a better way customers can reach your business. I even e-mailed no response.
author: Shelle B.

description:
Go online and look for a smartsave discount for 20% off the general admission price. Yes, this aquarium is kind of pricey but I enjoyed my stay. It also is kind of small compared to other aquariums i've been to but this is the first time experiencing the water tunnel - theres two of them. If you're lucky you'll get to see a "live feeding". 

They have an octopus, kind of big but in a small tank. I kinda feel bad for the guy. 
They also have hands on interactive touching to feel the back of a shark, stingray wings, sea cucumbers and starfishes. 

Overall it's great for kids, and others who love any sort of marine life!
author: Leo S.

description: The otter lady.  Ruined it.  She was this shape of water weirdo, way too young to be so pathetically party pooping on the exhibit.  She was basically harassing and soured the whole experience.  Young lady go on a date, interact with human beings and maybe you'll find a way to smile one day.
author: Gogo K.

description: We enjoyed our time here, however it was very small. I was hoping it would be a bit bigger, but we still had a great time. The shark tunnel was very cool to walk through! We loved seeing the jellyfish, and all of the employees were extremely helpful in guiding us on exactly what we were seeing.
author: Martina H.

description:
When you come to Fisherman's Wharf, you're probably not thinking that there's an aquarium here for you to visit. For you aquarium connoisseurs, you're missing out if you don't stop by this place. I think I came here for the first time after I left the bay area which is a pity because this is probably my second favorite aquarium here in California. Yes it is located on the pier and you think from all their advertisements that it's just a tourist trap but it's a good one! 

If you parked at the Pier 39 garage you get $2 off a general adult ticket so be sure to use it. You take an escalator upstairs and prepare for a several level experience of all the bay's sea creatures. You start off with some of the more tropical fish that you don't get too much here in California but as you go deeper and deeper you'll see displays of jellyfish, kelp forest fish and many others. Take a trip downstairs and your adventure continues with more local fish and then the shark tunnel.

Even the shark tunnel features fish from the local area including the 7 gill shark which is the largest shark that is endemic to the area. Yes, there are great whites too in SF bay but not all that common. They had large sturgeons, rays and guitarfish which are always fun to see. Your trip ends with a lot of reptile and amphibian displays followed by 3 playful male otters that are a hoot.

Park at Pier 39 for all your Fisherman's Wharf shenanigans. While the price is initially startling, your discounts make up for it and also the headache of trying to find somewhere cheaper to park would offset it as well.
author: Eric C.

description: 10 min show and tell.  This place is small!  I would have been enraged if I paid full price to see this.  Get it in a package deal.  Otherwise don't waste your time.
author: James B.

description:
I LOVED this aquarium!  It is located at Pier 39 so there are a multitude of activities you can do either before or after visiting this tourist attraction. It is a bit expensive, but what is "reasonable" these days!? 

Things to note: try to go early on in the day. If you go in the afternoon, the animals are not as active and it takes from the experience.  There is a hallway/tunnel you walk through.  Look around and you see sharks, fish, sea rays swimming around and above you!  Maybe I'm not hip to aquariums and don't realize that this is common but I thought it was great!
author: Allison J.

description: Ive been coming here almost every year since I was little, and I spent my sixteenth birthday here today !!
author: Madison W.

description: I love this place and always visit it when in SF. Only negative is that it is too small! Great staff! Again must go if you are in town! Perfect spot for all ages!
author: Ray K.

description:
Aquariums are fun, but this one was a little sad for a location in San Francisco. I would expect San Francisco to have an awesome aquarium, but I guess they'll just leave that honor to Monterey. Fortunately, Aquarium of the Bay wasn't too pricey -- especially if you live in the Bay Area. You can get a local's discount if you show your ID. 

This place has two levels, with the large fish tank containing the sharks downstairs. We got there in the afternoon, and unfortunately missed the otter talk feature, but did manage to catch the shark and fish tank feeding hour. We left before the feature on the lizard upstairs.

They have two small tide pools where you can touch stuff like starfish, but these are pretty popular with the children. They have paper towels to dry off next to the pools, which is nice.

I loved the otter exhibit -- so cute! I wish it was a bit larger, or that we had caught the otters when they were more active. But I did get to watch an otter try to climb some tree branches, which was cute since they're not the best climbers to begin with.

This is a nice little tourist joint, but I'll probably stick to Monterey for my aquarium fix.
author: Alyssa B.

description: The only pro is that they're a nonprofit, majority of the money goes towards conservation in the bay. Wish I would have look into yelp before going. Sooo bummed to have spent $50 only to walk in a stuffy and cramped space with lots of people. There are very busy escalators to take you and EVERYONE else to view other parts of the aquarium, and the stairs are only an optional if lead by a "tour guide" (lame, unorganized, confusing). My fiancé and I left before making it to the end because of how overcrowded and time consuming it was to just walk into the shark tunnel. California Academy of Sciences sounds like a way better time if you're looking into an aquarium experience, hoping to see for myself next time I'm in SF.
author: TJ B.

description: I'm very disappointed to say the least... I was trying to ask a employee a question about the aquarium (how long a normal visit would be) and she said "I'm on break and I have to go" this made me not want to go inside but maybe that's because my party wouldn't go in with me... hopefully this blonde headed employee doesn't ruin someone else's experience.
author: Kate W.

description: Decided to take the long trip up north to San Francisco.... on our way back, we decided to stop by the Monterrey Bay Aquarium.... and OH MY.... I'm so in love.... it's absolutely wonderful... the fact that I saw a whale while on the deck was amazing... I def need to go back!
author: Sandra S.

description: I first came to the aquarium when I was a kid and it had just opened, I was awed then and still impressed now. This aquarium was a great visit. We have two young children, so it was the perfect size. If you're looking for a long experience that lasts hours, this isn't the place, they focus on local fish and marine animals of the Bay, that is unique and wonderful. All of the exhibits are put together artfully and beautifully. It's also nice to know that $0.88 of every dollar paid in admission goes to conservation of the Bay and it's animal life/habitats. We'll head back the next time we're in San Francisco.
author: Katie R.

description: Really fun! My son and I enjoyed so much especially the otter and the sting ray touching exhibit!
author: Elle P.

description: It's ok to go there just for a walk or just to do something. It's not very big. I thought it was going to be better because it is at Pier 39 .
author: Arlette S.

description:
I came here last week and it was an unpleasant experience. This aquarium was so crowded and uncomfortable. We came mid afternoon but maybe it's better early in the morning. All of the employees were not overly nice or helpful. The bottom floor is unimpressive and unkept, the tunnels were very dark and murky. Additionally, the children were screaming and yelling. I had a headache when I left. The upper level has two touch pools with sting rays and starfish. The girl who works at the touch pool has a microphone that she used A LOT to remind people to "only touch the edges" of the string rays. Many adults were not watching their children at the touch pools, which was making the microphone girl mad. Additionally, there is a rock wall that is labeled with a sign that says, " do not climb on wall." There were families just watching as their children climbed on the wall to look into the touch pool with the sea stars.  A couple of the animals in this room were removed from their exhibits. The otters were so sad. I felt bad for them to be in such a tiny exhibit. The aquarium employee said the otters were napping and that they were more active when they were being fed. She said we could come back with our tickets later to see if they were more active. 

Overall, if you like screaming children and absolute chaos, this is the place for you! 

I wish I could get my money back. If you want to go to an Aquarium, check out the California Academy of Science.
author: Taylor W.

description:
I drove from the south bay into the city just for the aquarium so I was a bit disappointed when I saw the aquarium.  The aquarium is nice but there aren't many exhibits.  The highlights are two large tunnels that you can walk through and see he fish from an unusual view point (like you are inside their tank).  The rays seem to like to swim over the tunnel glass so you get a close up view of their underside.  It is fun but I don't think this meets the bar as a destination place.  I'd recommend this place if you are already visiting Pier 39.

In addition to the aquarium, I signed up for the 'Feed the shark' event which happens only on certain days and times so check their website to make reservations (only 5 guests per feeding).  It's much more than the act of feeding the sharks which is really just throwing some squid into the big tank.  You get a behind the scenes look at the aquarium with a private guide (1 guide to 5 guests) so you can ask all the questions you want about the fish or the aquarium.  I found it very educational and very interesting to see the facilities, to learn how their water filtration works, learn about their feeding, and see the quarantine areas.  If you add in this event, then I think the aquarium is worth the trip out.

Aquarium only: 3 stars
Feed the sharks: 4 stars
author: Lily L.

description:
My husband and I had some time to kill before our Alcatraz tour. Pier 39 is quite the tourist trap, so we figured we might as well check out one of the attractions! Plus, tickets were only like $20.

This isn't a very big aquarium, but the fish tunnel is pretty sweet. When you enter there are a few tanks with things like small fish, frogs, and other non exciting sea creatures. At first my husband and I thought that was it and we were about to be pissed - surely there's more! We weren't  given any direction, so we asked an employee where we could find more exhibits. She directed us to the elevators which took us to two additional levels of sea life.

We saw sting rays, turtles, sea otters, jelly fish, star fish, sharks, and tons of other fish. Of course the aquarium was full of kids, but it wasn't overly crowded which was nice. We were still able to get up to each of the tanks. 

The best part by far was the tunnel. You walk through and are completely surrounded by water with sharks, fish, sting rays, and more. Pretty cool seeing sharks swim above you!

All in all it was a good experience. Nothing mind blowing, but for the price it was a fun way to spend an hour. I can imagine that children would totally get a kick out of this, so definitely bring the kiddos!
author: Jacqueline B.

description:
It's a fun little destination. Pretty small place, not huge by any means. You could probably see every exhibit and be in and out of here in less than an hour. It's no Monterey Bay Aquarium, but the atmosphere is just as nice. I was a little bit taken aback that they had some non-aquatic exhibits like Chinchillas and Lizards near the tide pool area - so bizarre.

Still $25 is a pretty fair price for entry. I think you get a discount if you are a local or you used mass transit to get there. Not quite enough content in the area to keep you there for a full day, but if you are already around Pier 39 looking for more stuff to do it's a good way to educate yourself on some sea life and see some cool critters up close.
author: Casey D.

description: The Aquarium of the Pacific is well worth its ticket price. The Monterey Bay Aquarium is well worth its ticket price. Sea World is well worth its ticket price. This Aquarium of the Bay had SOME cool fish to look at, but it is not worth its ticket price. This Aquarium would be worth its ticket price if it doubled in size and added additional variety of fish.
author: Teri E.

description: Overpriced for what you get.  This aquarium took us 45 minutes to walk through.  The tunnels are cool and unique, but not enough.  The river otters were cool, as was the touch pool.  That is basically the whole place.  Oh, the lady at the front desk was rude when we were there.  She maybe needs to work with...not people.
author: Tom T.

description: This is much smaller than Monterey aquarium, but it was nice to roam threw on a chilly evening in SF- it only took us about 45 min to see everything ( tunnel with big fish and sharks are the boys favorite).  The otters are adorable and very active (girls favorite!) I do think it's worth the money, although there is a lot to do in this area. It was great to stroll threw while waiting an hour for a table at a near by restaurant, on a freezing cold night.
author: Donnette T.

description:
This is actually the first aquarium that I've ever been to. Which is surprising since I've lived in SF a majority of my life and just came here fairly recently.

Getting here by car can be the biggest hassle. Same with public transportation. But if anything, you can catch the 8X muni bus to Fisherman's Wharf and there you go.

My hubs took me here for my 19th birthday (yes that was 3 years ago, still feels recent lol) and I was strangely excited while going up the escalator. When we got there, we paid for our tickets (i dont recall how much, but we got discounted for being locals there.. well, he did, actually. Not me haha). What was cool was that they provided you with shark hats! It's like getting the BK crown from Burger King but this one's a dang shark!

To summarize my experience, it was a fairly small aquarium with lots of information about the sealife and its creatures. My favorite part was going through the tube where you got to look at the sea creatures from all around. After that is another museum that shows more land animals. I think there's a few interactive exhibits, like where you gey to touch one of the animals or something.

To make our visit memorable, i bought our picture taken by one of the workers. But mehhhh it was kinda expensive! It was about $30 ish bucks for two semi-medium shots.

It's not the most fanciest aquarium, but it's worth going to if you've never been. Plus, it's in Fisherman's Wharf, the food here is endless.
author: Jerianne G.

description: Not worth the money! Very short tour but I gave three stars for the sharks swimming above us!
author: Love R.

description: Animals are well taken care of and tanks are cool but the aquarium itself I fairly small and the staff are pretty slow and seem uneducated about the animals / programs of the aquariums research.
author: Cayla H.

description: Definitely worth going and seeing!!! The jellyfish tunnel is my favorite! They're so beautiful to watch! You can also touch stingrays! It was a great visit especially for the little ones!
author: Karen P.

description: Zero stars. What a rip off. $25 per person and you were done in less than an hour. Unless you've never been to an aquarium before, don't waste your time or money.
author: Jg F.

description: My family and I really loved this aquarium! There was so much to see and do for the little ones! The tunnels were awesome for even infants to gaze up at. My 2 yr old loved getting splashed by a sting ray and touching their fins. The otters were definitely a cute site to see as they were playing in and out of the water. We went on a Monday in the summer and it was a good crowd, not uncomfortably busy. I would definitely recommend coming to this aquarium!
author: Kaitlin E.

description:
Yes, its small. No, that doesn't make it any less cool.

Husband and I went there about two hours before closing and it was thankfully semi-empty.
As soon as you walk in you see about three or four huge tanks with cool fishies, eels, and other sea critters. My husband and I are huge on actually reading things so we read everything and I even learned that Great White Sharks can make an appearance near SF! Le gasp.

After that you go down in an elevator and see the all the Jellies. Super rad.
Then you go into the first tunnel. Mostly small to large fish and sea stars.
At the end of that is the octopus which was REALLY active when we we're there :)
Next is the second tunnel with the cool stuff: sharks and huge manta rays.
After that its pretty much over. Lol. You go up an elevator and come out to a frog tank and two "tide pools" where you can touch sea stars and little beebee string rays, I think (no stingers so its safe). They also have some reptiles and a chinchilla. (?)
After that is three or four otters in a huge glass tank/room thing and GOOD LUCK trying to see them/take pictures. They're like hyperactive kids after having a pound of candy.

And that's it.
If you have some time to kill I would recommend going there. What really does it for me is that our aquarium here in San Diego (Birch Aquarium) doesn't have those cool tunnels you can walk through.

Plus the music is amazing. If you're stressed just go for the music. It'll calm you down within minutes.
author: Amy A.

description:
5 stars for little kids! Not too big or overwhelming, not too crowded, well-staffed, and an impressive collection of sea life considering the smaller size of the facility.

Yes, there are bigger aquariums elsewhere that are a better value for your money, but this little one is perfect for the times when you don't have a whole day to spend and especially for visiting with little kids for 45 minutes to an hour. It's also a nice introduction to aquariums for older kids who wouldn't be able to handle a 5+ hour visit. If I was traveling with older kids and was planning to make a full day of it, I probably would have been disappointed. So knowing your audience and what to expect beforehand is the key to walking away happy. 

As others have said, the best part is the 300-foot aquatic tunnel. I was impressed that it was staffed with people to point out the different types of sea life and to answer my daughter's questions. 

The touch tanks were also fun. We got to touch sea stars, baby sharks, and baby sting rays. 

The facility itself is very well-maintained and the fish tanks appear clean. There is a nice deck out back with views of the boats, and the elevators are fully staffed, which I hadn't expected. The bathrooms are clean.

We paired the aquarium with the double-decker carousel at Pier 39 as a nice pre-dinner excursion and had a great time. It's a great experience for the Kindergarten and lower elementary crowd. Highly recommended!
author: Brenda A.

description: It  was okay. I liked Monterey bay aquarium better and the California Academy of Science! It was small,but amazing. I loved the string ray and the fresh water ! I would go back again.
author: Melinda E.

description: It is kinda expensive, yes. But I think this is a cute aquarium. Yeah it's nothing like the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach but the people at this aquarium are so friendly! Which is something the aquarium in Long Beach doesn't have. This aquarium has very knowledgeable people working here and who are more than willing to answer all your questions, they really seem to enjoy their job!
author: Cindy G.

description:
With a Groupon in hand, my boyfriend and I came to the Pier specially to come to this aquarium mainly cause I love jellyfish and I know they had some here. 

They had some different jellyfish tanks that I basically spent 30 or so minutes ogling and going back and forth between tanks much to my boyfriend's amusement. 

However, that's literally the only highlight for me. The rest of the aquarium was very small and cramped. Although the underwater tunnel was cool it goes by really fast. 

After the tunnel, the river otters were very popular and one can see why when they run around and chasing each other then diving into the water! 

There were stingrays and starfish you can touch and see other types of creatures such as octopus, frogs and turtles. 

For $12.99 a person (this is Groupon price) it was alright though I would prefer to go to the Exploratorium or SF Zoo instead since there's more to see and you get more bang for your buck. 

ps. If you are an AAA member you can actually get FREE parking! While my boyfriend drove us to the Pier, I just randomly looked on their website to find that if you go to the California Welcome Center and present your AAA card, your first two hours are FREE!
author: Rainar W.

description:
The aquarium is small but the staff are energetic knowledgeable. This is a great place for young inquiring minds to learn about regional wildlife.

All animals are representative of the Bay Area.

There are nicer and larger exhibits in the region at the Monterey Aquarium.
author: David P.

description: Much to my dismay this aquarium was very underwhelming and quite small. Even the aquarium back in Denver was much larger and we're in a land locked state and a couple of dollars cheaper too!
