There were a few cool things such as jelly fish, shark tank, and otters, but I wouldn't waste my time or money here.  Go spend that money on a lobster roll or something lol
author: Phung L.

description: This aquarium is nice but really small. However the exhibit was nice but I'd rather spend the extra money to go to the Academy of Science. It's convenient if you are in the area and also if you live in the Bay Area counties there is a locals discount.
author: Monique T.

description: This aquarium is so small, and they dont have anything special about the bay. Just like the other small aquarium that i visited before. Plus the gift store so expensive.
author: Steve Vu N.

description:
Came for a special "Aquapalooza" party night at the aquarium.  I feel bad that I have to compare it to the Academy's Nightlife nights, but the Bay was really lacking in excitement. It was much smaller than I had anticipated. It also feels very outdated.  I feel major updates are needed with the prices they're charging.

What I liked was the shark tunnel and the octopus (though it seems strange that the tank is well-lit?). There was a stingray petting pool and a little place for sea otters. 

The flashing headphones they gave us as part of Aquapalooza were staticky and went in and out of signal (occasionally blaring Katy Perry).  The food was decent, little hotdogs and tacos. 

Would probably be an okay place to take small children, but I found it very underwhelming.
author: Trish P.

description: This aquarium is pretty enjoyable but to me doesn't seem worth the ticket price. There are a variety of fish, two types of sharks and a few sea otters. That's fun and all but to pay $50 for this to me is ridiculous. If you're taking children this place is A1. If it's just a couple adults, go to Monterey.
author: Gabriel C.

description: Unfortunately the aquarium was a disappointment. The entry fee was high for a view of tanks. They make it clear, once inside, that you are only viewing tanks and not the actual bay. I also found it odd that they had a river otter segment rather than an ocean otter segment. Why imply that you are featuring sea animals from the bay and then not showcase them?
author: M B.

description: We enjoyed looking at the aquariums but it was expensive for what they had. Aquariums were poorly labeled, we frequently had to search to find what type of fish we were looking at. There was a lot of trash lying around on ledges of most exhibits and all around the touch and tide pool room. The bathrooms were so disgusting we left and found public restrooms elsewhere. The staff was not as interested in teaching about the animals as I would have hoped and seemed to just be there to make sure no one tried to pick up a stingray and that everyone knew the names of the otters.
author: Janice T.

description:
The aquarium is smaller than others I've been to before, but it was still fun! This aquarium was pretty empty the day we went (better photos though :) ). There are two separate tunnels, one with small fish and the other with the bigger ones.  I thought the first tunnel was the only one and was disappointed since it seemed pretty empty, but the second one was filled with sharks, stingrays, and big fishes! I could have spent forever in there. They also have a small exhibit where you could touch small stingrays and starfishes. 

It is definitely on the pricier side for an aquarium, especially considering the size, which is why I'm knocking off a star. Bought the ticket on Groupon (only saved a dollar off the listed price online), and it came with a photo souvenir.
author: Helen L.

description:
We loved the Aquarium by the bay.
Our 5 year old granddaughter and her parents and grandparents were there last Tuesday, we spent 2 hours there and saw everything. It was just enough time for a 5 year old. She loved the otters diving into the waters. The sharks and the jelly fish were the favorites. A great day with some cotton candy and ice cream and a carousel ride . Topped it off with food at Chart House .;watching   the sail boats, ferry boats and Red and White fleet  and the playful seals from the bay windows .
author: Ginger M.

description:
Had a great behind the scenes tour with Sidney. 
Only gripe was the other $44 we spent for the aquarium part. Save your money. Wish I knew, would have just done the tour. :) She was awesome! Do it.
author: Mike A.

description:
I mean, they have fish...

This was a pretty small aquarium compared to ones I have been too. (Atlanta, Coney Island). So I would say it's a nice stop it you need something to do for like 30 minutes. They say they have the longest underwater tunnel buuuuut it's nothing that really makes you want to stop and star for more than 3 minutes. I DID love the jellyfish. All three tanks. 
And the otters were adorable. But I honestly felt like the novelty stores there were more thought out than the actual aquarium. 

Pros: they have a nice area where kids can touch the fish. Fun playful otters, awesome jellyfish. 

Cons: doesn't really feel as interactive, only time you see the guides are in the elevators.
author: Veronica S.

description: This place is so great! I keep going back but sometimes the ppl in there r kinda weird or creepy or yell at u... anyways, I love it and I enjoy looking at the sharks and fish and jellyfish and they have a touch aquarium for the kids :)
author: Penny N.

description:
Admission is about $26 per adult.  3 and under are free and you get 50% off with a membership from SF or OAK zoo.  Parking is terrible since it is in a heavy tourist area.  Take public transit if possible.

The aquarium is quite small.  If you have been to Monterey Bay aquarium, this is much much smaller.  It is very very busy on weekends.  It took away from my enjoyment because I felt quite rushed.  Since I got 50% off of the admission with my zoo membership, it was ok but I would not go again since it is such a tourist area (Pier 39--Fisherman's Wharf).
author: S C.

description:
Well I'll be damned and slathered with whip cream and caramel sauce!  I got my money back! Checked last night and it was back.  Great job finance department! I was impressed on how they immediately processed my refund for the ticket that I wont be able to use (confused? read previous review). 

Kudos to you for providing over-all satisfaction to this customer.
author: Joy U.

description:
And a half maybe! It's not big and sort of rotates around to a second floor that won't take you that long to walk through but the breathtaking sea life will make you want to go home and clean your aquarium and restock it with some new fish and the touching pond or whatever they call it is really a great feature for children,mine loved it. It's easy to get to if you are on foot and already parked being as San Francisco is pretty much a parking lot from one end to another,(though beautiful).
Lots of scenic,sight seeing and shops here on the Embarcadaro area for you to enjoy of course as well. This one is not as big as Monterey but somehow it has more intense sea life to cause a lasting memory of.I love this place! My wife loves sea life as well.
author: Brian D.

description: Definitely worthwhile - don't expect it to compare to Monterey Bay Aquarium. However, the wow's come from the start, jelly fish, long walk through tunnel with tiger sharks, sting rays and schooling fish, then kids can get up close to bat rays at touch pools, and finally River otters!  It was worthwhile - my 3 year old loved the experience and I was entertained too! We bought a City Pass so entrance was at a discount.
author: Carrie W.

description: I am so disappointed in the Customer service at Aquarium of the Bay. My family and I planned a visit here weeks in advanced for my 5 year old disabled niece. It was her first time out of her home in several months and we wanted to plan something in door that she would love. We called the day before the 28th of October and checked online for closing hours and when arrived all the way from Fresno it turns out this places closed early they day for a private event. It was so devastating, but mainly frustrating because we called first to ensure the closing time and we checked online yet and was told "we close at 6" we get to the front and the Aquarium was closing around 3pm. Work on ensuring people about proper closing times!!! Folks travel long distances to come here and things like this happens.
author: Sophia J.

description:
This is a nice little aquarium. The fee is cheap and what you get to view inside is totally worth it.

My favorite is the shark walkway. It's gorgeous. You're surrounded by different types of sharks. It's a tunnel.

The jellyfish were really cool too. It's a must-see for SF tourists.
author: Kathy V.

description:
We visited aquarium as a part of last trip to SF, it's a good place but I felt a little underwhelmed because of the expectations from the brochures.

Anyway, all proceeds go towards maintaining the Bay Area marine life and you get to see sharks up close.

Highlights:
1. Jelly Fish
2. Sharks
3. Water tunnel
author: Ankit A.

description: It's a pretty small aquarium for being on the bay. There's basically three sections to it. Great for little kids. You can go through it in an hour. Touch pools are pretty neat.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: This is not much of an aquarium.  While this small place is nice, for what you get, it is very pricey.  $25 for adults.  The family rate is $70 if your kids are 4-12.  It was our first time there and I was shocked to realize it took my family about 45 minutes to see it all, and we were taking our time.  It is unlikely we will ever return.  If you can find a discount somewhere, use it!
author: Anonymom M.

description: Ok aquarium in the touristy Pier 39.  It's nothing special but they do have a great tropical fish, shark exhibit and a touch pool.  It's a bit pricey at $19.95 given it's relatively small size.  However, if you have the San Francisco City Pass, it's included so be sure to pick one up.
author: Anthony G.

description: I got a ticket to this aquarium for free with my Big Bus tour. The aquarium is pretty small, but it hits all the basics -- jellies, a touch pool, and a two great tunnel aquariums. They have an excellent collection of sharks. There are a few cute little otters, too, but they were sleeping when I visited.
author: Kayleigh S.

description: Love petting the baby sting rays and seeing the sharks. Had tons of fun there today! Would definitely recommend it. Also enjoyed seeing the jelly fish. Not crowded and perfect for my 4 year old.
author: Kimberly R.

description: This place is awesome! There is a lot to offer: from animals, to shows, to food, etc. We were able to join the behind the scenes your and got to see the actions behind those exhibits. It was really neat to see the operations side of the aquarium. I was also very impressed by the aquarium's effort on studying and helping endangered sea animals. It was heart warming to learn that the staff at this aquarium cared so much for these sea buddies!
author: Tran N.

description: I was expecting to spend a couple of hours here at the aquarium but I felt like it was small and quick. Which could be a good thing for some people.
author: Shab A.

description: Our visit here started out really good until we were midway through the aquarium when the power went out. The animals we did get to see we really awesome. They were extremely accommodating to give a full refund if you were in during the power outage. Good sights with a nice staff.
author: Karlee I.

description:
This is a really cute aquarium for kids and families. It is a little small but it's nice.
I like the jellyfish,  otters and giant walk through tunnel with sharks.
author: Funtime P.

description:
The Aquarium of the Bay is a small aquarium with mainly fish tanks, one octopus, a few land critters and mammals, and the main event being either river otters or the small sharks.  I am in love with animals and everything to do with the ocean, and we were done in 40 minutes.  Other aquariums have me there for hours or even a full day.

It's two stories but that is misleading as this is pretty small for an aquarium.  The tunnel with glass overhead and on the sides with fish everywhere was really cool.

It was also great to see the baby mana rays.  They swam right over to us.  One even came halfway out of the water to see me!  The employee told us that they like to be caressed on the top end of their fins. We tried that out, and that was a really cool experience.

There are employees in every corner who just jump into conversations and when they overhear you discussing an animal or display with a question, they pipe in with the answer like a ninja. It was a bit annoying because my friend and I were discussing amongst ourselves, and if we really wanted to know something we would have either looked it up on my phone or asked someone.  However, I'm sure other customers really appreciate that kind of thing. 

The river otters weren't around when we were there.  There was a big note at the display that it was closed.  It would've been better to have put a notice out at the front of the aquarium stating this.  

At the end of the displays, you have made a circle and end up in the souvenir shop just before going outside.  They try to get you to buy pictures that they imposed you to take.  I had told the photographer I had no interest in paying for some goofy picture from them, but he kept talking over me and wouldn't listen so I gave up to get away from him.  In the souvenir shop, when the cashier yelled over to us to check out our pictures - we were 20 ft. away - I walked over to her and said no thanks.  Her co-worker laughed, and the cashier then started complaining about how no one wants their pictures and she's tired of printing them out.  Well, maybe you should just ask people if they want them then.
author: Sheri C.

description:
We got two tickets on TravelZoo for the aquarium as we just wanted to get away and spend a day being tourists in SF.

They have a lot of different fish, river otters, & baby manta rays and sharks that you can touch in one of the touching pools. There are quite a few educational stations which were interesting to read. I really liked the glass tunnels where you can look at all the fish. We were lucky and got to see scuba divers working as well! 

I think one of the other Yelpers summed it up best, It's not a Monterey Bay Aquarium, so don't expect that! It's a cute little aquarium that provides an educational and fun experience for tourists!
author: Kory R.

description:
I really didn't expect to like Aquarium of the Bay as much as I did: They have very good exhibits of all sorts of creatures who live in and around the Bay.

Tell me I'm crazy but I think their octopus has a huge crush on me. I watched him cascade down from his perch and then cozy up next to me, tentacles waving, settling on the glass as if to hug me. He followed me around the glass, blinking at me lovingly.

I was positively transfixed for 10 minutes. I plan to go back and say "hello" to my new friend.

While Aquarium of the Bay isn't Monterey Bay Aquarium  or the Steinhart Aquarium at Cal Academy, they do a very good job and they're far more accessible (and less expensive) for a morning or afternoon of family fun.

You should go here with your children.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
They try really hard,  but it is not the Monterey Bay Aquarium. This is a small aquarium near Pier 39, a major tourist destination. Thankfully there is a discount for locals. It is 2 floors with most tanks showcasing local fish and species in the area. The bottom floor, which can only be accessed by elevator has 2 large tank tunnels that you walk under, but it is not the actual Bay. It would have been helpful to have the same fish information on both sides too. I wish the information about the awful practice of shark fining, which is now illegal in California was bigger to catch more attention. It looks like there was some sort of conveyor belt to guide people along under the tanks, but it was not operational.

I didn't care for the fake kelp throughout the tanks and the some of the display kiosks need more love. At least they are trying to promote conservation and work to save the octopuses from fishermen killing them. We were done in an hour and read most of the posters, watched a ray & skate feeding, and listened to the docent talk about the octopus.

Will I be back? Probably not, but it's a great place to go for families whose kids have short attention spans.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I like that this aquarium is non-profit. You can tell they genuinely care about the well-being of the creatures they keep here.

The aquarium itself is small. There are 2 levels with exhibits, however, they go in a circle...Eventually leading you back to the elevator. I did enjoy the tunnel that is surrounded by water filled with sharks and fish. That was pretty cool to see. I also loved that they have an octopus! That cute little guy was putting on a show in his tank! :-D

Overall, this is a decent place to visit for $30. They also have touch pools where you can touch stingrays, starfish, etc. Not a bad place to spend an hour or so!
author: Kristy R.

description: The day we visited this place, it was a spontaneous enchanted dance in the moonlit rain after a long day at work. We took immersed ourselves in the beauty that is nature in this wondrous musuem of life in between our flicker amid the stars. This museum, along with my rather smexy company, made my week! I acquired my membership several days later, and the staff were efficient enough to accomplish this within the timeframe that is my lunch break. I certainly shall be returning to celebrate my recent victory in attaining a lead banker position with Wells Fargo in the coming days.
author: Richard R.

description:
This review is mainly for parents of toddlers.... 

Slightly disappointing because of how small it is. My 2 year old and I breezed through it in roughly 20 minutes.  I could not believe how quick we went through! I mean my son looked at the exhibits, but there's just not that many. Admission was around $20 and he was free, luckily.  The jellyfish are beautiful and the underwater tunnel is very cool, but tight when it's crowded, with a stroller, and worried your kid might book it ahead of you. You can touch some sting rays, starfish, and sea cucumbers. The sting Ray pool is a little deep for toddler arms, just FYI.

Even though we breezed through so quickly, your ticket is good for all day - so if you're staying in the area and need something to potentially tire the kids out later, go back.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Don't spend the money you are going to be mad 
Lol 
Nah really Im from Nyc I expected a big aquarium well let me tell you it's was tiny and you can see the all thing in 10 min 
The only great part is that's it's in a great area and you can get some great food after wards
author: Myrisse D.

description:
It's a small aquarium but still large enough to engage the interests of both my 3 and 8 year old.  They have some very nice exhibits like the tunnel you can walk through. I think the prices were pretty fair for such a touristy area. Particularly with the local discount.  

Good place to take the kids.
author: Nora S.

description: Would have loved to give more stores for this place. But it was not great for strollers. One of the elevators was broken and there was no one ensuring that people were using order when entering the elevators. Many people walked right up and skipped the line. With two screaming toddlers, that's unacceptable. We had places to go and fish to see. It was nice and clean and cool but there were many of us there who were uncomfortable trying to get through with the stroller. It's not a great place for big groups.
author: Reala T.

description: Expensive and small but overall it's worth it. There is a lot to see and a few touch pools even. My daughter loved it. Walking through the dark tunnels you really feel like you're swimming with the fish at the bottom of the ocean. Very cool spot to check out on pier 39 especially if the weather is crummy it's a cool indoor spot.
author: Darin T.

description:
We were walking around the pier and decided to give the aquarium a try. Price is $18 per person but they gave us $2 off so total was $34 for two people - sort of steep for what the aquarium had to offer.

There are two floors. You have to take the elevator to the bottom floor and it gets really crowded. We had to wait a few times before we got to go on the elevator. When you first get off, you'll see tanks of jelly fishes and sardines. I always like the way jelly fishes and sardines look in "schools". There are several types of jelly fishes - some prettier than others ... lol 

Also on the bottom floor are tunnels of fishes - reminds me of six flags tunnel of sharks but bigger with a lot more different types of fishes and star fishes. Keep going and you'll see bat rays or manta rays. Also pretty cool.

Then you take the elevator back up there are touching ponds where you can touch the rays, star fishes and baby sharks. They also have side exhibits like the newly added possums, turtles and frogs. 

We took our time - I mean I was staring at the "dead" possum for a long while - and still only killed 30 minutes. I think it's a cool aquarium if you do the city pass (which is pretty much free to get into here) or get groupon deals. Personally, I wouldn't "wing it" like we did and pay $34 bucks. Wasn't worth it - the aquarium is TINY.

By the way - they do not validate parking.
author: Carolyn N.

description:
Aquarium of the Bay is small but a great place to visit. Our admission was included as part of the "City Pass". So to us it was like a free ticket.  I didn't know what to expect but I was pleasantly surprised. I've been to aquariums all over the world. Aquarium of the Bay delivers some quality exhibits, some of which were the best I've seen. The pictures really tell the story.

For example:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco#7RXDX5i-V5IjBLLmSBNVlw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco#5cZiIUA9ZSld8AHtz3C2EA
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco#cacJxYeg7IfRFrTiojoU7A
The jelly fish and some of the other creatures were amazing. Just like being a deep sea diver. Some of the best exhibits that I've ever seen because they were realistic with lighting that is perfect.

I enjoyed this exhibit better than the Academy Of Science fish tanks. The academy is very good and larger so don't miss it. But, this Aquarium has it's place. I probably wouldn't have been so impressed if I had paid full price. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco?selected=fhnsqY8w33i1oEcYEeQ6Fg#jZkr351Q228vszud9SnWHA
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco#fSR2eOJhIpi6ISNgDEA75w
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco#gwrw_cA_nlI1D10H3uRghw

Summary:  Would I go back?  Yes! Can I recommend it to others? Yes!  Consider getting the City Pass to save money on admissions.   Four Stars from me.  I liked it.
author: Vince B.

description:
This isn't as huge as Monterey or some of the other well known Aquarium's, its mostly for the tourists that come to Pier 39. You won't really find any locals going, hey let's go to the Aquarium of the Bay today for a great time. With that being said, if you're in the area, and want a place to pass time, this will do just fine.

It's pretty small overall. They do have a excellent display of JellyFish that are in black light. The rest of the fish are in pretty small tanks. They have two tunnels that you can walk through. The first with large fishes, starfish, and rock fish. The second is the more entertaining one with sting rays and sharks. I can spend a good 30 minutes just ogling these marvelous creatures. They also highlight some issues like pollution and trash in the bay. 

Following the tunnels there are touching pools. You can touch baby sting rays, leopard sharks, starfish and various sea life.  They also display a random assortment of animals- a possum, tortoise, chinchillas, gecko's and a snake. I thought it was really random but hey, animals are cute.

Lastly you exit by going past the otters. When they're sleeping its not much fun, but if you happen to catch them awake they are quite the sight to see. They are fast and curious and they have a decent sized exhibit to run around in.

I did like that the staff is super friendly and very attentive. Anytime my party and I blurted a question to each other.... "Hmm, that looks like a old shark", a employee would be there to give us the right answer. It was so fast that it felt like a ninja. It was the same employee too, i have no idea how she teleported to everywhere we were, but it was nice getting all that knowledge. 

Overall, its small, but it's still nice.
author: Bevi K.

description: This aquarium may be small, but it is filled with tons of sea creatures and rich with information.  I was surprised with how many animals they had in the tunnels.  I would recommend going in the morning near when they open as the tunnels can get a bit crowded.  There are schools of fishes, sharks, starfishes and all kinds of animals in the tunnels.  The jellyfish exhibit with the colored lights is awesome for pics.  However, no flash allowed.  My favorite exhibit is definitely the recently added sea otter exhibit.  They love to show off and are super playful.  Upstairs, they have the touch pool.  Pretty fun and slimy.  The picture magnets are a bit overpriced in my opinion.  However, there is a deal on Groupon for $25 with admission to Aquarium of the Bay with a free picture.  This was how my girlfriend and I found out about this place.  Overall, we spent a good hour and half here.  Pretty fun stop if you are looking for things to do in San Francisco.
author: Dang L.

description: I loved this spot. We were just adventuring around Fisherman's Wharf and decided to pop in on a whim. It's a small aquarium, no doubt, but the contents did not disappoint! There were two tunnels to walk through, a touch tank (so damn cool -- you can touch sting rays, little sharks, and starfish), and we got to see some sea otters doin' their thang at the end. Really cute, fun spot!
author: Justine J.

description: $45 for to hear children scream in the shark tunnel and finish the tour in 15 minutes. Pretty lackluster for a seaside aquarium. The exhibits were kinda small and very few too. Tulsa, Oklahoma aquarium is definitely better.
author: Dave H.

description:
I will begin by saying that I am a huge fan of aquariums and try to visit one in every city that I can. This pales in comparison to larger aquariums. It is quite small and actually has very little to look at. They could completely rebrand it as the under the bay experience as that (walking through the tunnel in a 70,000 gallon SF Bay simulation) is pretty much all there is to do there.

The Aquarium of the Bay focuses on the biodiversity of the San Francisco Bay and has a strong conservation message which I love.

Here are some of the reasons why I gave it a 3-star review:
*Admission is high for what it is. This aquarium is about a 1 hour experience. The adult admission fee is over $20. I know that the money goes to do great work, but seems a little high for the amount of attraction available.

*Educational Signage. This was a huge miss for me. I found myself wanting to know more about the species on display. in the underwater tubes, there is very little information about the species of fish and there aren't enough guides around to get information from. This was particularly frustrating in the jellyfish exhibit where I was mesmerized but wish I knew more about the species on display.

You will be delighted at the touch pond. Here you can touch species of ray, skate and shark. Interestingly enough, you can only touch the species with one finger and can not feed the ray. (At other aquariums you are allowed to feed the rays)

There is a second touch pond where you can touch sea cucumbers, anemones and starfish. Truly amazing.

Do not miss the playful and adorable river otters!
author: Daniel M.

description: Three words: sharks, sharks, sharks! They are swimming around you while you walking  inside the tunnel. Make a few loops around, so your eyes can catch different fishes and even brave divers. Aquarium also has octopus, jelly fish, tortoises, otters and a touch pool. It's may seem rather compact but it reaches  above and beyond into fascinating  sea world.
author: Ally M.

description:
I came here for the first time 16 years ago with my family. I hadn't returned to SF since then, but I knew that whenever I did, I'd have to stop once again by this aquarium.

Their impressive displays, the friendly staff and the educational line that reaches out to attendees are some of the most valuable parts of the experience when you come to the Aquarium at the Bay. 

I truly recommend this to everyone and anyone. Kids will walk away with a greater insight and understanding of the ocean, the fragile ecosystems that inhabit them, and the power of that the human hand has to help or destroy them. Adults can make a nice romantic adventure of it combined with a meal at the pier, or just adventure through for the experience :)
author: R R.

description: Although the pricing was outrageous I really enjoyed myself. The staff was awesome and very personable. They treated everyone the same and greeted us all with a smile. They have touch pools in here and they are a man by very knowledgeable employees. I got to see the biggest bass that I have ever seen in my life. I didn't really get to see anything that sets this place apart from other aquariums that I've been to, But it was still nice. I would definitely recommend going if you have never been to an aquarium or you just have random money to blow. Other than that there's nothing that makes this place stand out.
author: Cynetta M.

description:
this place seems to become more and more trite with every additional visit.  That being said, ive only been here probably 3 times max. ..... This past weekend included. 

came here with the baby for some family fun, thinking the baby would enjoy looking at all the different fish swimming about.  However, the displays were nothing spectacular. even with a plethora of marine life, i felt pretty lifeless staring into each display. There wasnt a wow factor to any of the things that were shown. As a matter of fact, i felt somewhat suffocated by the number of people packed within the limited space provided. People were bumping into each other and tripping over strollers. What a mess. .... At the very end of the trip, my boyfriend turned to me and said, "thats it?" 

not worthy of the $20 fee per person. we shouldve taken the drive to monterey bay aquarium.  That place definitely rocks compared to this one.
author: Abby Q.

description: I loved this. I had been here once before years ago during the height of tourist season on a weekend and it was so crowded that we weren't really allowed to stop and enjoy ourselves and spent most of the time looking at the back of other people's heads. Well this time around I went mid week and it was way less crowded we were allowed to spend all the time we wanted watching, looking at and even touching some of these amazing animals . It was so much fun, we even got to watch a training session with the river otters. What a delightful time we had, I'm hoping to back again soon.
author: Willow R.

description: I'll admit, im a nerd for aquariums. Im not even a huge sealife buff. But there is something so tranquil about watching the fish swim around above you. I could sit in the jelly fish exhibit all day. Completely worth an hour of your day. Take your time, relax and let the Clown fish tell you some jokes.
author: Mark M.

description: Took the kids here. I'd say it's smaller than most Aquariums.  Price is about right considering rent.  Average aquarium. Kids watched River Otters for an hour !
author: Mike H.

description:
This is a really sad and disappointing aquarium. Their highlight tunnel feature had only a few types of fish and it was very murky and stagnant looking water.  I felt very sorry for the river otters too. 

The academy of science has an infinitely better aquarium as well as many other amazing exhibits. Go there instead.
author: Kirsty E.

description: The place was not big, but it was OK. The sea otters impressed me a lot, very funny and interesting. This weekend I will brought my nephew here and hope he can enjoy.
author: Karen S.

description: It's not bad, but it's kind of expensive and not really spectacular, compared to, say, the aquariums at Monterey or Long Beach.  It's not that big.
author: Ian F.

description:
This is an ok aquarium.  I got passes from Groupon so we saved about $10 bucks, regular price is $19.95.  According to the website, if you buy online, you can save $2.  Children under 3 are free.  The aquarium is quite small and so we finished in about 45 minutes.  The underwater tunnels featuring sharks, sturgeons, as well as other marine life was amazing.  During the time we were there, we also got to see a scuba diver.  My LO loved the hands on exhibit of the sting rays and the tide pools.  I think she actually wanted to get into the water though.  The last exhibit on the way out are the 3 river otters.  The tour guide was quite informative about the characteristics of the river otters.

We got there at about 11 on a Wednesday and the crowd wasn't bad at all.  I'm just not sure that I would pay $20 per person for this aquarium.  I'd rather make a trek down to Monterey Bay Aquarium.
author: Jen S.

description:
Where to start? The entire experience at Aquarium of the Bay was hands-down the highlight of my San Fran trip. My husband and I arrived around 10am on a Friday. We started by looking at tanks filled with sea creatures ranging from eels, fishies, a baby shark, sand dabs, and a "Finding Nemo" tank that had all the fishes from the movie. There were also a lot of factoids about the Bay Area and a display of what our seas look like with trash. This particular exhibit had some hermit crabs, wandering amongst the glass bottles and whatnot. 

Once we finished peering into every tank like excited schoolchildren, we moved on to the elevator, where it whisked us away to the "tunnel". The entrance to the tunnel has tanks filled with brightly colored jellyfish and then suddenly, you are underneath a large see-thru tunnel. During the elevator ride, the guide told us that the tunnel is filled with sea creatures that are native to the Bay Area. Here we saw sharks, rays, starfish, and enormous bass fish. It was amazing! I felt like I could have burst out some Little Mermaid songs about being under the sea. While staring fascinated at the sea creatures, a scuba diver swam by and we were able to see some of the fishes eat. Once feeding time was over, we moved into an area with a large octopus and then rode the elevator to our next stop. 

The next exhibit allowed us to pet baby rays. They were so tiny and curious, swimming around randomly and bobbing up inquisitively. It was a lot of fun! We also saw some snakes, frogs, and turtles. Near the back of this exhibit was a tide pool area where I was able to pet starfish, sea cucumbers, sea anemones, and the like. When we were done with that, we walked around the corner to the otter exhibit. The first thing we saw was an adorable otter swimming in lazy circles, using his hands and feet to push off the glass to give him momentum. Around the corner of the exhibit, another otter slept on some rocks. 

After the otters, we were back at the entrance of the Aquarium with a gift shop. The gift shop had a lot of cute souvenirs ranging from clothing, purses, jewelry, stuffed animals, etc. The stuffed animals were really cute and I wish I brought one home as a souvenir.

Overall, this was one of the best attractions at Pier 39 and I would do it again in a heartbeat. If you are in the area, definitely check it out. It is great for all ages, so the entire family can enjoy!
author: Nicole B.

description:
I am not big into zoos or aquariums, I always feel bad for the creatures so I generally skip them unless I am with someone else that really wants to go.

We had out of town visitors over the Christmas holiday and they generously took us to this attraction.  

The "underwater" aquarium was great, it was fun to walk through the "tube" of Stingrays and other marine life.  I think this would be a great place to take children 5 years and up too.  

You can also pet the Stingrays as you exit the Aquarium.   

I do have to say Aquarium of the Bay is very conveniently located near major SF tourist destinations such as Fisherman's Wharf, DUCK Tours, Pier 39 and Boudin. 

Overall, I would say this is worth checking out if this is your sort of thing.
author: Kara M.

description:
As others are stating it is a bit overpriced at 17 bucks a pop, but this is what they charge at Mandalay Bays Aquarium on the strip and it isnt even half the size of this place!

There are plenty of cool creatures to look at and getting to touch/pet the stingray, starfish, and tigershark was pretty cool as well...I just wish the Octopus would have been up and about but oh well.

All in all, it was pretty cool for what it was...
author: Mike F.

description:
My daughter has been begging to come here for at least a year. I didn't take advantage when this venue was part of our local library's Discover and Go program(Bay Area parents, do NOT sleep on those deals) so I was willing, as penance for my foolishness, to fork over the admission fee. Tickets are cheaper by a $1 or so if you purchase online and yes locals get a discount(online as well.) Don't bother with driving and parking if you're close to BART; take the F on Market after getting off on Embarcadero(get a Clipper card for most convenience.) 
Once we got to Pier 39 and had lunch, we were ready for a stroll through the Aquarium. You can see from outside the building that it is small so I'm not clear on why my fellow Yelpers complain on what it is obvious.  The aquarium is compact and clean. They have included lots of info about local wildlife. Highlights were the tunnels(sharks!) and the touch pool where a friendly ray splashed my daughter from head to toe. 
Going on a weekday was good as we didn't have to deal with crowds. The gift stores are strategically placed at the beginning and end of the museum tour so be prepared to avoid paying $20 for a tiny stuffed seal or $26 for your green-screen family photo. 
Outside, Riveropolis is a free play area where the kids can build rafts with a supply of various corks, wooden blocks, rubber hands, and toy sea animals
author: Julie C.

description:
I love aquariums so this was the coolest place to go to when my friend and I ventured into SF. Of course, I usually LOVE all aquariums because I'm kind of obsessed with marine life, but at this one? You get an awesome paper hat to wear during your visit, so lots of fun for the kiddies.

They don't have a very big assortment of animals, but it is a relatively small aquarium, so you can't expect their to be too much. :-) Plus, at the price you pay, I would definitely say it's worth taking a look at. They have jellyfish, too!

The gift shop is standard of all aquatic attraction gift shops, the end of the tour ends right there, in the store. It has some pretty cool stuff, I did end up getting a shark key chain for my keys, which makes for an interesting conversation starter.
author: Molly M.

description:
I came here on a Friday afternoon and it was not crowded at all. In fact there were hardly any people there which was nice. I'm sure Saturdays and Sundays it becomes ridiculously packed.

The place itself is on the small to medium size with different floors and a walk through tunnel where you get to see various species of sealife. There's even an octopus that hides in the corner and sleeps all day pretty much.

There's a shallow pool where kids can touch the creatures with appropriate handwashing afterwards of course. And there are sea otters like most aquariums.

The place itself again is not big and you can finish it in about 30-45 minutes including some detailed reading so it's not a place where you get exhausted afterwards (especially if you have young children).

Locals get 2 dollars off and kids under 3 are free. If you want a larger aquarium in SF, California Academy of Sciences has it, but it's also more crowded even on weekdays.
author: Julia P.

description:
I was not impressed. I stopped by here to please a friend of mine from Japan stopped by the city for a day. 
I'm Japanese.  Aquariums in Japan are amazing.  Compared to them, this venue is too small and not impressive.  This aquarium clamis that otters are one of main things, but only two otters, they are cute though. 
I won't come back.
author: Kaori M.

description:
My family and I came here this past Friday. I bought an annual membership back in August with a groupon deal but hadn't actually visited the aquarium until months later. I must say that I have been very pleased with the membership! Not only do you get discount or free entry for additional visitors to the aquarium, you get 25% off in the gift shop, invitations to special member events, AND possibly the best of all, you get discounted entry to various bay area attractions such as the Oakland & SF Zoos, and various museums etc...That alone is enough incentive to have me consider renewing the membership. 

So on our first visit this past week, I was able to get my BF in at no charge with my membership, and our child was free as he is under 4 years old. Parking is an astounding $10 an hour, so if you have a membership, be sure to use member parking (which I was unaware of when we visited.) The aquarium itself is fairly small, as others have said, but there are a few things that I really liked: 
* The animals at the aquarium are native to the area
* The size of the place is perfect for smaller children with shorter attention spans
* The aquarium is a non profit organization which I like supporting
* The member perks are pretty awesome
Although the aquarium is small, you can easily make a day out of visiting by also visiting other locations on Pier 39 before or after your aquarium experience. 

Overall, we had a great day and although the aquarium isn't somewhere that I will likely visit very often, I'm glad it's here and I will consider renewing my membership for the following year due to the benefits that are available at other bay area attractions and the fact that the membership cost is tax deductible and going towards a good cause.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Worst aquarium I've ever been to .  Don't waste your time or your money . Even though they are on a pier on the s.f. Bay they have almost no fish there . ...Bob P.
author: Bob P.

description: Staff was very friendly, however the tunnels were overcrowded with no where to exit once in them.  Having no access to stairs and only two elevators taking EVERYONE up and down 3 stories is a terrible idea and poorly designed.
author: Stephanie S.

description: We went on a weekday afternoon when it wasn't as busy which was nice,  but it was a lot smaller than we expected. Both San Diego and Long Beach have better aquariums than this one. We got to at least view the stingray feeding time,  but after we finished with what little aquarium there was we went to the theater area to see the sharks of Alcatraz movie and I guess they are doing renovations and was closed. I think they should have told us when buying tickets or at least have discounted ticket prices since you're missing a main attraction there. Would probably not go back,  one time there was enough.
author: Tiffany S.

description: I just toured the Aquarium today with my father and my 7 yr old son. We all really enjoyed it. The place has the longest underwater tunnels. There are many sharks, rays, and giant fish. We took the behind the scenes tour and got to walk on top of the big tanks/tunnels. I really loved this place as much as my son.
author: Hailey A.

description:
Yes, there are larger aquariums around, and admission is on the pricey side (but the life choices that led you to Fisherman's Wharf probably didn't involve an obsession with value for money anyway). But if you can get a discounted ticket, this is actually pretty remarkable.

The centerpiece is the tunnel through a three-quarters-of-a-million-gallons-of-water aquarium, where you'll see some spectacular rays, sharks and other fish. It's jaw-dropping.

But there's quite a bit more to see, too: an array of tanks large and small, including a big cylindrical "treadmill" packed with anchovies. The touch ponds are great, and go beyond the usual sea stars and anemones to sea cucumbers and--this should register high on your kids' coolness meters--sharks and rays. Also, river otters, the planet's most adorable critters.

The place could stand a little more in the way of animation and interpretation. But the staff are engaging and knowledgeable, and on the day we were there, delivered a surprisingly sophisticated lesson on ocean acidification.

There probably isn't a return visit in our future--it's small enough that I felt we visited the place thoroughly--but I'm glad we went.
author: Rob C.

description: We visited the Aquarium Friday around lunch time. It is on the small side and a bit pricey. If it were not for the BOGO, the rating would have been lower. A couple of areas of interest are the two walk through tunnels and the area where you can touch stingrays, sharks, sea cucumbers, and starfish. The nicest thing about the trip is that it was not busy.
author: Robert H.

description: I bought a San Francisco City Pass & the Aquarium of the Bay was part of the package.  I suppose I can feel good about donating to marine conservation.  The two stars are only for the size (very small) and age (old) of the aquarium, the staff is great and very knowledgable.  They did have cool jelly fish though.
author: Joyce V.

description:
On our first visit to San Francisco, we went to Pier 39.  It's a touristy destination, but easy enough and small enough for my Grandmother to navigate easily.  This aquarium is one of the main attractions on the Pier.  We decided to check it out.  It was about $20 to get in, but there were coupons on the parking garage stub. I wish I had looked before we paid...lol.

The aquarium is very small and at times very crowded.  The tanks were small.  The walk through tunnels were interesting though.  They had an exhibit that strictly featured local animals.  There is a hands-on pool for kids to touch baby rays.  You can also watch them feed a little shark in the kiddie pool as well.  

I didn't see any of the guides talking about any of the animals except for the man at the octopus display.  It took less than an hour to walk thru.  I think it was pricey for what it was and it had very little educational value.  Kids might like it.
author: Kim L.

description:
It's hard for me to be impressed, because I'm from Baltimore. We have the National Aquarium here. But hey, this was a nice aquarium.

It focuses quite a lot on conservation efforts, which are pretty important, and I like that a lot. The exhibits are all pretty well done, and we all found the underwater section to be fascinating (two conveyor belts going through two tanks - you get surrounded by fish of all types, including sharks!). 

The otters were adorable.

The touch area was neat - kids of all ages seemed to love touching the rays - which waved.
author: Jude T.

description:
It's small. Not the best aquarium I've been to - definitely not worth the money.  I spoke to a resident of San Fran, this man asked where we were planning to check out during our stay.  He told us to check out the other aquarium (unfortunately, I don't remember what it's called) but it was close by, he said Aquarium of the Bay is very touristy and not as great as the other.  I should have listened, but I already had bought the ticket before speaking with him.  Take his advice, and mine.

The only great thing to remember about this Aquarium is that there's a fish tank to walk through where they swim above your head. OOOOOO WOWWWWWW!  Not.
author: Nina C.

description:
Seriously?!  YES, seriously JUST ONE STAR!  If I could give them a negative I would.  

This place is whack.  Small and obviously very stressful for the animals!  They have a blind animal towards the very exit in this tiny little cage who runs around and around probably for hours and most definitely, his entire life.  When I asked they said, "oh, he's blind."  Ok!  And so that's a reason to deprive that animal of a large enough cage to move or keep him alone?  Ugh, I was very disturbed that I even brought my son here.  

Sad. 

I do not recommend this aquarium; it's a money maker only.  If you're looking for real education and a place where the animals are treated with love, go to California Academy of Science or Monterery Bay Aquarium.  

Never will we go back.  A place that doesn't know how to correctly treat their animals and give them the space they need to roam is a place
author: Kat M.

description: I saw a CHINCHILLA! Super cute, my daughter asked me if we could take it home lol. Got to touch the sting rays and starfish. I never knew whale sharks existed. I know I'm late lol.  I had so much fun. The river otters were quite entertaining too. Not too crowded for a sunday.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I had a lot of fun here! Usually I'm not one really one for walking around a giant fish tank. And the fact that I'm not passionate or know anything about marine life probably adds to that fact as well; however, I was pleasantly surprised. 

You start off in an exhibit consisting of a bunch of silver fish (cue the "not knowing anything about different species of fish" lingo) and a small tank with the "Finding Nemo" friends. Those sneaky buggers put a lot of the same animals in it, so be sure to check it out and name the characters. 

The next stop on the tour is the jellyfish exhibit, you are lead down an elevator and get taken into "the tunnels". Don't worry, you won't get lost, there are volunteers and employees around every bend. They'll show you exactly where you need to be. After the jellies, you make your way down a long tube full of huge fish, octopuses, and sharks. Take pictures, touch the displays, and have fun! 

Once you are through with the tunnels, you'll catch the elevator back upstairs and end up at the touch pools. TOUCH THE STINGRAY AND TOUCH THE SHARK. 

Keep heading around and visit the otters, they're toats adorbs. And then viola! You're already at the gift shop, I'd recommend not touching anything in there--unless you would like to purchase a glass blown octopus for $90. 

TIPS & TRICKS: 
* Ask when the scuba divers are feeding the sharks because that is a FUN thing to watch! If you don't get a chance to check it out while the people are in the tanks with the fish, I included a video of one waving to us. It's practically like you were here. 
* In the touch pool room, go to the middle display. An employee usually has an animal out that you can touch and learn all about.
author: Haley N.

description:
This place is like a mini Monterey Bay Aquarium which is perfect for taking young kids. I tried taking my 2(almost3)-year old son to MBA about a month back and I don't know if the size of the place was too much for him, or what, but it failed to hold his attention and we were out of there in less than 1.5-hours; total waste of money. Fast forward a few weeks and I get an email for an Amazon Local deal for 1/2-off adult ticket at the Aquarium of the Bay and I thought what the heck. I've always wanted to check this place out and for 50%-off, why not? I'm certainly glad I did. My son was way more into it and we had a much better time. My theory is they push you through a self-guided tour because the place is so tiny -in comparison to the MBA- that there's no room for milling about smartly; there's a set course and you have no choice but to go where they want you. It's called structure which is what small children require. But, you didn't come here for a parenting lesson; so here are the highlights of the AoB:

1) Under the Bay - There's around 300' of moveable sidewalk that guides you through these glass tubes as all manners of fish and marine life swim around you. This was so much fun we went through it twice! I tell you it's pretty fun watching an 8-foot Seven Gill Shark & huge Manta Rays swimming right at your head! 

2) Tide Pool - This is always a perennial kid favorite. What Toddler doesn't love touching starfish, sea cucumbers, anemones and splashing around the water?    

3) Otterly Amazing - The new Sea Otter exhibit was really well built and gave you a ton of viewing angles to check out these cute, furry creatures romp around. They even had a tree in there that those rascals loved to climb! Who knew Otters could climb a tree?

All-in-all this was a pretty fun 2-hours and there was hardly any grumbling from the Little Tyrant. I'm not sure if I would've enjoyed it as much if I had paid the full price -yes, I'm that cheap!- but for the price I paid it was worth every penny.
author: John D.

description:
I loved this place. My girlfriend and I went here on a day date and we loved it. it has a good collections of animals and lot of info. They also had a interactive session with some of the animals. 

Will definitely recommend if you are into aquarium's.
author: Akhil P.

description:
The aquarium is kind of small, but it seemed ok. I enjoyed walking through the tubes, and my little sister and Goddaughter enjoyed petting the rays and the sea anemone. 

However, the staff seems a little disorganized. The parts where kids can touch the animals seems like a general all-around clusterf$@k. I think the staff is probably trying to balance between ensuring a good time of the patrons mixed with the safety of the animals, but damn, I was bumped into by kids and adults alike.

This is partially a commentary on our society......please tell your kids to be polite and not to "attack" areas where animals are around. So, as parents all think their children are angels, perhaps the staff could enforce some type of "taking turn" system when it comes to the animal exhibits?
author: Dan W.

description:
Been here a couple of times but never got to do my review. 

It's a nice little place where you get to see  bunch of different sea creatures. (Mainly fish) 
When you first walk in, you get to see the giant tank of anchovies which I find kinda trippy. Haha.  But then you also get to see a bunch of jelly fish up close and I always find that fascinating. 

My absolute favorite part of this place is the fact that you actually get to pet some of the creatures. (Mainly starfish, sharks, and stingrays) 

Reason for the 1 star deduct is because it's a short tour and that after the first time you've been here, it gets boring quickly.
author: Melanie L.

description: Definitely not an all day thing, but can be a nice supplement to a day in the city.  The escalator through the "underwater" aquarium is quite enjoyable and you will see a lot of marine life up close.  But don't think this place is comparable to a large aquarium.  In summary, check it out with tempered expectations and enjoy it for what it is.  You can do the whole thing in an hour.
author: Matt R.

description:
I've been here many times and while it's a fun way to kill a few hours it barely compares to the really nice aquarium we have in Seattle or the others I've visited in most major cities (Denver, Baltimore).

Prices are high and the newness factor is low. It also gets really crowded b/c it's in tourist central.

You can be in and out of here in about an hour if your kid isn't interested in stopping and reading more about the animals/fish/jellies that they see. Wish/Hope they expand some more and have more things to do and see or I can't really imagine going back again.
author: Joshua B.

description: Great for little ones, they enjoyed it a lot and the facility wasnt too overwhelming. Spent a lot of time in undersea tunnel and stingray petting area. Probably not the best for older kids and it might appear small. Friendly staff too. Would advise buying tix with 50pct discount if u have other zoo memberships, otherwise price is a bit steep
author: Philip L.

description: Very exciting and well educated employees. The best part was going downstairs to the under the see. My son enjoyed himself. Completely excited!
author: Joy S.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan.

But I'm a fan of most aquariums and I've seen quite a few across the world. Even a poor aquarium is still fun for me and the family. This would be A-OK except for the tunnel. I love when aquariums immerse you 'inside' the tanks. This is a short one, but it's still a tunnel. The aquarium itself is not that big, but it's big enough.
author: Derek F.

description:
Expensive for something we only spent 24 minutes in.  Tiny and not much to see.  Did however see this BOSS B!T*H (in like her late 60s) demonstrating how to touch the sharks.  

When this tattooed Dub TEE a-hole completely and utterly dismissed her she did not step down... she stood her ground and did not stop telling him on her loudspeaker to do it correctly.  She is my hero.
author: Vanessa C.

description: Don't waste your money on here. It's so small and there isn't a whole lot to see. The river otters were adorable but you can barely see them. I also enjoyed the tide pool.  That was all really. Everything was very mediocre.
author: Heather S.

description:
This aquarium is probably one of the smallest ones i have ever been to. We finished the whole aquarium in about 45 minutes. The location is very convenient. Right on pier 39. 

I dont think its worth the money.
author: Aubrey H.

description: It was just okay. It was very small for the price. Also, ticketing isn't very efficient. We bought tickets online. When we arrived the sign said "ticket holders to the left, non-ticket holders to the right"  We went in the left line where the employee said that she doesn't have a scanner to scan the ticket in, and I would have to wait in the long line behind all the people who didn't buy advanced tickets. What's the benefit from buying them early then?  The first exhibit was neat with the jellyfish, and the tunnels had some neat aquatic life, but other than that it was kind-of a snoozer for my husband and I. Maybe kids will like it better.
author: Sharon C.

description: Nice and clean with good flow for crowds. Admission is a bit steep for the experience but I was willing to pay it. The size of the facility is smaller than you'd expect, but if you have small children, it's perfect because their attention span doesn't last long anyway. Close enough to all the shops/restaurants at the pier. Park across the street in the garage and check your parking receipt for aquarium discounts. All in all, a fun experience for all.
author: Marina T.

description: So beautiful, they have a hands on area where you can touch the animals, and they have a lovely gift shop on the third floor. This is one of the stops me and my boyfriend visited for our four year anniversary
author: Diana V.

description:
Not worth the money. We paid and walked through the entire place in under an hour. 

The elevators are weird. You will know what I mean when you go or if you have been there.

It is not very stroller friendly either.

My daughter loved the jelly fish and sting rays. It is perfect for tourists at Pier 39, not very educational. Though my experience is with the Baltimore aquarium in MD. Maybe not a fair comparison.
author: Gem B.

description: Aquarium of the Bay is quite small, but that makes it perfect for a quick trip with small children. The enclosed spaces make it ideal for the kids to explore a little on their own. My kids love seeing the jellyfish and going through the underwater tunnels to see the fish and small sharks. The tanks look clean, and the staff has always been very nice. You can get through the whole thing in about 30 minutes, which is great because there's still time to walk down the Pier and see the Sea Lions or have lunch downstairs at Boudin. Tip: Park in the Pier 39 garage and check into Pier 39 on Yelp for a free coupon booklet at the California Visitor Center and two hour free parking validation!
author: Kristy C.

description:
I have been here many times, and the price keeps going up.  On the plus side, you can see a variety of aquatic animals you would find just outside the Golden Gate.  The highlight of the place is the walk-through tubes.  It's really cool to see a ray or a shark literally swim over your head.  You can literally see eye to eye with a shark.

Kids will love the touch tank, and there is one small tropical aquarium where you can see the more colorful animals of the sea.  You can just stand or sit in one spot and watch the fish swim by for hours.

You should do this, because otherwise it will be a short visit.  Every time I go, I hope they have expanded.  But so far, no.

It's too bad the moving walkway doesn't work anymore.  Then again, on busy days that would cause crowds.  If you don't have a discount, it's rather expensive, but I guess not that much so compared to the other attractions at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: This is one of the best aquariums I've been to. The underwater tunnels really sold me. It was the best part of my experience! This aquarium was complete with a jellyfish room, 2 underwater tunnels (one with fishes and one with all sharks and stingrays), otter attraction with other animals feature such a chinchillas, snakes, frogs, etc. There's even an attraction where you can pet baby stingrays and sharks! The only thing I would complain about are the employees. A lot of them looked like they hated their job lol
author: Melissa C.

description: They don't honor tickets purchased! "Manager". Was not helpful, just repeated herself, I'll be disputing extra charge we were FORCED to pay as 4 year old child had his heart set on the aquarium plus we drove 2 hours to get there. WONT BE RETURNING!
author: S R.

description: As someone currently studying marine biology, I am usually fairly skeptical of your run of the mill aquarium. But let me tell you, my aquarium experience was one for the books. While not as large or fancy as Monterey or Long Beach, this aquarium knows what it is and does not disappoint. It is truly an eye-opening, entertaining, and engaging invitation to the world of marine life. We arrived just in time to watch a feeding in one of the tunnels (which is always awesome) and were extremely pleased to see what I believe may be the most active giant pacific octopus currently in captivity. I also appreciated the focus on conservation and protection of marine life, especially sharks. While it would have been cool if the "under the pier" section was actually under the pier, the overall experience was extremely enjoyable, and I would recommend this to any of my friends in a heartbeat.
author: Chris H.

description: The tube is amazing!!!! A fairly small Aquarium, but worth the visit. I was a bit disappointed by the otter exhibit.
author: Greg F.

description:
My sister is a member of the SF Zoo so we got our tickets for half off which made the experience worth it. I probably wouldn't pay full price but with the discount it was fun.

The best part were the jellyfish,  the underwater walking tubes, and the otters. Too bad the otters were all sleeping (10:45am) so they weren't much to look at except for when the woke up to look around before going back to sleep.
author: Johnny C.

description:
More like 3.5 stars

The aquarium of the bay is small, but it is nice.

I have been here a few times now and I enjoy coming here when there isn't a lot of other people. Now let's be honest, that doesn't really happen there are always people here. 
The first time I went it was nice, not too crowded...they stuff you into a tiny little elevator to continue onto different parts of the aquarium...I am not a fan of that...so I asked a worker if there was any other way and she took me to the stairs outside and we went that way. (I have a perfectly rational fear or elevators) 

It is kind of dirty inside at times, the first time I recall seeing a dirty diaper someone had stuffed behind a bench but no staff had found it or cleaned up. Often there are little kids running around with no parents in sight - not that that is uncommon - but come on people there is a moving walkway for unattended children to hurt themselves on. 

They pretty much just have jellyfish, fish, sharks and some other sea creatures - nothing too big or fancy. There is a section that has some sea creatures the kiddies can touch and some mammals/reptiles as well.  It is nice to walk under the shark area and see everything swimming above you but again...only if you are not being rushed by screaming children and rude people pushing up against you because it is so small in there. 

The second time I went we opted to stay on the elevator....big mistake...I thought I was going to die. They literally cram as many people as possible into this tiny little death trap elevator and it does not feel safe or sanitary. Again a little dirty. 

For the price you pay everything is pretty much to be expected because of the location.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I came here using a free pass through Contra Costa Library's Discover & Go program. I checked out one pass and got two adults and two children in for free.  This is great if you are a local and want to do/see something new with your kids at Pier 39.

Considering it was free, this was a great stop on our Pier 39 outing.  The kids (2 and 5 years old) were entertained by the fish, jellyfish, and sharks.   There's nothing spectacular here - it's no Monterey Bay Aquarium - but for a small fee (or free), it's not bad.  However, the full price of $17.95 is too much for what it is.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Definitely better than three stars, this place may not impress people as being a super-duper mondo aquarium-plex, but it is a really nice, small aquarium packed with all kinds of animals, marine and otherwise.  There's so much there, that it doesn't really seem all that small. . .

Normally, I'd have lots of words to describe a place that I'm reviewing, but in this case, let me direct you to the dozens of pictures that people have been taking in here (I've got a few here too).  There's so many of them that quite a number are redundant and it really gives you a good idea of all of the animals you can see here in their settings.

In addition to the sea creatures, there are a few land critters as well from small tarantulas to a display case of chinchillas, complete with information on the number of times chinchillas poop per day.

My daughter likes the touch pools towards the end of the exhibit, especially the one with the rays.  I'd say of all of the attractions and shops on Pier 39, this is probably the one that is most worth the price of admission.  I actually  think I like it a little better than the new Steinhart Aquarium at GGP.  If you are going to spend a day at Pier 39, don't neglect to come here--spend a while wandering around and enjoy yourself..
author: Matthew D.

description: It's a small aquarium, it was like an hour and a half tour. But my almost 2 year old daughter loved it especially the tunnels. She kept screaming, laughing, and smiling. So, that let me know that she had s good time!
author: Princess S.

description:
I'm actually Glad we made our way to experience this once again. Of course this doesn't compare to the Monterey Bay aquarium but there are still lots to see and do. The front entrance still made some headlines with the littles ones and the best part for me was the meet and greet area with some of the animals. We got a chance to actually understand and learn about the animals a little more.
Another area that happened to be just as fun was the bay underground tunnel of fishes, star fishes, and many other sea creatures. There was a area in the back of this sea tunnel that have some insights to crabs and octopuses. 
Overall experience was A-Ok. Will i ever visit this place again? Sure why not, when my kids are a little older and if we were to ever be in the area.
author: Nai V.

description: Good for young kids. The 4 year old was entertained. Not sure it would be a must see activity if you are visiting the city. Pretty expensive too... Use your zoo membership to get half off. Check out the play area for kids when you exit the gift shop.
author: Deborah L.

description:
This is the smallest aquarium I've ever seen. There are 3 areas: upper floor with an area where they would take your group's picture on a green background right by the exit, lower floor with the glass tunnels, and a lab where you can touch the baby sting rays. It took us about 15 minutes to cover each area.They have some fishes, reptiles, and amphibians. There are 2 glass tunnels that allow you to see the fishes swimming. I liked to look at the huge sturgeons in the 2nd tunnel. There are also a few small leopard sharks and a medium sized shark. At the end of the tour, the staff would showcase your group picture with different Photoshopped backgrounds and try to sell them to you for a ridiculously high price.

We completed the whole aquarium tour in less than an hour. I think it was a rip-off when I had to pay $22/person for the tickets, though my friend somehow get a good discount on their tickets. After reading the yelp comments, I think the cashiers may have asked for my friend's ID and they saw their addresses in the Bay Area, that's why they get the discount. Dang it! They should have let me know that Bay Area residents get discounts. Had I get a better deal on the tickets, I would have enjoyed the aquarium more.
author: Elianna N.

description: This place is so much fun, and great for kids and adults, too. Walking into the tubes with fish over my head...amazing! Jellyfish, touch pools, snakes and more, just great!
author: William M.

description:
Normally wouldn't be worth the cost, but they have a locals discount and the pier 39 website had a buy 1 get 1 on tickets so I went with my bf. 
The Jellyfish, Sharks, Octopus and Otters were the best. You can touch the sting ray and shark and starfish. The cages are kinda on the small side for a lot of the fish and animals so it was a little sad.
author: Kajal G.

description:
Glad we had this as part of the City Pass. Would have been very disappointed if we hadn't. 
It's quite small, and not a lot of sea life to see.
The octopus stole the show... never seen one move around so much. 
We conquered this place in an hour. That's about all we could stretch it to.
author: X M.

description: We loved visiting this Aquarium. We were on a family trip to Alcatraz, promised our 4 year old that if he went with us to the Rock, After we'd take him here.  We've been to The Monterey Bay aquarium this doesn't compare. But it is nicely done. I loved the Huge tube with what lives in the bay. I liked how much of it was centered around what actually lives in the bay very interesting my 4 year old and 60+ year old father loved it. We'd come back again. It doesn't look like much from the outside but it's pretty big once you get inside.
author: Valerie M.

description: We enjoyed this aquarium on a Sunday morning. Not too crowded and the staff was extremely nice and friendly. If your expecting it to be like the Monterey Bay Aquarium you will be disappointed. This one is much smaller, enclosed and more intimate. Great for kids as its not to large for them to get lost in.
author: Bri R.

description:
We don't have a car, so as much as I'd like to go to Monterey Bay Aquarium, it is too much of a production for us.  I saw an online deal for SF's Aquarium of the Bay and my bf's birthday was coming up so I thought this was perfect!  We had a fun time looking at all the fish, jellyfish, sting rays, manta rays, chinchillas, otters -- the shark tunnel tank was definitely a highlight.  The river otters were sleeping but still cute.  

You can get a hand stamp and come back in same-day if you like.  The three river otters were all sleeping the first time we went, so we got some lunch and came back to see if they woke up.  They were semi-awake so that was ok.  We enjoyed the slow conveyor belt ride through the shark tunnel tank again!  :)
author: Maile N.

description: I haven't been to many aquariums, but this one is pretty good. They have otters, fish, stingrays, sharks, and lots more common sealife. There are awesome moving walkways that go through tunnels surrounded by a huge exhibit! Just imagine a 7-foot shark swimming over your head! Marine life has never been so neat.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Paying 20+ dollars seems kinda pricey for the amount of content. If it was $15ish I'd say it's reasonable. 

They do have a great staff though, super friendly
author: Allen C.

description: Love coming here!! Their basic membership cost $75 and it's you, and 1 guest. Plus the membership gives you 10% off certain restaurants. Minus 1 star because it's been almost 1 year, and we still haven't gotten our permanent card yet.
author: Xuan C.

description: Great set up for an aquarium! Love that it's a tunnel that you can walk through and see fishes from all angles. They have a wide variety of sharks, rays, starfish, fish, and more. Jelly fish exhibit was very pretty, and you can even finish up on the last floor (the aquarium exhibit is divided by floors via elevator rides) with land animals and pools of starfish and rays that you can touch. Perfect for kids. The otter exhibit at the end was a bit quiet (they were sleeping) but very cute! Entry is $21.95 per person, but you get a small discount if you're a Bay Area local!
author: Evonne L.

description: The tunnel was beautiful! Everything else is okay. The overall aquarium was pretty small for its price. My friend and I got done in less than an hour only because we spent most of our time in the tunnel.
author: Kathy M.

description: Awesome place to see what's under the ocean, loved all the different species of fish and mammals they had to show. This place would be so much fun if I was a little kid and got to experience the aquarium.
author: Nick T.

description:
I would give this place a 3.5 star. A nice little aquarium on pier 39. It's small yet engaging. Their collection of jelly fish was quite beautiful and their underwater tunnel was very well done.  However the place is a bit crammed and you have to wait to take the elevator. I guess I understand that they want you to have the whole experience of someone explaining the next room to you then wow of walking into a dim-lighted jellyfish aquarium... But the number of strollers on site just pushes the line back a lot. Their otter exhibit is very well done. The area is large and has three playful otters living in it. 

Pro: well done for such a small aquarium. Great jelly fish aquarium. Great tunnel aquarium with a number of sharks and rays.

Con: crowded.  Pricey for the size. No stairs.
author: Jamie L.

description: We decided to go since we had bought the San Francisco go pass, where you do as many things in a day as possible for one price. We don't ride in elevators (claustrophobic), and the staff was friendly enough to walk us down to the emergency exit and let us in that way. It was smaller than expected, but still really nice. We went in the morning and it wasn't crowded at all. My favorite was the jellyfish. They also had an area upstairs where you could see more animals and touch starfish. Overall, a positive experience.
author: Alex W.

description:
I think an update is warranted, being that I went to visit again this past weekend, nearly 3 years later from my last visit. I still maintain that this is a solid aquarium filled with interesting facts about the bay, beautiful jellyfish displays and oh yeah, a GIANT OCTOPUS (which I somehow missed during my last visit)

The tunnels with the sharks and rays gliding overhead never fails to entrance me and let's face it, when all is wrong with the world, going to the "touch" tank to pet the rays and starfish is about as zen as it gets. 

Quote of the day to my boyfriend at the touch pools "Hold my coat and get out of my way," as I rolled up my sleeves to my shoulder and stuck my entire arm in the tank...

The Yelp 100 Challenge-East Bay!
author: Jennifer N.

description: Took the kiddies here for the first time. I must say it was a fun and interesting experience. It's not as big as the one in Monterey but considering there are so many other attractions I can see that there may not be too much space. I think it's a little pricey but then again!!! We were in San Francisco lol. So maybe I take it back lol.. It was reasonable. I just wish I saw a bit more or wish there was more interactions for the kiddos. So I do believe you should check it out if ur visiting the area ;)
author: Kat G.

description:
The aquarium is probably a good place to go with kids but as an adult I think I would pass next time on visiting.

We were in and out within thirty minutes we were able to see all of the exhibits. When we made it to the gift shop I said "was that really it?"

Save your $ and go to the California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park where the exhibits are much more modern and impressive. 

I would have been disappointed if I had paid the $18 admission. Luckily, we had the City Pass so the admission was included in our booklet price.
author: Chelsea J.

description:
We stayed overnight for a Cub Scout event. My 9 year old son really enjoyed it.  The staff is very knowledgeable and really like what they do. We stayed in the jelly fish room--I'm telling you, staring at those jellies all night is like being on hallucinogens (not that I would know what those are really like). There is a huge shark and some big sea bass. The octopuses are very cool. 

My son really liked the petting pool. We were able to pet a baby Tiger Shark. Also, there were rays and starfish to touch. 

We never spend time at Pier 39, but this place is worth braving the touristas!
author: Donnie Mac M.

description: This is a neat place on Pier 39, if you have kids they will enjoy it. We got a nice discount on our tickets, which made it more reasonably priced. Had I paid full price I would have been disappointed for sure. I honestly thought it was going to be bigger. 30 minutes to do the whole walk through, so we did it twice. Monterey Bay Aquarium has this one beat by far, but it's still neat in it's own way. They have river otters and other animals you can't see other places. The nearshore & offshore tunnels are definitely the highlights of the aquarium. The touch pools were cool too.
author: Ashli B.

description: I went yesterday with my family We really love it. They have very nice tunnels you can see all kind sharks & other fishes. This aquarium has star fishes & very beautiful octopus too. If you have kids they really love this aquarium. We had lot of fun there.
author: S.R. S.

description: Aquarium Of The Bay is conveniently located next to Pier 39 and is the perfect Aquarium to take little ones too. We were very impressed with this nonprofit Aquarium, from the well taken care of exhibits, to the knowledge and friendliness of the staff.
