Yes, the Aquarium is smaller compared to The Academy of Sciences and The Monterey Bay Aquarium, both take a day to get through. However, we were at The Aquarium Of The Bay on a Saturday, for about two hours and were able to stroll through and enjoy a majority of the exhibits. The Aquarium was not crowded, which is a plus and we were able to touch a sting ray, small shark, box turtle, starfishes and sea enemies. We were also able to comfortably stroll through the tunnels that exhibit large sharks, sting rays, giant fish etc... The river otter exhibit is adorable and the salt water tank that exhibits the level of plastic in our oceans was fascinating. I also thought the gift shop had items that were reasonably priced and had a better selection for children's goods (books, t-shirts, stuffed animals etc.) than the Academy of Sciences. Another plus to this Aquarium is that because it is smaller (less overwhelming for the little ones) and conveniently located, it easy to go get lunch and/or ice cream after, see the seals and ride the carousel at Pier 39.
author: Cheryl B.

description: Small but very interesting. I enjoyed this however it is definitely overpriced
author: Brandi S.

description: We weren't impressed. Aquarium is small compared to others we've been to and seems outdated. It entertained the kids for maybe 30 minutes and then they were ready to go.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Nice facility with overhead immerse areas.  It's small so you can go through the whole place in 30 minutes.

We got in for free with our CityPasses.
author: Stuart B.

description:
Although I've been on the Embarcadero a million times I've never noticed this Aquarium. It was def a treat! The main highlight for me was the "tunnels" that you walk thru..I was completely mesmerized by the end. These huge fish & rays swim directly above you & the views of their bellies/undersides are amazing. I also really enjoyed the touch pools where there are tiny baby sharks & rays swimming around & you can touch them. 

I highly recommend this place for children & adults alike, I left feeling giddy & like I was seeing out of the eyes of a child. A GREAT PLACE!
author: Vanessa X.

description:
For what its has, its good, but it doesn't have much. From the outside you think its big, but the inside in just a small area with a quirky elevator system. You end out with a petting zoo of some kind, the fish kind.

If you are not willing to drive further to go somewhere else at least we have this in the city. I hope they expand at one point in the future.
author: John B.

description:
You can't compare this aquarium with any other bigger aquariums you have been. It is just not fair and not comparable. They mainly focus on showcasing the bay area. It is small but it is totally worth coming here if you have young children and would like to do more than just walking around the pier. The admission is very reasonable and if you park in the parking garage your get 2$ off for adults and 1$ for children/senior. 

Our son loved the aquarium in comparison to Monterey as it was not too overwhelming for him. No crowds and the exhibit was small and for little toddlers just the perfect place to explore sea creatures. The highlight was of course the tunnels as well as to take the elevators for each exhibit. 

The staff was very friendly and helpful. Will definitely return if we are in the area again .
author: Eri H.

description: I would have to agree with the current three star rating of this place. My fiancé and I love going to aquariums but this did not hold standard for us... Kind of a disappointment. The best part was Karen, the lady that was talking and feeding the Rays and sharks. Small compared to others that we have been to. The bright side is you don't have to spend the whole day here if you have small children.
author: Brandon C.

description: I have been here lots of times. It's very relaxing and peaceful to see. One problem is that the place is very small other wise. I love this place!
author: C G.

description:
In wandering around Pier 39 the honey and I stopped in front of the Aquariaum. Not quite ready to go home we decided to take a peek inside. Sadly we should have skipped it.

Admission was $16.95 but they were giving out coupons in front thus I paid about 14.95. Which frankly still felt like too much to simply look at a bunch of (beyond the huge sharks) generally uninteresting fish and two small tide pools.

The building is quite small and uses an elevator to navigate floors, thus on busy days the one elevator is overfilled to the point of being uncomfortable and the hallways are extremely hard to navigate with their people mover.

It was an experience, but I doubt, after being to Monterey Bay, that I'd ever spend money to come back.
author: Meg T.

description: Pretty good experience. Smaller than I was expecting compared to other aquariums but the tunnel aquarium was pretty neat on how long it was. Good to do if you're down by the pier and looking for something to do. Good they promote healthy water and how to conserve/save the ocean and its animals.
author: Ranee W.

description:
I Came here on a LivingSocial Deal so it was only $11 per person plus if you buy any Livingsocial deal which is $25 or more you can use the PROMO CODE AUG10 and get $10 off so i bought three for my hubby, my little sister and myself and only paid $23 so it was a pretty good deal.

Pros:
1.I love sea life. I go scuba diving during every vacation i have taken because i find all sea life so fascinating therefore i loved the walk in tunnel which allows you to see stingray, different species of fish and sharks swimming around.
2. I got to touch a baby shark and stingray!!!!!!! yes i was transformed into a 5 year old.
3. I do like that they have alot of information plaques so children can read about the animals.
4. All of the workers were extremely patient with the children who ran around marveling at the sharks or fought to get a chance to touch the baby shark or stingray.

Cons: 
1. It can get a little loud.
2. There honestly isn't a huge variety of sea life to see.
3. (This is probably my bad timing since i went two hours before closing) but the sea otters were asleep in their cave and we did not get to see them. They did look absolutely adorable sleeping though lol.

Overall it was a fun trip and i got to learn a lot. I wouldn't have paid full price but since i got such a great deal it was well worth it!
author: Renu D.

description:
"Aquapalooza" is an adults-only (21+) pirate-themed party with science and a silent disco from 7-10 at Aquarium of the Bay.  I won 2 tickets and I was very excited for our first trip here and to learn more about the place. We parked at Pier 39 parking garage ($9/hour), conveniently located across the street.  It was foggy and very cold and windy! We practically ran to the Aquarium and up the stairs to the entrance where we were ID'ed and let in, but hardly greeted by any of the four employees we encountered.  We were each given complimentary drink tickets (won with the VIP ticket prize) - which was awesome because the rum punch they were serving in the tiny rocks glass was $8.00!

There were several displays with land animals.  I didn't know why they would keep two chinchillas in a tiny glass cage in an aquarium. The frogs and snakes and turtles seemed more fitting.

A woman spoke to the audience while we were being fed nachos, sliders, and a noodle dish, from three local restaurants (Wipeout Bar and Grill,Fog Harbor Fish House, and Pier Market, who ran out of the scallops they were serving with the noodles before we arrived.) The food was very good and the speaker was very entertaining.  She is the sustainable initiative manager for the Aquarium and has studied the effects of plastic pollution in the ocean. It was amazing to hear her speak about the pollution she saw as her expedition team sailed across the Atlantic. 

 We waited in a slow line to go downstairs to the tunnels where we were able to view many more fish. The Aquarium was actually very full with several different species. Some of the fish were HUGE! Even the starfish were much bigger than I expected. It was really neat to watch them swim past us. I loved looking at their eyes and faces, searching for smiles on their fish lips.

The Aquarium has a gift shop near the entrance.  They sold trinkets and fish-themed necklaces and tee-shirts, as well as photos they took of their guests (in pirate costumes) earlier in the evening.  The $21 package of less than 5 pictures wasn't a sell for us, but we did go back and take some pictures on our own phone with the pirate gear!

The "silent disco" meant wearing headphones as you walked around that had 3 music stations to choose from. Many of the guests were drinking and dancing and having lots of fun in the tunnel. It was definitely not a silent disco for them as they stomped and danced.  You had to give your ID over to the staff in order to "check-out" a pair of the headphones. (Which was why the line was so slow getting down to this level.) The system they used for holding the MANY driver's licenses and passports they were collecting was surprisingly disorganized and we waited a long time in line to receive AND return our headphones.  With $9/hour parking you'd think they'd have a better idea of how to keep the IDs in some sort of efficient (alphabetical) order. But standing in the line did give us time to finish our second free beverage (went with a tasty bottled Hefe beer). 

 The event was really cool....for free.  The regular $25 tickets plus Eventbrite fee would have left me very disappointed had we actually paid to attend this.  I thought the staff was terrible.  The woman operating the elevator to and from the tunnel told us about their switch to a non-profit only a few years ago, and the work she does to bring children to the Aquarium free of charge. She was the only person who told us anything about the place and there were lots of staff walking around.  I know this is a huge tourist destination, given the location, but we would have loved to learn more about the place.  It's also much smaller than the Monterey Bay Aquarium, so if you've been into that gorgeous Aquarium, don't expect anything near the same size.  The jelly fish displays were probably my favorite thing here. The beautiful boneless fish are mesmerizing. I was really glad to get to see this place and especially for such a unique event; hopefully they continue to improve their execution of nighttime events for guests.

Thanks to FunCheapSF for the free tickets and unique date night with my husband!
author: Amy S.

description:
This was a fun little aquarium on the bay. I like the first floor with the moving walk way underneath the tunnel. That reminded us of a Valencia aquarium we visited in Spain.

This place is pretty nice but it's a bit small for an aquarium. It fit perfectly in our day as we only had an hour to do something- but you can't spend much more time than that in there.
author: Tamara H.

description: Nice but small and not worth the amount of admission. The tunnels of fish and sharks were cool but very crammed. Horrible set up for a photo opportunity blocked the pathway and caused major backing up of people in a small area. I had a discount through my local zoo so was happy I didn't pay full price. Cute gift shop that the kids enjoyed and we all loved the otters at the exit of the aquarium.
author: Monique V.

description:
Not the best aquarium ever, but still a fun time. It's a small place, so it's a quick trip through the jelly fish and under water tunnels (no penguins...lame) but you end up in the touch pool area. The touch pools are the aquarium's saving grace. Oh so cute sting rays float around waving their little fin arms at you! Being from Chicago, I naturally compare this to the Shedd Aquarium, which is bigger and has more big animals, their touch pools pale in comparison. If you're playing tourist at Pier 39 and are obsessed with aquariums like I am, you won't mind giving them your $15. 

HINT...pick up a brochure in the welcome center across the pier to save $2 on admission.
author: Kirsten A.

description: This is a small but very fun Aquarium my kids ages 14, 7, 2 and 1 really enjoyed the experience. I can't say enough about how the tunnels are so close and so amazing. We really enjoyed this place small but fun
author: Joel-Amanda R.

description:
Id say a 4.5.  Great variety and very pleasant staff.  Loved the three floors... The tubes and individual aquariums, as well as the interactive areas were wonderful.  Wish it had some more floors/exhibits, but I did think hat they do have was wonderful. 

A bit overpriced for the size of the place, however pretty common for an attraction in the tourist area of pier 39.  :)

I would bring my child here.
author: Lyndsey C.

description: It shouldn't have cost about 25 dollars for a small aquarium that takes 20 minutes to go through. Even one of the employees told a joke about the elevator being the best part of the whole trip. Why so expensive for a small aquarium. The Cal Academy of Science has more sea life and animals than The Aquarium of the Bay.
author: Noah R.

description:
Over-priced Overly Crowded Friendly Staff.

Since we purchased tickets to the San Francisco Magic Show we were given the opportunity to upgrade to include tickets into the aquarium for a small fee of $11 for adults and $8 for children. Under normal circumstances I wouldn't have done this but my sons was dying to go although we've been here once before. It was also a cheap upgrade compared to the actual entrance fee. 

The exhibits were pretty cool featuring jellyfish and shark exhibit. I thought the coolest part of our visit was the 300 feet tunnels featuring thousands of local marine animals. They also had a touch pool where you can touch the starfish, rays and sharks. It took us roughly an hour and 15 minutes to complete the walk-through. I was pretty miserable toward the end.

Overall there is nothing spectacular about this aquarium. It's over-priced overly crowded and too many strollers Had I not gotten the upgrade I would have paid $35 for adults $25 for children. Hence, I don't have a need to come back for another visit.
author: Rochelle P.

description:
Worst Aquarium I have ever been to.

Hell, I have been to fish stores that were better. 

Sure it has a tube where fish swim over you and that is cool but the place is cramped and not well planned out. 

At $20 a ticket save your money spend it on gas and drive the two hours to Monterrey Bay.

Pathetic excuse for an aquarium.
author: Drew W.

description:
Small but packed full of animals.  Easy and engaging aquarium for the young, especially the conveyer walk through tunnel.   My 6 year old wanted a repeat-- 4 times!  The super enthusiastic and eager staff and naturalists were a refreshing crew compared to their Monterrey counterparts.  

Get the 50% coupon!  They're everywhere.
author: Surai J.

description: The place is pretty small, so I feel like the price is too high. With that said, they have a pretty cool underwater tunnel. I'll give an extra star for that.
author: Abbey Q.

description: Small aquarium geared more toward kids.  I went through it within 45 minutes.  The tunnel aquariums seemed quite dirty with a lot of stuff floating.  Maybe I  just wasn't in the right mood to be inside when it was beautiful outside...  I went to it as it was part of the City Pass.  I wasn't impressed...
author: Rick P.

description: Convenient way to view sealife with the family and stay in the city :) Love their otter feeding and touch pond.  It's not the largest, but I really like what they're doing for preservation and community education.
author: Kate S.

description:
We were visiting San Francisco for our honeymoon, and we found ourselves with a little extra time to kill on our last day.  We decided what the heck, let's hit the aquarium since it's convenient and will take the right amount of time to see before we have to be at a theater show at 3:00.

Of course the aquarium is somewhat pricey, I think $16 per person for adults, but we had a coupon from some parking structure that gave us $2 off per person, so that helped.

Overall this is a very nice aquarium.  Their use of elevators to move guests through the exhibits and keep traffic moving was interesting!  It's geared toward kids, of course, but we enjoyed it as two child-free adults as well.  The moving walkway through the tunnels with the fish all around you was pretty neat.  

If you are an aspiring or hobbyist photographer, you can get some really great shots and challenge yourself here with your shutter speed and ability to compose shots.  The fish are often quite beautiful.  

Other than price, my one main complaint was that it was so short!  After the area where you get to pet/touch the rays and sharks and sea stars, the exhibit abruptly ends in the gift shop.  Disappointing!  Oh well... the displays were beautiful and we had fun!
author: Johanna K.

description:
Today 2/25/10 is the last day for Alameda County residents to go FREE to the Aquarium of the Bay.  All we had to do was go to the main entrance upstairs and show our ID.  That was sweet.

My 2nd visit and I still enjoy it.  Moon Jelly, other jellyfishes.  Went for the 12:30pm Bat Ray feeding - upstairs on the 3rd Fl.  

Saw:
Chinchilla - cute, like a small rabbit w/ flat nose. Saw 2 this time.
Blue Tongued Skink - it didn't stick out it's tongue this time.
Pink Toed Tarantulas - does have pink toes.
Skates - nice, like bat rays
Bat Rays - cool, they jump up.  Can touch tip of wing w/ 1 finger - I didn't.
African Pygmy Hedgehog - it just stayed in the corner w/ its back to the window - didn't do anything.
Calif. Kingsnake - naturalist showed us an Albino Kingsnake.  Doesn't bite, very cool, has red eyes!

Saw the Shark feeding - just ok.  Took a while, maybe 20 min.  Go to the 2nd tunnel, mid-way and stand on the carpet side.  Only on Thurs & Sun.

Recommended.
author: Ann L.

description:
Boo!!

Usually I'm a fan of anything that is related to animals, but not of this place! Overall, I was disappointed by the Aquarium of the Bay. It really fell short of what I was expecting. Let me briefly break it down...

*About $26 to get in for an adult ticket (kids are less). 
*If you don't have children, you can easily get in and get out in under one hour. 
*There are two levels of this aquarium, but they're both kind of a joke. 
*I will give them credit for the bottom level since you're pretty much walking through a tube surrounded all around by fish, sharks, starfish, sting rays, etc. It was pretty cool. But, you'll be through it in maybe 15-20 minutes (depending on how fast you walk and how many pictures you take). I wish they had more animals down here to be honest. 
*Top level is smaller and not too much to do unless you have kids with you. They have a couple of tanks where you can actually pet whatever animals they have in there (which was pretty cool) and they also have a couple small tanks to look at other animals. This level you can be done with in 10-15 minutes. 
*There's a gift store. It has pretty cool stuff and I was tempted to buy a couple of items. 

Overall, this place is so small and not so fun if you're an adult. If you have kids with you, it probably would be more fun. I'm a kid at heart when it comes to animals and generally enjoy aquariums. But, I felt this place was too small and needed some more work to have its "wow" factor. 

Would I come back here again? Nope!

Cheers!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Do you take your kids here before or after eating a seafood dinner?

Before. Saves you money when they don't want to eat seafood for dinner. 

Small aquarium on the pier that will take about an hour to go through if you take your time. Very easily accessible for strollers and wheelchairs. Nice variety of animals and exhibits. Gift shops are strategically placed on your way out.. and when you think you made it through one, oh look here's another just in case you forgot something at the first shop. 

Definitely makes for a nice day at the pier, especially if you're visiting and won't make it to Monterrey during your trip. Less expensive and the kids will enjoy.
author: JASMIN O.

description:
I had low expectations of this aquarium for several reasons, including reading some of the reviews on Yelp and coming here YEARS ago when I was a kid when it was much smaller and kind of dumpy). I was pleasantly surprised, though! Although a smaller aquarium than the Monterey Bay Aquarium and California Academy of Sciences Steinhart Aquarium, I thought they had plenty to offer in a small package (native fish, tropical fish, sharks, jellyfish, otters, and other small animals including an opossum and a couple of chinchillas). Everything was very clean and well-maintained and that staff was super friendly and helpful. The bathrooms were very clean, too, with plenty of stalls.

The only thing I really didn't like was the use of elevators to get to the floor with the underwater tunnel and jellyfish. I am not a fan of elevators and being crammed in a small space with a bunch of people including screaming, rambunctious kids and people with huge strollers is not my idea of a good time. Unfortunately, the doors to the stairway were locked and we couldn't find anyone to open the doors at the time (although the staff was very understanding of me not liking elevators), so we waited until the evening when less people were there to go down to the floor with the underwater tunnel. Everything else is accessible via the top floor, though (the fish displays, animal displays, and otters). The elevator did have a staff member there to control the elevator, so that was reassuring. They also tell you more about the animals they have there.

My favorite exhibits were the tropical fish tank (I LOVE tropical fish and they had a lot of cute clownfish there) and the otters. The otter exhibit was much nicer than I expected and pretty big. The three otters we saw seemed very happy playing together and would come up to the glass every now and then. The underwater tunnel was also beautiful and much bigger with more fish in it than from what I remember from when I was a kid.

Some Tips:

- If you have a membership to a zoo that participates in the Zoo Reciprocal Admissions Program, make sure you show them your membership card to get a discount. My boyfriend and I are members of the Oakland Zoo, so we both got 50% off our admission. There are also sometimes coupons available online and Groupon offers deals at times, too.

- Go in the evening during their summer hours (open until 8pm), if you can. There were much less people on the day we went (Sunday) during that time and we could actually enjoy the exhibits for the most part (although there were still some screaming, undisciplined kids there, which is pretty much to be expected).

- The otters are asleep during the day, so if you want to see them really active, go during the early morning or late evening hours. We saw them first when they were sleeping around 4:30, but came back around 6:30 and they were running all over the place and playing. Very cute!

I really enjoyed this aquarium and would come back, especially with a discount. It may be small, but I thought it had a lot to offer.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I'm from the east coast so, I wasn't impressed. Mystic, CT is better. The sea lions outside ae more interesting.
author: Jess H.

description: Coming from San Diego and having visited many amazing aquariums around the world, I would say this aquarium is just okay, nothing out of the ordinary.The staff members were very polite and earnest and would answer questions. However, the facility needs a bit of modernizing, more clarity of the water, better lighting and flora to create a vibrant and interesting aquarium. I got a discount with my AAA card, so this was a plus.
author: Heather G.

description:
i can't say that its was amazing, but it was a pretty good experience. walking through all the displays with fish that i would never normally see was pretty cool, esp the underwater section. nothing that excites you but pleasant to look at. every time we had a question and just blurted it out, there was a lady there to answer it. she was like a ninja, you didn't she was there, you ask a question, to nobody, while looking at the fishes and voila she is there to answer it. This happened to us like 4-5 times.  

The best and cutest display has to be the river otters, they are mostly active and its really fun to see them play.   

definitely worth checking out, but they haven't updated it in a while. i was here last year and it was the same displays and the same stuff, nothing new.
author: Anuj C.

description:
I suppose that I was expecting an exciting experience as this place is located not too far from the new Exploratorium location (you get a few bucks off the ticket price if you show your Exploratorium ticket, actually), but I was completely underwhelmed by the entire experience.

As far as aquariums go, this place was lackluster and extremely limited. The jellyfish tanks are cool, but everything else is just sort of "blah." The river otters at the end helped to make up for the bland overall experience, but it was still way overpriced.
author: Ryan E.

description: I really enjoyed the aquarium.  Having a place like this right by the ocean i would have expected it to be much larger than it really was.  I loved the jelly fish though,  so beautiful!
author: Rena A.

description:
Came for our Valentines Day celebration. I remember coming as a kid and could have sworn it was so much bigger  but it was still so much fun. I loved the jelly fish! There was a worker who was showing the Jellies at every age and that was awesome. 
After a while we got hungry so we went to the cafe, we expect sky rocketed prices but they were decent. YOU HAVE TO TRY THE ENCHILADAS!!! Oh my gosh. Lovely. Great day!
author: Anna S.

description: The aquarium was very well put together but due to it's small size I gave it 3 stars. For 20 dollars a person I was hoping for something larger. It took less than an hour to go through the whole thing. What they do have is very nice though! I'd say it is about 1/10 the size of Monterrey Bay Aquarium. If you have little kids, they will love this place!
author: Andrew Z.

description: I was pretty disappointed with this place. For $20+ a person to get in I was expecting something decent, but it was honestly so small. If it hadn't been for the petting look to pet the rays and the otters I would have probably asked for my money back. It literally took my wife and I 15 minutes to walk through. We're from so-cal and long beaches aquarium is by far a better place to visit. Much larger, way more animals to see and alot more to do. I don't recommend this attraction.
author: Greg C.

description: I was visiting San Francisco for the weekend and this was a part of of the CityPass...this is definitely a great spot if you have little kids but for a 20-something this is not worth your time if you are only visiting for a limited amount of time. It is also pretty small. You can touch sting rays so that is pretty cool but otherwise save this spot for if you have 5+ days in San Fran.
author: Melanie P.

description: Love love love! The tunnels were awesome,  felt like you were in there with the fishes and sharks
author: esther h.

description: This isn't the Monterey Bay Aquarium, but it is a really interesting place to visit. The way how the displays are laid out and the order in which you view them insure you see them all. The most interesting exhibit takes you down an elevator to the tunnel tank which shows you what it looks like under the piers and the creatures that inhabit it's waters. The other half shows the aquatic life out in the bay. It's really interesting to see what goes on below the surface. Whenever we ride a boat or walk on a pier, we never really think about what may be living right under us!!  The staff are very helpful and they guide and interact with visitors very well. One note to fellow Yelpers, I checked in after I purchased my tickets, but little did I know you get a 20% off admission deal when you check in on Yelp!
author: Dave F.

description:
Seen one, seen them all. 

This is a smaller aquarium (been to Monterey's and others) but if you're in the area, or have guests, worth a stop.

What made our visit enjoyable was the extra Behind the Scenes tour. We spent another 45 minutes seeing the octopus get fed (given his toy with hidden fish inside), walking the catwalks above the 2 tunnels, seeing shark eggs, shark teeth, sting ray stinger, and learning about how the animals are taken care of. 

Purchased tickets at discount plus a code thru Trusted Tours website. You get an in and out stamp on the hand. We toured on our own for about an hour, then took the extra tour, went to have lunch, then returned for the tidepool section.

Otters were very active. The exhibit is very visible which made it nice. You could see them in their den or playing in the water. 

Tide pool show was quite informative, feeding the anemone and star fish, and learning about the sea cucumber.
author: Ree T.

description:
I had better memories of this place when I was little. My classes used to take field trips here, and I loved the tunnel where you can see the fishes swim above you. I thought it was the coolest thing. Now, however, that I'm older, this place doesn't seem so cool. It's a relatively small aquarium but they do have a lot of stuff to see. And I like that there's an area where you can touch the starfish and sting rays--that was the highlight of my visit. My favorite was also the jellyfish, which looked really pretty, and I was able to capture some good photos of them.

Overall, I still think this is a place worth visiting, if you happen to take a trip to Pier 39. It completes the experience. Pier 39 may seem like a tourist trap, but they do have a lot of cool stuff to see and eat, so the aquarium definitely adds to the experience.
author: Karen L.

description:
This place wasn't bad, and it wasn't great. It is a solid 3 stars. The location is excellent if you are spending the day on the piers and want to get in one more tourist attraction ad have about an hour. They have one of those water tunnels which is HUGE. Kids would really enjoy this place as they have excellent touch pools which baby rays and sharks. 

Employees were helpful they gave us the local discount when they saw were from San Jose and it took $10 off our tickets, that was COOL!

All in all once you have done it once no need to go back but we had a pleasant experience and enjoyed our time at the Aquarium of the Bay.
author: Caitlin C.

description: My expectations of this aquarium were not met. Staff are some young students that show their mood, tired and over their shift. The place needs to be remodeled badly. I feel like the fish you find here you can find at Petsmart. Definitely not coming back.
author: Rene F.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for over 20 years and have only been to Pier 39 a few times, so when family was in town last weekend we decided to check it out again. Since we had Alcatraz scheduled in the afternoon, we decided to go early and check out the Aquarium, which I had never been to. 
 
Wow, I have to say I was pleasantly surprised! Although smaller than the Monterey Bay Aquarium, the exhibits were cool, especially the tunnels, the touch pools and the otter exhibit.   What really stuck out for me were the staff, who were informative and friendly.
 
If you haven't been there before (I know locals don't go to Pier 39), I recommend you check out the Aquarium of the Bay.
author: Jeff S.

description: Way too expensive for this short and bohring show. There is not much to see and you want 22 dollar for it. I expected to see way more like see lions and so on
author: Michael Y.

description: Very disappointed visit.  I expect much more from an "aquarium".  They only have 3 showroom total and only 1 really stand out (the under water one).  The rest is just is merely there.  The staffs are really give you a hype about everything, even the sleeping otters... I got the ticket on sale for $16, but it didn't worth it
author: Chris N.

description:
My kids and I just spent a very enjoyable couple of hours here. The kids were fascinated by the river otters swimming around, as was an octopus!

I really liked the glass tunnels...you actually feel like you're underwater with sharks and fish swimming all around you!

Everyone was friendly and extremely knowledgeable. My son wants to come back for the Feed The Sharks tour during which you get a bucket of fish to feed the sharks...but you need to book ahead. 

Oh yes, we also enjoyed their new sea lion center further down on Pier 39...which was FREE!
author: Carolyn D.

description:
I visited the Aquarium with my almost-2-year-old daughter on the Friday after Thanksgiving, and early in the morning, so it was not excessively crowded and the otters were still active (they tend to sleep in the afternoon). We parked our stroller just outside the main entrance. Staff was helpful (although clearly they were instructed to tell people there was no stroller parking anywhere).

One has to adjust expectations: this is not the Monteray Bay Aquarium or the Vancouver Aquarium, and the space is very small due to the location. Entrance at other big aquariums will cost over $30, so at $22 it's not out of line in my opinion. (Do check your library Discover & Go program, or your tourism map for a discount coupon.) The space and displays are not flashy, and the elevator system is a little unusual - but it worked very well during our visit. (I can imagine it's tougher when crowded.) 

We had a lovely experience. My daughter loves sharks, jellies and colorful fish, and there were plenty of those. The otters were being fed and running around in what seemed like (relatively) reasonable space. The tunnels are truly well designed and impressive, an ingenious use of such a small building. Sadly, my daughter was scared by the divers cleaning the shallow-Bay tunnel and we had to make a beeline for the exit. She is also too short to really take advantage of the touch pools, which is too bad because there were almost no other kids there at the time of our visit. 

The possum and chinchilla exhibits are really, really small - frankly I think it would be better not to have them. 

Also of note: there were a bunch of signs in Japanese that appeared related to the campaign to ban sharkfin soup. I totally support the campaign, but the signs looked almost like someone had "hacked" into the exhibit. Why no comparable English signs? 

Overall, considering my relatively low expectations, I'm happy to give the Aquarium of the Bay 4 stars. My daughter was pleased, too.
author: Brigitte G.

description:
I am giving it 4 stars because I got my passes though Groupon and felt that it was worth the price because of that.  
It took us about 30 to 45 minutes to go through the entire exhibit - but everything that I saw there was cool and everyone that worked there was really friendly and informative.
Seeing all the different sharks and learning about all the underwater species in the area was cool as well.  I would go back with others if the wanted to as long as I could get the Groupon deal again.
author: Mark S.

description:
Out of all the times I've been to Pier 39, I just went for my first time to the Aquarium of the Bay. We went here for a spontaneous date adventure, which turned out to be really fun. At first, I was a little put off by the appearance of the establishment, but it turned out to be nicer than I originally thought.

My favorite things were probably the coral reef aquarium (you'll see a lot of fish from Finding Nemo!) and the jellyfish room in general.

They have a new sea otter exhibit with three specimens in the habitat. They're super cute.

Their moving sidewalk is pretty cool, which takes you through a couple difference rooms with overhead aquariums, and it's a nice way to slowly pass by all the large fish and sharks and sting rays.
author: Denise B.

description: For what they offer and how much they charge, its ok. The best part is waking through the domed tank where you feel surrounded by the sea creatures. This place is skip-able, unless you have a lot of time to kill or just love aquariums.
author: Gill S.

description: These reviews surprise me , me and my fiancé are 25 years olds and we LOvED this place . The large fish and amazing looking Sharks where breathtaking . We went as a family and we all loved it . Definitely a must see if your near the peer ... Perfect for kids and audults of all ages . I love the exhibits where one can actually touch the water. I say print out a coupon and take the family defenitly worth the trip
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Had a blast here! But, it isn't the biggest aquarium around. The tunnels are really cool, but probably the highlight of the whole place. If you live in the Bay, tell them and you only pay $18 a person!

The jellies and octopus were also amazing.
author: Nathan T.

description:
From Monday through Thursday of last week, admission was FREE if you had proof of being a San Francisco resident. Since it was free, I decided to help this place out & buy a few things...

I went on Monday around 2PM, and there was no line to get in, I sort of expected one since this was advertised on Yelp. Flash your SF residency proof, get a hand stamp, then go in.

After getting a hand stamp, you go towards the left to see a few creatures...Northern Anchovies...then you walk to the back & go down the elevator to see more sea creatures. You go through a tunnel with small sea creatures...then through another tunnel with large creatures. It reminded me of Kelly Tarlton in New Zealand but that I believe had an airport like escalator, so no need to walk. After the entrance at Aquarium of the Bay, you then go back to the elevator & go back up, there's a tide pool, so you can touch sting rays & sharks, COOL. The sting rays kept coming up to nod & say hi to me (for air), that was cool. If you want to touch the sea creatures on the bottom of the pool, make sure your arm is long enough & roll up your sleeves. A another tide pool with starfish near the exit/gift shop. There were a few more sea creatures, turtles, tree frogs, CHINCHILLAS...along the way.

I don't think it's worth $16, maybe $10 but not $16, it's too small for $16. You can finish looking at everything under an hour.

4 stars because it was free. If I had to pay, 2 or 3 stars, too small for such a large price. There's a lot more to see at the Academy of Sciences for a little more $.
author: Kylie L.

description:
This place is located on Pier 39, the touristy part of touristy San Francisco, at the front of the store row.  This place isn't as big as Monterey Bay aquarium but for the space they have, it is impressive enough.  The crown jewel of this place is the underwater tunnels down below.  There are two sections of the tunnels, one section loaded with various fish and another loaded with various sized sharks.  There are small exhibits upstairs and downstairs with various other marine life on display.  They have a nice little otter exhibit which is a lively one when they are running about like energetic scamps.  

It's a cool thing to see if you are in town or need to do something fun in the area to kill time.  Also, it is of noteworthiness that if you are a member of other organizations, the reciprocity discount can make the sting of buying tickets here much less painful as you will pay tourist prices to get in.  This place is always a fun little time killer that I frequent when I can, I encourage you to do the same.
author: David A.

description: Lack luster... If your expecting the Monterey aquarium this ain't it. Small, poor layout,pricey and lots of upcharges available. After a tiny exhibit area your funneled into an elevator lobby to get to the other two levels. Only one of the two elevators was working which made for long waits and crowded cars. Before getting on the elevator they take a "free" picture that you can buy at the end $$$$$. The aquarium is small with very little staff interaction. Except at the tide pool/ touch pool at the end. My son had fun but not sure it was worth the price of admission.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I love animals and aquariums and zoos are some of my favorite places to visit. On a recent trip to San Francisco we had a few hours to kill before the Giants game so I stopped by the Aquarium of the Bay. Overall the aquarium is nice. There are lots of marine animals to see, fishes, sharks and other aquatic life. The displays are good with informative text and photos. There is a large kid's area with opportunities to touch starfish and manta rays. The large "undersea" tunnel is also pretty cool and a fun way to experience undersea life. 

However, because the emphasis of this aquarium is the San Francisco Bay it doesn't have any exotic or really cool animals. The jellyfish were the coolest exhibit in my opinion, but that doesn't make-up for the rest of the aquarium.

All things considered I wish I'd saved my $16 and not visited the Aquarium of the Bay, I've been to other aquariums that were a lot more fun and had a much better selection of aquatic creatures.
author: Sam S.

description:
I do not feel like this aquarium is worth the amount they charge for admission. I feel that it was overpriced and overcrowded on the day I went. It was a lot smaller than I expected and I was hoping for more education as well. In the area with the tide pools the main focus I was seeing was petting and touching (which was nice) but it was too crowded for us to really get that chance.

It is nice to have an aquarium on the pier but I feel that it should be cheaper for what they offer and maybe let customers know that there are 3 school field trips going on before we but our ticket to enter the small space. 

I would highly recommend the Monterrey Bay Aquarium to get a better experience & education for yourself & kids.
author: Christin H.

description:
Much more impressive than imagined from the commercials, especially given such a small piece of real estate. The layout is a little hair-brained .. which you do NOT realize until you are in the twenty minute elevator line, waiting with 15 children who have the combined energy of a neutron bomb, with nothing to divert their attention.  Idea: put a staff member here dressed as a sea otter with a seaweed touching station on the far end.  Anything would really change the dynamic.  It's like taking kids to an amusement park for 30 minutes and then expecting them to, immediately following, sit patiently in your dentist's waiting room for an equal amount of time. 

But I digress... fans of the Monterrey Bay Aquarium will love this, especially the tunnels.  This is what sets this small aquarium apart.  You'll still see other interesting exhibits here, albeit experiencing essentially the same animals and habitats on a reduced scale. But when you're driving close to 2 hours for that experience, scale is way overrated.  

Let me demonstrate with Exhibit A: my 15-month-old son, Phoenix.  He has been to both parks.  Per the Excite-O-Meter, a parenting device that makes heavy use of an ages-old formula involving a) Excitement, (duh!) measured by both peak and sustained hyperactivity ... b) Education: illustrated by memory cells actively devoted to vocabulary growth exhibited over a minimum of 12 hours following (ie, your kid never has uttered the sound "stafish" and now every multipointed object is a "stafish") ... and most importantly, c) Parental Satisfaction: how fast (and long) he sleeps post-event ... by all these measures the trip was a raging success and yes, we will probably be coming back at least once a year.  

I have to admit, we'd come more often but dealing with the parking horrors and then coughing up equal amounts for the entire experience AND parking???  Are you kidding?  Parking was the second visit to the dentist's waiting room .. and cost just as much.
author: Alex J.

description:
So my boyfriend and I did their Behind the Scenes Tour.  It was actually quite fun.  So we first got there, and we were a little late but luckily they didn't leave us behind.  They showed us where the animals were fed, what they were fed, where they were taken care of when sick or injured, where they were kept for breeding, or etc.

I LOVED the tour and thought it was super exciting being able to see all the different things that happen in the background.  Be prepared to constantly have to smell a fishy smell the whole way through ... since you are at an aquarium, going on top of the tanks.  Also, do not where flip-flops.  The floors have puddles and unless you want fish smelling feet all day, then wear some shoes.

The aquarium itself is quite nice, but smaller then I thought it would be.  And I wish I had went through the aquarium first , before doing the tour ... since I thought the tour was so great and felt so into it.

If you are visiting the area or just haven't been to the aquarium yet/haven't visited in a while, I'd suggest coming back for the Behind the Scenes tour.  Go early to check out the aquarium first (free admission into aquarium when you purchase Behind the Scenes tickets) and then go on your tour after.

I think I might go back to do the tour again.  =)
author: Pia V.

description: Really cool!  When I was there they had a meet the blue tongue skink and shark/ray feeding so that was cool to see. I really loved the shark/ray/fish tunnels. It's so cool and they're so big!  Feels like you can touch them!  It's a good time for adults and kids.
author: Tammy W.

description:
I enjoyed my day with my son by visiting the Aquarium of the Bay for the very first time!! 

Pros:

- Opened at 10 am

- You can get discounts, IF, you are a local residents to 6 or 9 different Bay Area counties by showing your DL as proof.

- Also, IF, you are NOT a local residents, you can still get discounts to the Aquarium, IF, you happened to park at the Pier 39 parking garage. When I parked today, I received 4 long paper (parking slip, discounts to the Aquarium, Fudge plus one other place), which one was a discount to the Aquarium. $2.00 off of an Adult ticket whereas $1.00 off of a child's ticket. Not bad.

- Two different gift shops (one at the beginning + the other at the end).

- Most everyone here who worked on 1/26/20014 were super friendly, professional and knowledgeable.

- Both my son and I enjoyed 2 tunnels, which was so peaceful and got to see various sharks + other kind of fishes. I did take photos so I will have to upload them.

- Prior to starting your visit, I ran into 2 guys who took photos, which at the very end of your visit, you can buy them at the 2nd gift shop. IF, I can remember correctly, the big picture + a thin voucher was $21.00, the picture + thick booklet was $24.95 plus there were (2) 5x7, which was like how much? I thought I kept hearing $1.65, but that would be too cheap wouldn't it? It must have been $11.65, but I'm not sure now. And, IF, you wanted to buy the whole package then the guy mentioned $40 something. I decided to buy the picture + booklet, which one of the guys gave me one of the smaller 5x7 for free, which was very kind of him to include that. Too bad, he wasn't that generous to give me rest of our pictures for free. haha I'm assuming, they recycle unsold pictures, right? 

After you get your photos taken, you walk through the door into a hallway with 2 elevators. I tried looking for the button to go downstairs with no available and one older couple came along so I asked them, "Do you know?" The wife was like, "I hope this isn't a scenario where it's some kind of prank such as the candid camera show." haha Just to be sure, she walked back to the guys taking photos and asked, "Do you know where the buttons are for the elevators out here?" Turns out, there was a guy working the elevators who comes up and picks you up between the floor downstairs and the floor beneath it. :)

Overall, my son and I had a blast visiting the Aquarium of the Bay!!

IF, you have NEVER visited, you should.
author: Risa S.

description:
Good start, bad finish. 

We were taken in an elevator down to the bottom floor where they have a walk through tube with animals swimming around you. Definitely cool so we were excited to see what else there was. 

We were then taken to the upper level which had a couple touch pools and some animals in display cases. 

And then...;that was it! It was a very small aquarium and if we had had to pay for the tix, we would've been even more disappointed (we used our city pass). 

The aquarium @ the california academy of sciences is much better and more extensive than this one. It was literally two small exhibits and that was all.
author: Suie C.

description:
Okay, I agree with other comments about the price of the tickets and small scale of the exhibits. However, I have to say it's better than I expected. It's on the prime location at Pier 39, you pay for the location. We got 50% regular price for being a zoo member. 

The jelly fish exhibits were amazingly beautiful. And some color little fish caught my toddler's eyes. It's small but perfect size for my toddler. It's a perfect 20-30 minutes quick stop for a little kid while you're visiting the Fisherman's Wharf.
author: J G.

description:
"wait...THAT'S it?"

pretty much sums up my visit to aquarium of the bay as we were being dumped into the customary gift shop - roughly 30-40 mins into our visit.

=(

what are we supposed to do all day now?! 

yes, perhaps I should have researched a bit more (i.e. at all) before assuming this aquarium could fill a giant gap in my day in the city. It will do no such thing. 

1...1.5...2

thats how many exhibits there are to see. two moving walkway tunnel exhibits and a hands on area with rays, starfish, anemones, etc, as well as  a king snake (?), chinchilla (?), pigmy porcupine (? and i think...maybe it was a hedgehog i forget), bees (?), taranchula (?), frogs, and turtles all in glass enclosures as well. sorta random, but at least they filled the gap of marine life with something more.

:-|

and i mean, its fine. VERY much an attraction for the kiddies (we may have been the only above 10 yrs old, non-parent adults there), and they offer a lot of educational aspects. It was great to have the opportunity to see the bat rays and (forget the other kind) feeding and learn more about them. It was also nice to hear the reason they dont allow visitors to feed them (as you can at like sea world) is in order to perserve they natural instincts when they are released back into the wild. There is also a center area with a naturalist who provides education and games / activities.

its just....soooo small ;-( and even with coupon the adult pass is $15. im sorta kickin myself I didnt go to the exploratorium (same price) instead, which WOULD have filled the whole day. sigh...live and learn.

***We used a $2 off coupon you can find online along with other SF tourist activity coupons BUT

- Check in on foursquare at the California Visitor Center across the way and receive a coupon book that includes a $3 off each person coupon.
author: Heather W.

description:
Found tickets through the San Jose public library system. Anyone with a library card can print passes for 2 adults and 2 kids...

Good: it was free! Would have been very upset if I paid to get Ito this tiny aquarium.
It had a really cool tunnel (small) where sharks and other sea life swim around and over you- the kids really enjoyed this portion. Super friendly and knowledgable staff! 

Bad:  It was tiny, we planned a trip out to SF with about 8 kids and they were in and out of here within the hour. 

Ugly: Everyone was super nice, can't say anything negative about this place. If you're looking for a quick 30 min break on pier 39 check out this place for FREE only or you will be disappointed. This place is about 1/10 the size of Monterey Bay Aquarium- if you're going to make a drive check out MBA instead, similar prices and a much better EPIC aquarium experience!
author: Bea R.

description:
Small but pleasant.  We went because my son needed to look at marine life for his 10th grade marine biology class.

It's overpriced, but that is to be expected since it's on Pier 39 at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Adora M.

description: Aquarium is not big but it's very neat - the underwater tunnels are great, touching pools are fun and the newly opened otter exhibit is great. Jellyfish tanks were my favorite!  I got discounted tickets through Groupon and I feel like paying the full price would be kind of a lot.
author: Kasia G.

description:
I love aquariums. And I love this one. I read reviews that everyone thought that this place was small but to be honest, it was much bigger than I had anticipated. I came here 10 years ago and while I don't remember much about my trip overall, I do remember the awesome tunnel on the moving walkway with sharks overhead. 

The tickets were $16.95 per adult which could have been much worse in my opinion. Especially for a place like this which is such a tourist hot spot. Maybe I'm jaded and we spent a ton of money on everything else and comparatively, this didn't seem as bad...

Oh, and how can you NOT love jellyfish?
author: Sarah M.

description:
My husband decided to take me here 2 weeks ago and I'm not sure how I feel about it.
I've only been to one another aquarium, which was back home and wasn't too impressed. 

I'm glad I could say I visited here but the fact that it was super packed and ear piercing whining kids made this visit less than desirable.

I's say this place was a nice distraction for a weekend but wasn't worth my time or money. I definitely think the builders of the Bay Aquarium could have come out with something better.

I wouldn't recommend this place as an adequate attraction and it's a no go for me.
author: V W.

description: I would say it was great to finally come here after living in the Bay Area my whole life, and I loved the tunnels where you could see the fishes up-close, not to mention the moving walkway. Also, it was cool to be able to touch the starfish and stingrays. However, even with the LivingSocial price I got (full price would have been worse), I felt like it was too short of a tour and had a feeling at the end that was like "that's it?" Overall, it is nice to come here at least once in a life, but any more than that, perhaps not.
author: Char R.

description: Was fascinated at first, but got a bit bored. Not enough to see. was crowed, tight space. but was clean The staffs had knowledges, polite and nice.
author: Hye L.

description:
I brought my niece here for one of our regular "Auntie Days" and we both had such a great time. She was 2 at the time and the size of this aquarium is just perfect for that age! We spent just shy of 2 hours going through everything. She took her time in the tunnel and was just amazed by all the different types of fish (and that they were swimming above her). Petting pool was great and so were the activity tables around there - she had a conversation with the turtles, splashed around at the starfish and showed me how fast she could figure out the puzzles. It was a great day and hearing her say "wooooooow - look, auntie - it's fish! woooooooow"! as she passed the tunnel was worth the price of admission. 

I think if the aquarium were any larger, she probably would have gotten tired before we saw everything.  It wasn't too crowded inside the day we went and we ended our adventure with a visit to the gift store (she picked out a rotating flashlight thing that she still loves) and by making a "squish" penny as we left the building. 

Is it the most impressive aquarium out there? No, but would I take her back again?  ABSOLUTELY. I figure I could probably bring her back here for a few more years before she loses interest too fast and admission starts to seem not so worth the time spent inside. I'm looking forward to bringing her little sister when she's "a big girl" too!
author: Dawn L.

description: As far as aquariums go, this was marginal at best. There is a small room with tanks, a set of tunnels that run under large tanks, an exhibit where you get to touch rays and small sharks, and a river otter enclosure. It felt very small and we were through the whole thing, including walking through the two tunnels twice, in 25 minutes. I was left with the feeling that I'd missed at least half of the exhibits. My feelings were shared by others I overheard as we left. My family and I received a 50% discount for being members of the Oakland Zoo. Had we paid full price, $25/adult, I would have been severely disappointed.
author: Perry S.

description: I've been here twice this year when family from all over the world. Same girl at the welcome desk with great chancery service.  Bubbly personality and very  helpful.  Is great to see youth enjoying what they do and spreading joy.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Worst aquarium I've ever been too. I'm so glad we got free tickets for it because I would have been quite angry paying 20+ for tickets. 

The aquarium consists of two floors. One that had underground tunnels through small exhibits that consisted of star fish, small sharks and sea bass. The other floor had a few exhibits with touch tanks and otters as the finale. There wasn't really any learning stations along the way or a variety of exhibits. 

I'd recommend waiting for groupons or discounts for this place.... Not worth the full price. Then again, it's a non profit organization, so support your local agencies?
author: Jasmine N.

description: This is a wonderful aquarium!! Spent more than five hours. Great place to bring kids of any age. Also they have a cafe, gift shops, and also check their website for special nights where they sell gourmet tapas and wine/beer with live music band. It is a wonderful place and can't wait to return! Also use your student or corporate discounts to save about $15 per adult ticket.
author: R And J.

description: Love Aquariums, came here for some work training and thought an Aquarium by the bay would have a lot. Boy was I wrong this place is small and doesn't offer a lot. Picture/camera man was in a rush and very inpolite while there was no crowd/line. Aquarium needs to add more a lot more. Nice thing there was the large underwater tunnel.
author: Dustin H.

description: When I first walked in, I was disappointed on the size but since it was my first time to an aquarium, I enjoyed it. I would recommend it to first timers, but if you've already been to an aquarium you might not be impressed for the price ($20). The coolest part was being able to touch baby stingrays, they pop out of the water, it's so cute! They also have beautiful jelly fish, I wish that was a bigger display. Overall my experience was positive because I've never seen an aquarium but I would like to go to a different one next time.
author: Angela A.

description: A little small, but very informative staff. My 11 year old sister enjoyed it.... The tunnel is definitely the best part. However, petting the playful sting rays and tiger shark was fun as well. I would consider going here again.
author: Jessica S.

description: Fun! Awesome educational materials, big tanks with huge schools of fish, helpful and friendly staff. The tunnels are awe-inspiring and the river otters are too cute to miss! Decent little aquarium at the edge of Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I bought a City Pass and this place was included. Had I not bought A City Pass I would not have come here. This place is small. I mean really small. I waited for the elevator longer than I was in here. The jelly fish are cool, and all the starfish, plus you can pet some creatures. Very oriented toward very small children.

If you are going to the science museum in Golden Gate Park, skip this place. There are more fish at the science museum than at this aquarium....
author: Holly C.

description: This aquarium is perfect for five year olds, I suppose. It's extremely short (allowing for their attention spans?) and overpriced. This is kind of an embarrassment to San Francisco, is you ask me. Tourists come, and are underwhelmed. For us it was extremely crowded, I mean how many strollers can fit into that sea tunnel before it creates a fire hazard haha. Quality of exhibits wasn't that great, kind of shabby. The river otters were the coolest part but as others mentioned you can't help but feel bad for them, confined to a fairly small cage in a small white room. Basic aquarium, the animals were cool of course but they need a bigger budget to do them justice.
author: Alyssa C.

description: What a waste of $16 per person! Two levels of nothing special to see. Know wondering why it's unlimited entry all day because you can finish it within 20 minutes. The longest part was waiting for the elevator to down or up one level. Spend your money on food or clothing and watch the sea lions for free-- it's more entertaining.
author: Chris B.

description: Place is super small and not worth the price !! Staff was friendly but the exhibit is nothing to compare to Monterey bay
author: Jon P.

description:
I bought a city pass and obtained entry to the Bay Aquarium. For such a small aquarium, the regular price ($18) seems a little high to me. However, I thought it was amazing. The first area you walk into coming off the elevator houses the jellyfish. And I'm not going to lie, I kind of wanted to cry when I saw them because they were so absolutely beautiful. I probably could've stayed in this room for 30 minutes but decided to venture on fairly quickly since I got there as soon as they opened and didn't want to get stuck with a bunch of people around me. 

The next part of the aquarium is a large circular tank that surrounds a walkway and houses all kinds of life from sea stars, to octopuses and fish. The next surrounding tank had sharks, rays, and gigantic fish. They were all really cool. After that, you could "touch the bay" where you basically get to feel skates, sea stars, little sharks, etc. This was really cool and there were also some other animals in this area such as an opossum, snakes, turtles, slugs, etc. And then, just like that, it was over and I was kind of disappointed. My favorite part was definitely the jellyfish and made the whole experience worth it. I was just very surprised I got through the whole aquarium in roughly 45 minutes and I was taking my sweet time. 

As I was leaving, there were a LOT more people there so I recommend walking in the doors as soon as they open them. Great place to take the kids!
author: Meg W.

description: It's not as big as the Monterey Aquarium, but my 4 year old loves it here more than Monterey.  The walk through tanks are awesome. Great if you live in the city and need a place to spend half a day with little ones.
author: Regina T.

description: You've seen one aquarium, you've seen them all ... but daughter was really looking forward to It. It was really crowded esp during shark feeding but it was 4th of July weekend. Plus, my kids kind of rush through these things and don't take it all in. That's a lot of $ for rushing through.Try to go at a time when it's not so crowed.
author: Christie D.

description: Considering the location, it is a decent aquarium. The cost is reasonable, especially if you get a good deal. The aquarium itself is ok. The best part of the aquarium by far is the jelly fish. The variety is awesome. The water tunnel is good, but it can get crowded. Overall, the aquarium itself can get very crowded. Ultimately, there are better aquariums, but this one is a decent attraction for Pier 39.
author: Ron B.

description:
We were here on a Friday morning and had an excellent experience. I imagine all the folks who gave negative reviews about the crowds were probably here on weekends. People, places are crowded everywhere on weekends. And this is San Francisco, so don't expect sprawling real estate. I actually think they utilize the space really well across the three floors.

On Friday, there weren't not that many visitors. My small children (both under 4) could browse the exhibits at their pace. We loved all the exhibits they had -- the tanks, the overhead tunnels, the touch pools. The employees there are so friendly, in the elevators and by the touch pools, ready to answer questions and eager to engage with the children. We spent 2 hours there.
author: KP H.

description:
Disappointing, I appreciate their conservation messages, but the staff were uninformed, and rude. And a lot of exhibits needed work.  

Customer Service: 
One employee kept telling us to look at a fish, then when asked told us to find an education staff member. (poor customer service, since we only saw 3 employees on the floor the entire visit).  On the floor we thought there may be a pregnant animal, when asked the "naturalist/supervisor" was short with us with how that wasn't likely.  For an educational visit its not worth it, no staff looked liked they wanted to be there.  

Cost: Everything costs extra, which I understand they can get since they are a tourist attraction, but the lady at the picture booth got mad when I was on my phone and my party looked at the picture- you can't take a picture of their picture.  One small picture and frame was ~$22.  

Animals:  The plus side of it, lots of neat local animals.  I wished there was more signage for the jellies, and first few exhibits to know what we were looking at.  They also point out their octopus when you get there, but no one is in the tunnel to help you spot these camouflaging animals, so I'm sure many people miss them.

Overall, skip this place, and go see the aquarium in Monterey. If it's busy (which I imagine it is during summers/any holiday,weekend) I can't imagine how the facility would handle the crowds.
author: S S.

description: More of 3.5 for the maintenance and staff but taking out 1 and half stars for its redundancy and level of noise . If its your first ever time to an aquarium you might be spellbound by the variety of creatures in the aquarium. But having been to several aquariums around the country and outside I wasn't WOWED because there was nothing unique about this locations. It still is a decent place to catch sight of some animals which we cannot otherwise see. It is not that big so don't keep your hopes high. If you are around the area and would just want to catch a glimpse of sea creatures then stop by otherwise skip. Its a definite fun place for kids.
author: Geetha K.

description:
Just terrible. It was so overcrowded we couldn't see anything. Each room was filled with too many people, with floors divided by mandatory elevators without crowd control. You cant enjoy any of the rooms because there are too many people everywhere, half of which are waiting to get on the elevators or enter the next room. We sat on the elevator (after being transported to the next floor and the doors already opened) because there was not room to GET OFF THE ELEVATOR!  Fire code? The entire place is like this and was a sad experience for everyone. 

If the crowd wasn't an issue (I went on a weekend so I suggest going when they first open or on a weekday) it would still be a small, unimpressive aquarium not warrant of the $23 ticket price.  The ticket price is steep but in all, they sell too many tickets than they should allow and it was a nightmare.
author: David G.

description:
I had a really fun time on Pier 39 at the Aquarium of the Bay. They have great exhibits, have a level where you can actually touch sea creatures and it does a great job exemplifying the Bay Area marine life for tourists who want to enjoy some of the aquatic life by the pier. 

I wouldn't compare this aquarium to any large aquarium, such as Monterey Bay Aquarium and Long Beach Aquarium. The only turn-off I had about this aquarium is that in the case of an earthquake, I wouldn't know where to escape or how to get out of the congested and tight-packed establishment. 

Overall, I loved it though, I would recommend tourists checking it out and it was lovely seeing the aquatic life.
author: Jackie H.

description: How in the world does this place have so few stars - I would imagine cost and comparing it to Monterey or some other facility that includes an aquarium plus added exhibits for a similar price.  However, coupons are available for adults and kids too. Buy one get one free is the coupon we used. And locals (this meant Bay Area and not just SF) got an additional discount. My 5 year old loved it!  Hands on opportunities and the tunnels which to a young child is a lot of fun. Totally worth it!
author: K S.

description:
I was here like 2 years ago so my memory is not very good but overall, this place is great for kids and adults. We love sea creatures so we enjoy any aquarium and we don't expect it to be as good as Monterey Bay but for the locations, this is great to learn and appreciate living things.

I remember they have a travelator which guide/walk you under the glass to view the marine animals. There are many activities for kids to experience and have fun. Don'
t expect too much from a small place and it does get crowded at time so just have to wait in line longer. Do a search for discount online before you stand in line to get the tickets.
author: Sam M.

description:
PROS: fun for the kids,great shark exhibit, great jellyfish, fun tunnel with slow moving walkway, good opportunity to speak to staff about the fish and they are friendly, able to go more than once with the ticket stub for the day.

CONS: a bit pricey for the small aquarium.
author: SJ R.

description: Yes, this is a quick walk through attraction where you move through basically in a line of people. But it's still cool. Actually it's very nice if you are planning on doing other things that you can get through this fairly quickly. Yes, it's a little pricey for how quickly you go through but what do you expect of something on Pier 39? I visit this aquarium often and will continue to do so because I love the shark tunnel and to pet the leopard sharks & rays and so do my kids.
author: Roo P.

description:
Aquarium is a really good place to relax, you can experience so many activities, they have a lot of different species of sea animals, and I strongly recommend this place. I have been in other aquariums but this aquarium in fisherman wharf is something you won't forget.  Beside you can enjoy having a good time inside and outside of it.

5 stars for this awesome place.
author: Albert S.

description: What a great experience. It's a must for a quick thing to do on the piers. Reasonably priced and very clean and nice. My son loved it. We will defiantly be back.
author: Brian S.

description:
A nice little aquarium, but really good for the younger kiddos. It is not an all day adventure so they don't get overwhelmed and cranky.  The 7 yr old boy loved it!  The sea tunnel was fascinating to him - we walked through 3 times! And the exhibits with the bubble in the middle so the kids could put their heads in the exhibit were great!

We both loved the octopus, the otter training session and also seeing a hedgehog up close!

The "petting" portion of it was really fun, one of the tiny stingrays seemed to be saying hi to everyone as it swam around and even tried to splash people.  Quite entertaining.

For something I had looked upon with disdain as a cheesy tourist trap, it was surprisingly entertaining and educational.

I highly recommend it!
author: Rhonda H.

description: I can here with my boys and I got to tell u there's not to much to see.. The shark tunnel was amaizing  the highlight of the aquarium and that's where we were most of the time . I was rushing them so that we would see other things and next time u know it I was at the exit .. I think we when tru the whole place in like 30 mins .. So if ur kids are into sharks this is the place to be !
author: Adriana G.

description: Came here with the family on Christmas Eve. It's a cute little aquarium. It's not very big and there's not a ton of animals/sea creatures to see but there's a decent amount. It's only $22 per ticket which is a good price. Most aquariums are pretty expenses. Overall, we enjoyed it, just wish it was bigger and more to see.
author: Amanda L.

description: This placr at first was good customer service but after we got in we found out ourselves that there was a big school field trip and the experience was horrible didn't enjoy the aquarium at all, so much bad kids there they were not controlled and couldn't even see the fishes. They should of worn us about a field trip going on but today was sooo horrible!!!!!!!!
author: Mauricio R.

description:
HIGHLIGHTS:

Octopus!!!  
Petting pond - bat rays
Possum
Shark tunnel
school fish 
Giant sea bass
Jelly fish


OMG best aquarium ever. Can't believe I've never gone here before. It has everything. And it's in the middle of Pier 39 so you can make a whole day of it.
author: Angela L.

description: it was my first experience at an aquarium.. it was nice with lots of varieties of fish, sharks, jelly fish, sting rays
author: Ameeta M.

description:
I love marine life and aquariums so I had a nice time at the Aquarium of the Bay.

The big highlight is the tube through their 700,000 gallon tank.  I also think it's cool that they feature all bay area animals.

It is a bit small, so it really doesn't take all day to go through everything...but its at Pier 39 so you can take a look at the sea lions and shops after!

(btw, parking prices at the pier are INSANE.  I think it was like $7 bucks an hour.  Geez)
author: Jennifer A.

description: Brought my family here to start off our family vacation. Great little aquarium. It could be a little bigger but the exhibitors at the stations were great. Awesome guest services staff. We were greeted by everyone including administrative staff walking through the facility. I would recommend this aquarium to anyone visiting SF.
author: Jane H.

description:
I have been here a few times now, both with and without children.
If you've been to Monterey Bay you will be slightly disappointed, this aquarium is quite small and you can easily tour it all in less than an hour. 
The touch pools are pretty cool, you get to touch a sting ray and leopard shark and a few other things.
The octopus is pretty cool too.
If you are in the area and have a spare hour it's worth a look
author: sarah s.

description: We became members before viewing the aquarium, thinking it might be a smaller version of the Monterey Bay Aquarium.  All in all, not a bad place.  Definitely a small aquarium and can be done in less than an hour, unless you take in a behind the scenes tour or a movie in their theater.  The gidgets were thrilled with the underwater walking tubes that allowed you to view sharks and other marine life and even enjoyed the petting area (although the petting area was similar to the ones in Marine World.  Definitely a nice family orientated stop for a day in the City.
author: Michele P.

description:
Clearly its not Monterey, but then again what is?

This is a nice aquarium with some cool exhibits and neat moving sidewalks where you get to ride through tunnels in the fish tanks and come face to face with sharks, rays and other fish. There's also an area where you can actually pet the sharks and starfish.

It's a little pricey so you may want to look for discounts. We saved money because we have a membership at the Arizona Science Center and I believe there's also a discount for AAA members.
author: Brad H.

description:
I thought the Aquarium was pretty good. The underwater tube is really cool; my daughter thoroughly enjoyed that part. Overall it's a little small compared to other aquariums, but I kind of expected that so I wasn't dissapointed.

I will say that being required to wait for the elevators on each floor was ridiculous. There needs to be a better option. I don't know why the stairs are emergency exits only. We were there in February; I can't imagine how crowded it gets in front of the elevators during the high season.
author: Zachary C.

description:
It must be hard to run an aquarium or a zoo. Balancing out admission prices with the tough economy all while trying to have enough programs and animals to keep everybody (including the aquarium inhabitants) happy. Well ... Aquarium of the Bay needs some help. 

The admission price was a bit of a sticker shock but on a sunny day in San Francisco, I felt like doing something totally touristy and who doesn't like staring at enchanting aquamarine life? Their tube is a pretty awesome design. The conveyor belt was off but you could walk through and feel surrounded by swimming tiger sharks and starfish happily plastered on the glass. Granted the tranquil aesthetic of the place couldn't compete with the many screaming kids underfoot. I know, I know, it's an aquarium. 

But really, this place is super tiny. I think their multiple gift shops combined had more things to see than actual exhibits. At the end, there was a petting portion, poor starfish and stingrays getting poked and jabbed by little fingers. The weird part was that they had a bunch of non-water related land animals. Like chinchillas and snakes. Er ... why? 

The jellyfish at the beginning were chillingly bad arse though, check out the pic!
author: Faith Y.

description:
Most of you may not know but I am a wannabe Mermaid.  While this aquarium doesn't make me want to flip my fins like Monterey Bay Aquarium does.  It does work for a quick Mermaid fix.

Its small and kind of cramped feeling.  While in the underwater tubes I had moments of just wanting to run out because no one was paying attention and just stepping all over each other.  

It drove me nuts and I don't think I got the full underwater tube experience.

Also, there is not enough bathrooms throughout the building either.  I had to walk all the way to the end to go pee then had to walk back to where my brother was waiting.

The Jelly Fish display is small and the Jelly's are not as colorful as the ones in Monterey either.

The touch pools were probably my favorite.  The rays seemed less stressed than the ones in Monterey also.  I got to pet one little one.  They're so slimy!

I petted the Starfish and a Sea Cucumber.  Sea Cucumbers are not as squishy as I would think.  And the Starfish they have are giant!  You cant pick them up though.  I snuck an arm up but my brother scolded me and told me not to do that.

There is also a hive of Bee's on display.  Both sides are encased in glass and you can see them all busily working in there.  I really, really liked that one.

We also got to check out some Chinchillas.  I'm going to get one of these as a pet some day.  There is one that is all gray but has hairless pale pink ears.  Its one of the cutest little creatures ever.  Like a furry little gremlin.

If you are being a Ham & Egger at the wharf along with all the other Ham & Egger's this is the one thing I highly recommend checking out.
author: Ivy R.

description: This is a small museum.  The exhibits are well put together, staff is friendly, and it's great for kids. BUT, it's really expensive.  Be prepared to spend a lot for a short-lived experience.
author: Julie B.

description: Went to the aquarium as part of the City Pass.  Probably wouldn't go back as it's not worth the money really.  The 2 Sea Bass were massive.  Apart from that not much of a wow factor.
author: Timmy R.

description:
