I've always wanted to come here since I go to pier 39 quite a few times and always pass by the ticket office but the price has always put me off especially since I never knew how big the place really was. Sister got a groupon here that let our family go in for way cheaper so we decided to go last weekend.

Nice sunny day in SF. A bit windy but not too unmanageable! It was nice.

Got inside the entrance and waited behind one family with a stroller to enter... not a good first impression because there were three employees and I was waiting there with our tickets so we could get them looked at and enter. One looked up and saw me but made no move or greeting towards me. I HATE that kind of thing so I just moved forwards and held up my ticket and said that we were here and here were our tickets. I waited patiently and isn't this the kind of training that employees go through? Sheesh.

It was cool going through the entrance I guess kind of. A small-ish room with some fish and etc. in small tanks. You pass this photo opp. where you can get your photo taken and the background will be photoshopped in as part of the ocean or something. Then you wait in line for the elevators that will take you downstairs. The employee girl was nice who took us in and out of the elevator though.

The next part was pretty cool! My favorite part. They have these underwater tunnels that you can walk through with fish and sharks and turtles and manta rays and starfish that you can look at. It was pretty awesome. There were some annoying people there too but can't help that. 

There was even an octopus tank but it was pretty small... I would have thought it'd be bigger. The cool part of the tank was that there was this small crawl space underneath and it had a part where you could put your head in a dome shape that was in the tank. You couldn't even see the octopus which sucked but I found it in the very back of the tank hidden underneath some of the plants. I don't blame it wanting to hide away from people haha.

Then you had to take the elevator again up which led to the small touching pools! This part was also pretty cool!! There was a small pool where there were baby sharks and baby manta rays. You were allowed to touch them as long as you touched them in the correct spots and an employee was there to remind everyone where with a sign and a microphone. Some of the people were annoying because a lot of them were with small kids who just kept splashing against the water and sharing the animals. Or there were people who could follow an animal a bit and shove against others. Besides that, it was fun to watch the animals go so close to you and that you could touch them. One small manta ray was super playful, sticking super close to the sides and coming up out of the water to sort of wave hi to you!! So cute.

The gift shop was a small room not too impressive. Bathrooms were clean but not too big. Overall, I feel like employees could have been way more friendlier and welcoming. The nicest employee was the one on the elevator who was kind of short with dark curly hair so good for her! The others could work on that. 

I would recommend not going UNLESS you would never go to the Monteray Bay Aquarium (waaay more worth it. This place is about $18 for an adult I think and the Monteray Bay Aquarium is about $30.. expensive but it's 5x the size of this place and has way more interesting and fun exhibits- even though the underwater tunnels were awesome) or if you have $$ to spend.
author: Samy L.

description: The aquarium staff are awesome. So nice and helpful.  The aquarium is beautiful but way too small and expensive to visit considering its size.  The kids did have fun looking at the fish, the sea otters and the hands on exhibits.
author: Vanessa A.

description:
I AM AN AQUATIC ENTHUSIAST. :)
More like a marine reef keeper. This place is the anemone heaven. WOW. The big tank at the entrance to the aquarium is breath taking. A great first date place. Much to see, but not too much. 

Many places to charge your electronics.
author: Eve K.

description:
We went to see the new North American River Otter display and were a little disappointed.  There are only three otters, and they seem to sleep a lot.  While we were there they were note really active.

That said, the Aquarium is decent overall. The jellyfish display is really nice.  The 2 tubes with the larger and smaller fish and sharks is pretty cool.  The really tried to make it look like you were at the bottom of the SF Bay.

I think it is a fairly nice addition to Pier 39, but don't go there thinking its like the Monterey Bay Aquarium, because its not.
author: Stewart B.

description:
The aquarium was a bit on the smaller side. It was fun to kill a bit of time with but the regular admission price of $18 is high for size of the aquarium and its exhibits. They did have very cool underwater viewing tunnels for you to go through though. That was a whole different experience. 

It's something to see if you happen to be wandering around Pier 39 but I've seen way better aquariums. In fact the one at the California Academy of Sciences is actually much better and there's so much more to see there for like $5 more.
author: Jackie T.

description:
3 starfishes out of 5

This aquarium is small. And I might be a little harsh on this place since I'm a marine animal nut. I love aquariums but this one simply does not have a wow factor that other aquariums present. I took my girlfriend here on a date before but before we knew it, it was over. We probably spent less than an hour there. I love the animals there but there just wasn't that many to begin with, partly due to the size of the place. If you want to go to an aquarium with a wow factor, make an investment of your time to go to Monterey. That place has a fantastic aquarium that is bigger with more selection of wild life. Honestly, this place is best when you take kids to see marine animals. There are ton of kids there. This is NOT a good place to go with friends and such. Maybe a little date but you better be sure to take your date somewhere else afterwards because you'll probably spend an hour or less there. Overall not bad but definitely not good. Just.. Mediocre.
author: Chris K.

description: Always nice to come here when in SF. Love the tunnel where you can watch the fish swim over you. It is a small aquarium though and a bit pricey since it is a quick walk through... but is also a nice touch to add to a days itinerary in the city!
author: Erika C.

description:
Went to the SF Aquarium for the first time today.
$16 for adults,10 for seniors.
The place is way smaller than the Monterey Bay Aquarium.You can spend a good few hours there.We were in and out of here within half an hour or so.

The one kickass exhibit here is the underground tunnels in which fish,sharks,starfish and whatever else is under there can swim next to or above you.
This place is a big tourist trap,though,and is filled with them.Or,at least,it was today.
Rude ass people too who push you out of the way so their Little Jimmys can get a picture next to the [enter random wildlife in aquarium here].
author: Mike M.

description: I visited with my husband- we loved it! A great place to take our tourist friends when they are in town. It's a small aquarium, but a lot is packed into the small space!
author: Steph P.

description:
How does one rate an aquarium?  I just don't know.  But I am going based on my experience.

I felt the price was pricey ($18 for an adult) yet then again, I live in Sacramento, and this is San Fran.... and have nothing to compare it to except the Sac/SF Zoo, which is about $8-$10 in Sac and around $15 for SF.  I am sure that the cost is adjusted based on location being right along the Embarcadero, as well.

Staff is friendly, helpful, and never short handed.

The exhibits are awesome!  There was a room of Jellyfish, the tunnel where you could see sea stars, sharks, sardines, sea bass, etc.  There was also an area where you can touch/pet a skate, sting ray, leopard shark, sea anemone, sea cucumber, and star fish.  

As much as I enjoyed the experience, I however did feel bad for the animals constantly being poked and prodded by us as spectators.  There was adequate staffing amongst the tanks where the creatures could be pet, but given the large amount of young children who disobeyed the rules, I felt bad for the treatment of the animals in captivity.  Maybe that's me being too much of a hippy!  

The Aquarium is quite nice but a little expensive for the number of exhibits.  However, given it's location I think that the price is justified. 

They should also maybe offer ear plugs for adults who don't like listening to screaming children.  It's probably a good place to bring your kids if you can tolerate screaming children or yours like to scream and be annoying.  If you're an adult who doesn't like screaming kids, maybe this isn't the right place for you!
author: Jenna B.

description: Had a lot of fun with the family. Its a small aquarium so don't expect too much of it.
author: Jackie R.

description:
I was surprised to have liked this place given the mixture of reviews.  I have to agree the entry price does seem quite steep for the limited space and time.  We were in and out, having seen everything, within probably 45 minutes max.  We could have gone back in throughout the day to see some of their feedings or talks, but it's kind of a one time through thing.  

The exhibits could have more information.  In fact the first room you enter, there are some tanks that have nothing that I could see written about the types of fish, habitats, etc.  There were also limited staff around and those that were available seemed to have a pre-defined role and almost reading off a cue card.

It's true that this certainly isn't Monterey, Chicago or Boston when it comes to over-the-top aquariums...I don't think they are trying to convince you of that.  I do agree with the reviewer who suggested heading out to the California Academy of Sciences probably for the same or less.
author: Ryan O.

description:
I had really low expectations for this place, but my husband really wanted to go. And I have to say, I enjoyed it. Even as an adult with no kids. If you have kids, they'll love it. And if you don't have kids but enjoy science, you'll also love it. And it only took about 2 hours to see the whole thing.

CAUTION: When we arrived, we were thirsty and tried to buy bottled water. But you can't. Because they're an environmentally-conscious organization. So they'll sell you a refillable canteen for $20 or you can use a water fountain on the other side of the museum. Alas. Lesson: bring your own water.

Other than that the aquarium was great. We really liked the jellyfish exhibit. The other main section of the aquarium was a moving sidewalk that you ride through a tube filled with sharks, star fish, and other aquatic life. This is a fantastic idea because it keeps little kiddies and big adults from constantly bumping into each other while looking at the fish. 

As far as kids go, it's packed with them, but we managed to get good shots without kids photo bombing our pictures.

Have lunch at Boudin Bakery, which is at the head of Pier 39, right by the Aquarium. Have the sourdough bowl with clam chowder. But go after 1pm, or it's really crowded.
author: Mrs G.

description: We really loved this aquarium! The glass tunnels were incredible and the touch pools for the kids were great. The glass tunnels had a conveyor that you stand on which made viewing easy. The river otter exhibit was beautiful. The best part was there were not that many people there at noon on a Saturday and you can enter and exit all day.
author: Kevin S.

description: I found this aquarium to be just as enjoyable (and cheaper) than Monterey Bay.  It's close to home and my 4 yr old loves it.  We really enjoyed the newer otter exhibit and he always loves the tide pools.  On the smaller side, but just right for younger children.
author: Austin S.

description: If you plan to go here, you should look up deals on groupon! I saved a lot of money using groupon! This place is a great time if you're planning on visiting pier 39. I'd recommend going, the facility is really clean and the otters are so adorable. Why wouldn't you want to go?!
author: Zohal S.

description: I expected more than what they have here, it was fun tho. They have 3 stories. I'm guessing you can't go back downstairs. Saw sharks, stingrays, bunch of fishies, jelly fish ! And you can touch the baby leopard sharks and baby sting rays ! 1 finger only, bunch of star fish ! They feel so weird to me but cute haha. The admission is pricy $21.95 but hey once in a while it's fine, take a stroll and enjoy what they have :)
author: R F.

description:
This aquarium isn't that big and when I got to the end I felt like, "Is that it?" The highlight is the open pond where you get to pet the rays, starfish, etc. And that's really why I'm giving it three stars instead of two.

However, this place would be perfect if I had children. It's big enough to captivate them and for them to pet the sea critters, but probably small enough to get out before they have a meltdown.
author: Zenovia E.

description:
I wouldn't have paid the $16.95 admission fee, but we found some tickets on Travelzoo for $8 a ticket.  My favorite exhibit was the jellyfish-they're mesmerizing!  
After getting past the initial claustrophobia of being trapped under water with no way out, I was able to enjoy the two tunnels.  Both tunnels have moving walkways which prevents the tunnel from getting over-crowded. The first tunnel has starfish and other large fish, and the second tunnel has stingrays and small sharks.  We actually got to see the scuba divers feeding the sharks which was pretty cool.  The last exhibit has shallow pools so the kids can pet starfish, stingrays, etc..
I don't think I would come back because in general this area is too crowded, but it was a nice experience.
author: anne m.

description: The underwater tunnel is amazing and Trippy and unlike any other aquarium. Great for kids or people of all ages.
author: Arielle B.

description: Great place to take the kids, even if they are teenagers! Lots to see and learn, great hand-on opportunity!
author: Karen C.

description: I give this place 5 star because of the awesome friendly staff.  The little ones had fun and staff was very kid friendly. There's not much to see. But after a long day of walking with three children age 8, 6, and 2. The staff made it inviting for the kids to forget their feet and tired legs.
author: Mydua H.

description:
Completely missable.  I'm not entirely sure that we spent more than an hour there, and much of that was trying to find our way out of giftshop after giftshop.  Plus, they have a magic show that you can pay for too - wait, what? A magic show aquarium?  I'm good, thanks.

I think the major highlight was watching a video of an octopus go through an obstacle course.  Really, I need to go to an aquarium to watch an octopus video?  

I can say, though, that for being a dive of an aquarium (whoops, bad pun!) that the staff there were incredibly cheerful and upbeat.  It's a shame that the exhibits weren't much to look at.
author: Angela G.

description:
The bf was able to get really cheap tickets ($8 per person) for the Aquarium of the Bay so we decided to spend Easter Sunday checking out the fishies. It was raining a lot so I was surprised not more people were crowding into the aquarium but I guess most people decided to stay at home all together. The Aquarium is located right at the beginning of Pier 39 and its bigger than you think it is when you look at it from the outside. There are three stories of marine fun to be had and the staff are well trained and very helpful when answering questions and helping visitors. If you take the escalator up you'll walk through a gift shop first, then outside again and then enter the aquarium where you'll be greeted by a staffer. The place bottle necks in some areas so it gets a bit crowded at times but usually clears out pretty quickly. 

The elevators are manned by a staffer who tells you a little about the next exhibit you're going to see and answers any questions people may have. It was a great experience because you felt like you were being very well taken care of and attended to. I really liked the jellies exhibit and the touch pools. I can't see how some people could rush through the place so quickly. The Bf and I spent almost 3 hours enjoying the aquarium. True we went through it a couple of times but that's because there was so much to see we missed it the first couple of times we went through!

After the bf and I had gone through the whole place once we wanted to go back and see the octopuses which we missed. We happened to say this in front of the elevator girl who called another staffer to come meet us at the elevator and show us the octopus. He was a very personable and knowledgeable guy and gave us a mini personal tour. I was impressed with how well the visitors were treated and would definitely go back.
author: Joie P.

description:
Having signed up to take a sunset cruise of the bay, my husband and I took the MUNI over to Pier 39 a little early so we could do our one and only touristy stop at the pier. It was a good thing we left early since the MUNI took us more than a couple minutes to figure out and head in the correct direction... we are prepared for the next time we have to use it, though!

Anyways, there are only so many corn dogs and ice creams a person can eat and we didn't want to look like creepers on the carousel, so we moseyed our way over to the aquarium. Everyone was really nice and available if you needed them but did not hover, which is always a good thing. I loved that they had the glass tunnels with native sharks and schools of fish swimming overhead. The tanks of jellyfish were breathtaking and the hands-on areas were great, I couldn't help but touch a starfish or two.

This aquarium is the perfect spot to come in from the blustery air, learn something new and relax while enjoying some truly beautiful creatures. Definitely recommend to families or anyone who can appreciate a nice aquarium that has enough to boggle your mind, but won't send you or any loved ones on a death march.
author: Josephine S.

description:
My husband had gone here on a private tour with the gang from the Exploratorium , so when tickets came up on Travel Zoo he insisted I buy them.  Solid 3 stars.

The good:
Giant red octopus put on quite the show for us. He Cthulhu-ed out all over the tank and showed off his camo- abilities.  I could have watched him for hours.
Jellies-  I adore jellyfish.  This by no means is in the same league as the Monterey Aquarium, but then it is not a 2 hour drive either.
Moving pathway-- keeps people from stagnating in one spot.

The meh:
The displays were rather underwhelming.  The animals were active and well taken care of which made me happy, but would it hurt you to add a little more kelp to the tanks?  It is native to the Bay Area you know.

Pier 39.  Need I say more.  Lots of tourists and kids and strollers.

More staff required.  People behaving badly around the octopus and jellies.  Pounding on the tanks, taking flash photos, etc.

18 bucks to get in?  Are you kidding me?  If it weren't for the elevator wait (which is not an option) the whole aquarium will take less than 40 minutes to go through.  Except if you hang with the octopus.

I would probably go again if nothing else to see the octopus.
author: Monika S.

description: Not absolutely amazing aquarium but still enjoyable with a very knowledgeable staff. You are able to touch the batt rays and sharks which i believe made the experience much better. The price is around 20 adults who are non locals. Length is about An hour long average
author: Carlos M.

description:
This place isn't cheap with Adults  $16.95 and Children (3-11)  $8.00, but this place is small. I came here during their Free Days for San Francisco Residents. I was able to walk most of upstairs right upon entering in less than 5 minutes, looking at displays.

Downstairs is just the jelly fishes and the two glass tunnels. After taking the elevator back up, it is a short walk to the feeding tank and the star 
fishes, then back to the store. 

Coming here for that price, the whole family really must love fish.
author: M C.

description: This place looks much bigger on the outside than it really is inside. Don't get me wrong this is a great aquarium but I was just expecting it to be bigger. I'd actually give it 3 1/2 stars
author: Janel B.

description:
As aquariums go it was decent...  but considering this aquarium is in San Francisco and right on the bay I was expecting more exotic sea creatures and more advanced exhibits...  It was almost an identical experience to the Seattle aquarium which is nowhere near the actual ocean but still has random Puget Sound sea creatures swimming in and out of open water exhibits...

-1 star for 16.95 price tag
-1 star for cheesy $20 photo
-1 star for lack of ah inspiring exhibits

If you can find a deal its worth checking out...  I saw a review where someone got tickets for $8.  At $8 it would be a 3.5 to 4 star experience.  But double that price raises my level of expectations to the point that I was left disappointed.
author: Antoine V.

description: My wife and I have been to monterray aquarium and to the aquarium in golden gate park. We weren't exoecting alot BUT...we were pleasantly surprised. Has a touch pool for everyone with baby manta rays and sharks,Great fun. Also the tunnels through the aquirium were fantastic. We were able to stop and spend alot of time watching various sharks and fish. Other exhibits where jellyfish otters and tropical tanks. Good value for money. If u can get a coupon book from pier 39 information booth upstsirs saves you 4 dollers per person.. GREAT FOR FAMILYS WITH ALOT OF INTERACTIVE DISPLAYS.my wife is a 2nd grade teacher. Definatly worth seeing thid if you have an extra hr or so.
author: Simon H.

description:
I went with my two grandsons, age 4 and five, yesterday to the Aquarium.  I live in Oakland but my grandchildren live in Alameda and Santa Cruz.  That in itself could have been a deterrent for going to the aquarium, but we made it into an adventure. We took Bart and the "F" tram in order to get to the aquarium which was easy and exciting for the kids who are usually buckled into their car seats. The boys were excited when they saw some of the signage to the aquarium, marketing answered their question as to whether or not they would see some sharks.
The tram took us right to the front door of the aquarium.  Entry was exciting in itself. They wanted to stop in the store, but we let them know that would be available to them on the exit from the establishment as well. We had arrived around 11 and had an hour before the shark feeding, which all of us agreed we want to see. Their first favorite was the "trash in the bay" tank exhibit. I asked them, "which of these things don't belong with the fish in the tank?"they loved identifying all the things that they knew about which didn't belong with fish. We found right away that the tanks were easily viewed by four-year-olds, very accessible, and there was such variety in each display area that they each could yell-out to the other what they were seeing and excited about. Because they were so excited and the aquarium was set up in a large circle they ran through the aquarium wanting to see each thing ( jellyfish, touch tanks, sharks, and otters) in an hour. We then asked them "what was your favorite?" And went back again for a second round seeing the things they like the most. One of my grandchildren loved the otters and the other the touch-tanks so we did those things one more time. With our hands stamped for entry in and out, we left for a quick lunch and then back for the 3-D movie.  I highly recommend the aquarium as a place to find educational material, entertainment, and diversity for all ages. My favorite were the jellyfish. I'm sure we will be back again.
author: Bea Y.

description:
It's a baby aquarium, that's for sure, but it has one of the best touch pools!

If you are looking for a big, Monterrey Bay Aquarium experience, you are in for some disappoint.  As I stated, it has a very small foot print but some great ambiance.

The shark tunnel is nice and soothing and the jelly fish display is super pretty.  As of now, they currently have a very awesome octopus on display as well as some incredibly adorable river otters!

I will say, I do think it is a bit pricey for the amount of aquarium you get ($20 per adult), but if you take your time through the place you can make it worth your while. 

I suggest going during a slow season, one so you don't have to fight tourists on the pier or children for the touch pool.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
"Truly a Locals Aquarium..." This is the quote by the CEO from the Bay Institute, the non-profit organization that is now partnered with the Aquarium of the Bay. 

I was able to take advantage of the Free admission event for San Francisco residents this past week.  I'm glad I did-- For the quote above really proves just how "Local" the aquarium is.  

What's special about our Aquarium of the Bay is that it houses thousands of local creatures of the Bay, that many of us locals are unaware of.  

Their purpose is to shine light on conservation of these creatures and our Bay and surrounding areas as a whole.  So for those looking for those tropical colorful fishies, you aren't going to see those here.  These ones are specific to our Bay. 

So yes, while the Monterey Bay Aquarium is much larger, and has far more exhibits, the Aquarium of the Bay is for those seeking to learn about native marine life here in our own region.  

As a local gal--b o r n  and  r a i s e d--that's enough for me to love this place.  

My few of my favorite exhibits are the 2 Underwater Tunnels. The first tunnel showcasing creatures close to the surface of the ocean  And the second tunnel showing creatures living deeper in the ocean.  Both tunnels were awesome and were well-air conditioned.  

Another favorite of mine was the Touch the Bay exhibit where guests can get up close and personal with various sea-life.  In one of the pools, you can touch the bat-rays and skates and even a tiny tiger shark.  

But it was this one cute bat-ray that was stealing the show from the others as he continuously kept peeping his head out of the water to say hello to everyone.  
So   C U T E ! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P6X9hff8GAqNHJjhyr0ENQ?select=WUvRD0UQSORyUJ-ivFxQ7A
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/P6X9hff8GAqNHJjhyr0ENQ?select=nKDXMLJzUbEeqgjK3aRFoQ

Overall, I spent a great 2 hours spent here at the Aquarium of the Bay for free.  But despite being smaller than a lot of other Aquariums, the regular admission of $15.95 Adult rate is a well worth experience for those seeking a little education about the great San Francisco Bay!
author: Cass J.

description: it was a cute little aquarium that had exciting jellyfish, sharks, sting rays (baby ones that you could touch), blue tongue lizard, and river otters . . . however, for the amount of $$$ and the amount of time that you're actually in there observing the animals doesn't seem worth it for me to ever go again.
author: Brooke W.

description:
Okay, I'm a little late in posting this review. Admission is FREE this week (Jan. 4th-7th) for SF residents (just show ID) and today is the last day. Sorry! They close at 6pm today so there's still time if you go now. Go!!

I went on Monday around 5pm. Normally you'd buy a ticket at the booth, but for this week's offer just go up the stairs, show your ID at the desk, get your hand stamped, and just follow the path like a Disney ride.

The entire setup is just an elevator that takes you to the underwater tubes (2 tunnel sections - near shore fish + deep water fish - take as much time as u want) and later brings you back up to see the interactive exhibit. The exit is by the gift store.

Great place for frustrated fishermen, so you can see all the fish that you never caught. LOL!

Also great for kids. Nice for foodies too - you get to see many of the species we get to eat: yellowtail, salmon, sea bass, rockcod (don't miss the giant rockcod!), perch, skates, sturgeons (caviar, yum!), octopus, etc. Plus sharks, rays, jellyfish, frogs, bees, tarantulas, and many others.

A fair rating would probably be 3-stars, but added an extra star for the nice and friendly staff. I took a lot of pics but most are blurred. *sad face*

I'll upload the non-blurred pics later, when I'm less ashamed of my poor photographic skills.
author: Luis C.

description:
This place felt kinda small, run down, and old. Someone suggests going to the Monterey Aquarium instead. 

But its also youve seen one aquarium youve seen most. I was hoping to see some nice great one since its SF. But no. I guess I will have to check out the one in Monterey.

The neat thing about it is that glass/plastic corridor were you go through the water and can see the fish swimming around you.

Id say skip it. Save your money.
author: Frank M.

description: I am glad I didn't pay $16/head to go here. Took about 30 minutes to walk through all three floors. Overall it is a decent aquarium but it needs a lot more.
author: Kien M.

description:
This was probably the worst aquarium we have ever been at. It had VERY few attractions, and was not easy to navigate at all. We probably spent 20-30 minutes just trying to figure out how to get from one place to another and then deciding that we had actually seen everything there was to be seen.

It is pretty much 30% gift shop, 30% theater (which costs extra, even on top of the overpriced general admission), 15% aquarium, 10% TV monitors, 10% playground,  and 5% over hyped advertisements.

The only cool thing this place had to offer was a huge tank that was on both sides and over top of you, You viewed from a moving walkway, so you didn't get to take much of it in. However, considering this was the only thing worth seeing at the aquarium, it where everyone was. So without the moving walkway, you won't even get to see anything anyway for all of the people. You have to take the elevator all the way down to get there.
author: Kurt C.

description: Really cute aquarium, love the fact that it's by the main piers. Not your average aquarium, there's different levels that you take to see different species. The jelly fish room was by far my favorite, it's glow in the dark black lighted ! The huge tank when going through the shark & fish tank was gorgeous. You can touch starfish, Sharks, & stingrays also! 20$ to get in, cute gift shop, also has a kid play area.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
My wife and I went here because it was included our CityPass. So why not take a look and see how it goes. The verdict: pretty nice and decent. It wasn't stellar, but it wasn't terrible either.  It's a nice few hours at an aquarium and certainly there are better ones, but they do have some nice exhibits and friendly staff.

Their jellyfish tank is small, but very beautiful to watch them, the underwater tunnels are enjoyable and educational if you take the time to stop a staffer to chat, and lastly the petting tank is a very cool attraction. Get your hands wet by petting star fish, sea cucumber, and other sea life.

The place is small and sometimes tight quarters, so be careful if you're claustrophobic. Otherwise, have a great time.
author: Randy G.

description: Like the last reviewer, I was appalled at the conditions the otters were in! There were no toys to be found anywhere, and the screaming and glass licking from the one otter was terrible. Anyone who knows anything about animals could tell that they were stressed out. There also wasn't really a place they could hide from the public, as the enclosure is all glass - who would design this? Definitely not supporting this place again until they start treating their animals right - and telling my friends not to, either.
author: Nicole Z.

description: This place is small and kind of pricey for its size compared to bigger attractions like Monterey Bay Aquarium. If you're a local, show your ID and ask for the local price. That should save you a few bucks. Once inside there are 2 levels of aquariums and one petting floor. The main attraction is the underwater tunnel. This is where everyone goes and can get quite crowded as most people take pictures. You can easily finish seeing everything in less than an hour. 2-stars for its price and size.
author: Bill C.

description: This is definitely a smaller aquarium than normal but I loved it. Don't expect to go in there seeing miles of tanks and everything else. We paid to do the behind the scenes and it was worth it. Being able to see how the animals are cared for and how and why they are being researched was great information. We came out learning more than ever. Inside they do multiple interactions with different exhibits so there's always something new to learn.
author: Virginia F.

description:
We took 18 Girl Scouts (Brownies) and 12 adults to the Aquarium for a sleepover on Saturday, and the experience was outstanding!  The staff was helpful, engaged, and provided a perfect experience for the girls; full of information and fun facts, very patient and sweet.  Two of their teachers actually slept over too, in case the girls needed help during the night.  We had our choice of sleeping areas (most girls slept in the tunnel under the sharks) and they even provided Amici's Pizza for a late night snack and Boudin pastries plus fruit for breakfast.  I'm hoping to do this again next year.  Thank you Mayra and the rest of the staff!!!!
P.S. Also, they just added and/or upgraded the front section, and it looks amazing.
author: Laura B.

description: Yes, this is a small aquarium. However, it is only $20 dollars for "locals", so I think it is well worth the price. The tunnel is super cool, and they have many other nice displays. I wish there was more education information. I definitely would recommend going once or twice.
author: Channing M.

description: Small and overpriced but it wasn't crowded which was nice. My bf and I walked through pretty quickly but I did get some great pictures of sea life.
author: Nadia G.

description: Completely overpriced - takes 20 minutes to see the entire display!  I would strongly recommend saving your money.  This is one of the worst Aquariums I have ever been to.  A complete and total disappointment!  Come on San Francisco, invest some money to make this attraction worth the ridiculous price charged!
author: Marilyn N.

description: We liked this place. A little expensive and hoaky at times, but the animals were neat and we got some really nice pictures. The highlight though, was when we were leaving, there was a GIANT pelican sitting outside just chilln' with a large crowd gathered around taking pictures and feeding it. The pelican loved it. It was pretty funny!
author: Dean S.

description: We had a blast!  Wish that the New England Aquarium would do a tunnel like this! Staff was super helpful with everything from questions about the exhibits, to the gift shop! Will absolutely do this again next time we head to S.F.!
author: Dina H.

description:
If you can get in with a 2 for the price of 1 deal I'd say it's a decent time but for any cost over that you'll likely be disappointed unless this is your first aquarium.

The jellyfish exhibit, touch pool, and "shark" tube were a decent size for a touristy aquarium on the pier. I grew up visiting So Cal tide pools and Seaworld every weekend so I'm really spoiled on the aquarium and sting-ray petting front but this was a decent reminder of all the good times I used to have.
author: Krystle S.

description:
Birthday treat for me I got my free pass from Discover and Go through a partnership between Museums and the Oakland Public Library.

I became aware of what fascinating beings living in the Bay. I did not know. It was breathtaking and beautiful and amazing this sea animals and bugs are able to live in such a polluted environment.

It was an intense experience I admit I was sorta afraid of them they look so bizarre and alien looking. I eat some of this things. They look so much different in a can or on a plate.

There was a very talkative and helpful Docent who was walking through offering info.

My low expectations were blown apart this museum is fun and inviting. I could've stayed for hours I wandered in there for 2 hours however noisy annoying running kids chased me away.

The anchovies, the sea stars, sharks, bass, rays was a feast for me I was able to touch and watch them

Ooo and the Chinchillas are super cuteeeeee!!!!!!!!!!

Being moved by elevators to access floors was different and fun.

And the last exhibit was back on dry land with chincillas, lizards, snakes, frogs, and bees. Mmm the beehive was smelly. This was a very surprising Museum I will be back it was fun.

Yes I fell for the gimmick a($20 for 2 small pics different backgrounds and a nice S.F trolly frame) and bought the horrible picture of me exiting the museum. And really the background of the Golden Gate Bridge was great it was me that looked like shit. 

I'll be back
author: Adamma I.

description:
Got there at 5:45pm, I asked "you're going to close at 6, right?" and of course, to make the sale they say "no problem, you can stay until 6:45", so we buy the tickets, saw some fish tanks that were slightly better than I've seen at restaurants, the tubes were cool of course, finally get to the otters at the end of the aquarium (and the best part), and they put them away at 6:15, very misleading.  Got to see them for 90 seconds, and I had a pretty unhappy kid.

The place costs 1/2 of the Monterey Bay Aquarium, but of course the Monterey Bay Aquarium is 20x better,  save your money and go there.
author: Steve L.

description: This a great addition to pier 39! I love that it is short and sweet. I hate when I go somewhere and it takes forever to go thru everything. My son loves it there. I also love how ALL the staff is attentive and friendly thru out the whole place! I also like the fact that it's all locally funded and sustainable. The huge fish and sharks were my favorite. And it's great that when your done with the museum you can wonder downstairs and hang out at the pier
author: Linzi D.

description: The place lacked in exhibits but the tunnel was the most interesting part.
author: Angela L.

description:
This past Memorial Day weekend, we took our 2 and half year old toddler to Aquarium of the Bay. My husband hasn't been here before either so we decided to check it out. I had bought a Bloomspot deal previously for two general tickets for the price of one. At 3 years to 11 years, you pay $10 so at least for now, my son is free.

The aquarium is small so don't expect it to be like the Monterrey Bay Aquarium. When you enter, you see a few tanks of different fishes. Then you take an elevator down so you can see two types of jellyfishes (totally cool) and go through the tunnels. It's like being underwater and you have an employee that you can ask about the different fishes, sharks, rays, etc.

After you explore that, you take the elevator up to the touch and feel pool. There is only one touch pool with rays and sharks and another toward the exit for starfish. There are glass containers where you can see chinchillas, turtles and snakes. After exploring that, you end up at the aquarium's small gift shop. There's a sign that says that there's a bigger gift shop across the way.

When my son is older, we would check out the behind the scenes tour. There is also a separate ticket if you want to check out the family-friendly films at the aquarium's 3D theater across from the entrance.

Since we just spent an hour at the aquarium (which is probably the most you'll spend), we just hung around Pier 39.
author: Jenn D.

description:
I dont want to sound like a monterrey aquarium snob, but it is better, some of the exhibits here seem like they where directly copied from there.  My review is based on the price and quality compared to monterey.

Best feature was the moving walkway that went through the tunnels, keeps you moving and you dont have to navigate through people.

Worst feature is the way they guide you through it.  You go upstairs to enter, fine.  Then you go through a small room and then line up to ride the elevator down to the main floor, then line up for elevator again to go back up for the petting room.  Two elevator rides, when it can be done in one.  The venue is too small and tight for strollers and there is no stopping and watching room. 
My husband stated it is like a ride, get on and keep moving until your in the gift shop.

I agree with some of the other reviews, with discounted tickets it would be ok.  $65 for a family of 4, two adults and two kids is full price.
author: Larry L.

description:
(Review based on 2.5 stars)
Came here after having lunch with my brother and fiance. My fiance has always wanted to come here so we thought we would check this place out. Admission here is $16.95 but if you have triple A, it comes out to $13.95 each (there are not student discounts here).
You can purchase a ticket for the theater, but we were not interested in going.
Anyways, when I was about to purchase the tickets, my fiance asked if this place was big. The guy said 'yea, you could see this place in about 1 hour'... hmm, that doesn't seem like a big aquarium to me, but whatever, just paid the man and off we went.
There are about 3 stories in this aquarium and has your typical fare you would find in any other aquarium (salt water fish, jelly fish, petting tank, sharks, turtles, etc). We all went through the entire place in 45 minutes (and we weren't even rushing and took a ton of pictures throughout the exhibits).
Overall, it's a nice little aquarium, but the price of admission does not fit the experience you may expect to find. The price they charge is about the same as the aquarium in Long Beach (Southern Cali) and the aquarium is probably 3 times the size). I would not come back here and would recommend others to check out a bigger aquarium or this aquarium charge a cheaper price (but you know they won't because it's right in the heart of a tourist trap).
author: Vic C.

description:
Really disappointed.
It was small and the fish weren't not impressive at all. 
The jelly fish were nice but no better than any other aquarium I've seen

And "feeding the sharks" 
More like they threw in hundreds of fish to feed them and then we threw in like 5 each and one fish ate it...
The sharks don't even come up to the top they stay low. 
Most of the tour was the lady babbling about the food, care, cleaning, alkaline levels of the water, and a bunch of stuff no one gives a shit about
RIP OFF
author: Anna L.

description:
This fairly small Aquarium (about equal in size to the New England Aquarium... but much less expensive) is a relaxed place to wander around. The displays themselves weren't super informative but it is fun.

The anchovies swimming in a big school around a circular tank was certainly a highlight. They were all going in the same direction... except for the one, who seemed to be swimming backwards. He did this for the 5 minutes I watched... A well spent 5 minutes in my book. 

Of course, if you want to see fish in a more natural habitat they have this giant fish tank you can actually walk in a tunnel through. You sort of feel underwater, as fish swim around and over you. It wasn't as big as I thought, but once we got out of the first section, and into the shark section my Yelp Review bounced to 5 stars. They weren't big sharks, but none the less, very very cool. Great photo ops here.

After the tunnels you take an elevator up to the petting zoo. You can pet a shark, touch an urchin, or talk about baseball with the guys that work there. Apparently red sox fans are everywhere, and have taken over the SF Bay Aquarium. 

Show your AAA id, and this place is cheap for a tourist attraction. The proceeds to go to conservation and studies, so you can feel good about dropping you hard earned cash here. Sure, its not a huge aquarium, but it is a great place to kill an hour or two and connect with your childish wonder as you wander the tunnels and play in the touching exhibits.
author: David M.

description:
I wasn't planning to come to the aquarium. It wasn't even on my list - but I am so glad I made it! I bought a SF City Pass and admission to the aquarium is included. The underwater tunnels are amazing. 

One caveat - this is located in a tourist trap. I planned my visit during off peak times and had it been crowded, I would have probably had a less pleasant time.
author: Sara N.

description: I had a problem with my admission tickets and the people at the help desk went out of their way to help me to resolve the issue. Five stars for customer service! Thank you
author: Stefanie S.

description: This aquarium was decent.  I liked the big tunnels that you can walk through to see all of the sea life.  I had a discount coupon,  so I only had to pay $18.95 for two of us...but usually it is $18.95 PER person.  I don't really think it is worth the ticket price  as it is a VERY small aquarium.  We had seen everything we wanted to see in 40 minutes.   But, for what it was worth....the jelly fish, octopus, tunnels and "touch" pool were nice.  I don't think I would go again, but am happy to say that I have seen this aquarium.
author: Heidi S.

description:
You know, it wasn't All That and a Bag of Chips as I'd thought I'd remembered it to be.  It was kind of fun, but doesn't seem near as cool as the ads on TV or in the promo.  

Coolest part was the Jellyfish.  I hoped to see a whole lot more crabs.  The diver cleaning the glass/plastic walls was kind of cool.  I was hoping to see a lot more sharks.  

The TV Ads make you feel like you are totally surrounded by water in one section where even if you look down you might see fish swimming.  Rather, there's a base that starts on either side of the tube you're in and the glass and tank wraps around your sides and above you.  Some areas were quite dark, making it hard to see some of the fish.  

The really large fish (Tuna?) are always a treat.  Not enough sharks or starfish.  Was hoping for more variety, as well.  There's a section where you can pause to watch a video of just how flexible/collapsible an octopus is.  

There's the usual gift shop at the end, and you can have your pic taken for a fee. Standard touristy stuff.  And there's also a learning center which is fun for the kids because they learn more about sea life and can touch sea cucumber and rays. 

I think overall  it's not quite worth it for the price, but it's probably better for field trips for the kids, when they still view all this with awe and wonder.
author: Wyman L.

description: Nice aquarium and good for kids. It has a couple under water tubes for up close viewing of some sharks rays and other fish. There is also a nice otter exhibit, some jellyfish exhibits, and a touch pools.  The aquarium was good and worth checking out. Definitely better for kids.
author: George A.

description:
It was a nice little aquarium  not much more than the tunnel, but that had a lot of fun and interesting fish.  

As for the 3D movies, the turtle movie was cute and well done, but the sharks in 3D was done very poorly. A few (3 or 4) blurry, jumpy "3D" sharks.  Both movies were strong on the conservation, horrors of mankind on the ocean message which is not my thing.
author: Weston N.

description: A cool little aquarium that has the basic sea animals/fishes, but obviously not as extensive (or expensive) as the Monterey Bay Aquarium. I came here to use my Bloomspot, and felt it was definitely worth the 2 for 1 price. Even though you've probably seen most of the fish/jellies/etc before, they did a good job of changing up the displays. I loved how the light in the anchovy tank really brought out their shinyness (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco?select=RGjH7IPWeBFT13gQhV9htQ#RGjH7IPWeBFT13gQhV9htQ), and the lights in the jellyfish display made them look really cool (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco?select=RGjH7IPWeBFT13gQhV9htQ#zbI3OUuaQ0dHKp9z1V1X9g). I was surprised to see chinchillas (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aquarium-of-the-bay-san-francisco?select=RGjH7IPWeBFT13gQhV9htQ#Db3fyssm5Dc0hSR-dRRNhw) on display, but no complaints since they are so cute. I thought it was an added perk that they had petting areas where you could pet baby sting rays and a baby shark, and also some sponges, etc. Unfortunately, the octopus was hiding when I went, so I didn't get to see the mini show, but the rest of the underground tank part was interesting. There were a lot of huge fish in there! Overall, I don't think you could spend more than half an hour at the Aquarium of the Bay if you're over the age of 12, but I would recommend checking them out at least once (and ideally with a coupon!).
author: Amy D.

description: This was a nice little aquarium, it's not the Steinhart Aquarium, but it has a nice tube that you walk through with lots of fishes swimming all around you.  The jelly fish were pretty cool.  I think the octopus was beautiful, though I did feel sorry for it, it seemed to really being looking for an escape.  It was also free with the Citypass, so if you get a Citypass and are near Pier 39, stop by.
author: Lyssa D.

description:
Let me preface this by noting that we got in for free with a free pass in conjunction with my county library. Technically this place is a nonprofit (you can see their 990 filing online at their website) even though they seem like a lot of for-profit tourist traps.  We decided to add this to an afternoon where we started off at the Exploratorium.

I'd heard of this place for ages and remember the controversy about building it at Pier 39 since it would displace part of San Francisco Bay. The employees were all extremely eager, earnest, and welcoming.  Most tourist traps sort of want to get people in and out, but they want people to enjoy their visits. Our kid was handed a crown shaped hat similar to a cardboard crown at Burger King, but where the points are shaped like shark fins.

Overall it's OK for what it is, and perhaps shouldn't be compared to what it isn't - a world class aquarium like Steinhart or even Montery Bay Aquarium.  I understand a lot of visitors go because their San Francisco CityPass includes either this or Monterey Bay Aquarium (choose the latter if you can make it).  However, it's not bad if you can get a discount or maybe a freebie like we got.

Still - a few things felt a little bit strange.  They've got Dungeness crab in one tank, and I understand they don't feed except on the ocean floor at higher pressure.  I figure they throw new ones (pretty easy to get Dungeness crab in SF) in when their old ones expire and feed those to other animals.  The moving walkway didn't move - not that I particularly wanted it to do so.
author: yp w.

description:
This is the smallest Aquarium I've ever been to and why does it have 3 gift shops?  To enter, we passed through 2 gift shops!

We went here to kill time while waiting for the next Bay cruise, so we had about an hour to meander around.  But this Aquarium took us less than an hour to get through.  I'm glad I didn't pay to get in here, it was included in the City Pass.  

The only thing that was cool, was the shark feeding we got to see.  The underground tunnel through the large Aquarium had a conveyor belt made for humans (automatic walkway, like baggage claim that curves and turns).  I can see this being useful during summer peak tourist season, but lucky for us it wasn't on when we arrived.  Otherwise I'd really feel rushed to get through this Aquarium.

This Aquarium doesn't even compare to it's sister in Monterey Bay.  I went there last time I visited SF and spent hours getting lost in the ginormous Aquarium there.
author: Sandy C.

description:
While walking on the pier after a tour of Alcatraz, the aquarium seemed like a nice afternoon stop on our trip to San Francisco , but it left much to be desired .

As many have mentioned, the cost of admission does not accurately reflect the content of the aquarium. I understand that unlike most aquariums which exist for spectacle, this site functions as a replica of the aquatic life in the San Francisco bay and contains many local elements of sea life . However , the museum lacked detailed placards to denote information on the marine life included at the aquarium. Rather you were presented a plethora of stock photos that named fish with minimal description. When attending an aquarium I'm interested in knowing the feeding habits of the fish, predators, level of endangerment, size, behaviors etc. The existing placards had little more than the general name for the fish, which is upsetting if the aquarium prides itself on the conservation and understanding of local sea life.

In addition to a lack of readable information about the sealife, the aquarium functions through the use of narrow elevators and no useable stairways. Although I appreciate the idea of mirroring scuba diving by " descending " to see the exhibits, alternative methods of seeing the museum would of made the experience less painful as being crammed into an elevator with strollers and families or waiting for several minutes for a clear elevator was uncomfortable.

I will say that we enjoyed the conveyer belt walkthrough as it was cool to be " under the bay " as the schools of fish and sharks were nice to see .

After walking through the two main floors you can go to a touch tank on the bottom floor and learn about conservation , which was informative and well done.

I must lastly mention that one of the most condemning features of the aquarium and the one that really forced me to give 1 star is that the aquarium's final exhibit before entering a strategic gift shop is of bees. You read that right, one of the final images you see in the aquarium are bees.

For an aquarium that focuses on and prides itself on being about the education and conservation of local waters, I find the inclusion of bees to be flabergasting and poorly designed. Are we to believe there was no other aquatic life that could be put there ?

Please save your money and attend one of the other attractions of similar cost, at worst it would be equal to the aquarium.
author: Sheila F.

description: My boyfriend and I took a day trip to SF and decided to make the aquarium one of our stops. However, we both really weren't thrilled by the aquarium. Zoos and things of that nature are normally something that the both of us really enjoy, so we thought that this would be a place that we'd have fun at but to be completely honest we thought most of the tanks were lackluster and yes, the fish were pretty and cool looking but nothing really stood out about this place. Once was definitely enough for this aquarium.
author: Claudia P.

description: It was nice to check out the ocean life. It was really really small though and the tour was far too fast. What was nice though is that you can come and go as you wish with a day pass so we went once and headed out to get a nice lunch on the pier and then came back before we left for the day for one more lap around the aquarium.
author: Justin F.

description: This place is gross and run down, but will never struggle for business based on location. The water in all the tanks is murky and there are fish carcasses all over the bottoms of each one. Animals here look unhealthy.
author: Mike T.

description:
This aquarium is tiny!! Definitely not worth the entrance fee of $16.95 for an adult. (thank goodness my husband and I had a groupon for $8/person)  

There are 3 floor.  One floor has 2 walk through tunnel aquariums which can get quite packed.  Another floor is where you a touch a shark, star fish, sea urchins and some sort of ray.  The last floor is the basic aquarium of different fish and jelly fish.   

I didn't notice where the restrooms were.  

They do have a small snack stand before you enter the exhibit. No outside food allowed.
author: Tin F.

description: I don't care what anyone says about this place,  it has the freshest fish ever!  They are still alive,  not frozen.  Yummy!!!
author: Ajit D.

description:
This aquarium was very true to the average rating, 3 stars.  It was very small, but the exhibits were well presented and the fish are clearly in good condition.  For the price, a modest $16, it was the least expensive aquarium I have ever been to, and the ticket states that for each full-price adult, one student is admitted for free.  The top floor is great for kids, as they have a tide pool with skates and bat rays that you can touch and watch them being fed.   The lower level has a large tunnel exhibit, one featuring large octopus (hard to spot, good hiders!) and the other featuring several species of sharks. 

I was looking for a place to kill an hour and get inside to warm up, so I got my money's worth.  If you are expecting a lot of wow-factor, I'd skip it.
author: Shannon H.

description: Love this place!!! We have had a family membership 2 yrs in a row.. it's small but we'll done and the staff is knowledgeable and friendly. It's perfect for small children intrigued by the sea.. it seems like they have something new or in the works every time we come .. typical entrance fee is a little high but there's coupons online if u order ahead
author: Mimi W.

description:
Not the best Aquarium I have ever been too, but still worth the visit. It is small, but the two tunnels make up for it. The first tunnel includes lots of various fish and star fish. The second tunnel has small sharks and sting rays. I must say it was surprisingly relaxing to walk through the tunnels in such a tourist area. 
I also liked the sting ray petting area and some of the smaller animals they had on display. The price of admission is pretty spot on. The larger aquariums like monterey bay and long beach charge $30 and up. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but it's worth checking out if you are on the pier.
author: Frankie P.

description:
I havent been here since it opened.  And i was just a todd when that happened.  Back then, even though i was a kid, i remembered it to be pretty small.  It's no different now.  

So many years later, I didnt return until we got free tickets to go.  The only cool things they have here are the under looking, where you can see the octopus, and the shallow water where you can touch sting rays.  UNILIKE monterey bay, they make it so big and deep, and call it a touch pool, but theyre so far, you can watch it swim by you.
author: kim w.

description: I had a blast here while I was on Vaca from Seattle and the staff was very friendley. Have to say one of the coolest Aquariums I been too. Defent recommend :)
author: Summer W.

description:
We were soooo looking forward to this aquarium since our 1 year old is now very interested in fish and animals.

We've recently gone to the Dallas and Boston aquariums. We thought that San Francisco (being a high profile city, and right by the ocean) would have the best one.

We were extremely disappointed.

First off, as many have said, the place is overpriced at around $20 a ticket. (We did get $2 off, I think, for parking in the garage nearby and getting a coupon.)

Next, the architect that designed the place was dumb. I guess he did not think KIDS and BABIES would come to an aquarium. They have different floors in this place and only 1 elevator which 50 people at a time with strollers and everything try to cram in. You have to ride this elevator two times. (Oh, the "first" floor of this place is actually the second floor. So before you even go into the front door, you need to ride a service elevator which is super tiny and can only fit 2 strollers in there).

All this elevator cramping ruined the entire experience. Additionally, there weren't any fish/animals note worthy in this place anyway.

Overall, this is just a poorly designed aquarium. Families with KIDS are the #1 clientele for aquariums and the fact that you have to go up and down on elevators all day long is just plain dumb.. (at least have more than one elevator if you are going to build a multi-story aquarium)

I always thought the Dallas aquarium wasn't that impressive (well... compared to the aquariums I see in movies and tv shows). But I must say, it is the best one out of Dallas, Boston, and San Fran. Check it out if you are ever in D-town.
author: Sam Y.

description: im a fan its a aquariam on fishermans wharf its small for the price, but its in prime real estate
author: Leigh G.

description: Fantastic place--small but packs a big variety of fish and marine wildlife.  A must-see when at the Wharf!
author: Virginia C.

description: Staff is really friendly. Touch pools were nice but other than that a pretty basic aquarium, nothing too special. Would recommend the aquarium in California Academy of Science if looking for a good aquarium in San Francisco. Still worth going to if you have the City Pass.
author: Christi G.

description: I do love this place. Anything that has to do with ocean life fascinates me. This aquarium is relatively small, but it's a good size in the city. I really like the tunnels and the mini exhibits. Usually go through a few times and just observe as much as possible. If they still have it available, the pier 39 parking structure has a coupon on the back of the parking ticket which is cool!
author: Christina C.

description: 3 stars are fair.... It's really cool for its size but don't expect anything that wows you.... The elevators are a bit annoying, but yes your in a city aquarium. People were nice, fish were cool, tanks were a bit dirty. It was neat that the bay animals were the only ones in the tanks.......
author: Matt A.

description:
The aquarium was great! The space was a little tight. However my husband and I had a great experience. After our tour we went to the theater which is located on the other side of the aquarium.
 Well I did not appreciate one of the workers accusing me of stealing. I have never stolen anything in my life. Why would I steal 2 boxes of candy?!
Well I was waiting to purchase my snacks in the theater, I noticed that no one was working in the snack bar. After a few minutes of waiting an employee who was directing individuals into the theater, said that she will be with me in a moment.
 As I waited I noticed that the candy was quite expensive. So I put it back and decided that I get some popcorn and soda for my husband and I. When the employee finally arrives, I noticed that she was looking at me suspiciously. Then she asks "I thought you had two candy bars?!" I explained that it was over my price range and that I put it back. Due to that situation, I am giving you two stars! Maybe security will be better suited for this job.
author: ClassyKiaMarie ..

description:
I think they charge to much but it was a nice little aquarium.  We had fun looking at the jelly fish and the touching pool.

The elevator system is weird.
author: Kristine A.

description: Really generic and not very impressive. I was really disappointed. For the price I expected more. The only thing I did enjoy was being able to touch the stingrays. If you want to see a really amazing aquarium, make the drive to Monterey and  visit the Monterey Bay Aquarium. It's stunning!
author: Katie W.

description:
This is a small time aquarium compared to the Monterey Bay Aquarium. It takes about 45 minutes total to view the whole aquarium with time to interact with the touch pool and other hands on activity on the second floor.

The first couple of rooms you go to will be dark in comparison to the touch pool area. So if you have kids that are not very comfortable in dark places, I don't recommend coming here.

But, if you have little ones (5 years or under), they will definitly enjoy this quaint aquarium with not many frills to it.
author: Charissa G.

description: Nice fish, fun to watch, educational. But for $22.00 admission they had better be serving dinner too. Way over priced. Best way to see this place is on a free pass from a library. On top of the high admission you will most likely end up in a pay lot for parking. You are better off going to the Steinhart Aquariums in the  Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park if you want to see Fish.
author: Ron W.

description:
This place was not worth my money at all.  Nothing was unique and the tour was super short.  I can, literally, observe the whole aquarium in 15 minutes.  It's so small!  The only things I can touch were the sting rays and starfish.  

The underwater tour had a really unenthusiastic tour guide, who didn't talk much.  There's really nothing to say.  Yeah, they're striped bass, squid, shark, sturgeon...the stuff I eat.  YUM!

You should still go for the kids because kids' fee is low and free for 3yr and under. For me, I'd rather go watch the sea lions for free.
author: Lisa T.

description: It's a little aquarium so you can get through it quickly with little kids. I found it to be really fun and interesting expecially if you have little kids with not much patience. The priced aren't too bad and there are lots of discounted tickets available everywhere (GO Pass, etc.). Much better than any of the tourist traps of the rest of fisherman's wharf.
author: LovinLife Z.

description: Fun to walk through those tubes and see the creatures swim overhead.  The behind the scenes Feed the Sharks tour was excellent.  We got to toss in the food from above and learn more about the care of the animals.  My 10 year old son especially enjoyed it because he loves sharks and sea creatures.
author: Deborah G.

description:
I am a big fan of aquariums and being in San Francisco for vacation I thought I would have to check this place out.  First of all, this aquarium is extremely small- you can see everything in well under and hour.  When you first go in, you see a couple of tanks with various types of fish in them.  There is also some educational information about the area that you can read.  Following this short section, you must take an elevator to the floor which contains a couple of jelly fish tanks and a large walk through tank.  

The walk through tank was the best part about this aquarium.  You walked through and the fish, sharks, sting rays ect surround you (like you are in a tunnel).  After going through this section, you must then take another elevator back to the original floor you started on where you the other side of the elevator opens to a section which contains a few touch tanks.  I imagine that kids would really love this area as they can touch sharks, rays, seastars and other marine life.  In addition to the touch tanks there are a few other tanks with chinchillas, snakes, and reptiles.  Once finished with this, you walk through the gift store to exit.

The way this Aquarium is set up is extremely poor.  You have to ride up and down the elevator twice which makes it a little more difficult- I imagine quite difficult if you have a child in a carriage or a large group.  When going down to the level with the walk through tank, I encountered others on the elevator who could not figure out how to exit the Aquarium.  There is no real clear signage about where to go.  With San Francisco being on the water, I expected more from this aquarium.  I have been to the Boston, Baltimore, and Monterey Aquariums, all of which are much better then this one.  Overall, this might be enjoyable to take a young child to, but I would not waste the money to pay for the whole family.
author: Erin G.

description: Pretty cool place. I recommend stopping by around dinner time to avoid the swarms of little ones. Makes the trip a bit easier without so much noise!
author: Molly L.

description:
VERY SMALL & OVERPRICED. Only cool thing was petting stingrays at the end. We were in and out within 30min and had seen everything! 
Save your money and go to Monterey Bay Aquarium! It's not that much more and you'll have hours of fun!
author: Sonia K.

description: Pricey but a fun experience.  Not a very large aquarium but the tunnels made the visit worth it. The jellyfish tank is mesmerizing as the colors are always changing. The shark and stingray tunnel was such a neat experience.  Not the best aquarium, I think the one in Baltimore Maryland is the best I have ever been to. Only because the size is small. If it weren't for the tunnels I would not have visited.
author: Sarah C.

description: Loved the tunnel. A little on the small side for the price, but pretty cool.  Enjoyed watching the otters frolic and touching the rays.  Nice day trip.  Only issue was the elevator was down at one point (little kid pulled the fire alarm) so we had to walk down to one of the exhibits.  Not a good deal for handicapped patrons, they should have an alternative.
author: Sara K.

description:
I have to admit - I'm a bit of an aquarium elitist.  I had a membership to the aquarium in Boston, which was HYOOJ, and in which I spent many, many fond hours.  So I was kind of hesitant to enter another aquarium, particularly since I had heard that San Francisco's aquarium was smaller, and that in fact the marine life are spread out over several different museums (you can actually see some of the cooler stuff at the Academy of Sciences - including penguins and the albino alligator).

However, when I did end up at Aquarium of the Bay, it was still a really good experience.  The focus is on marine life that you could see in the bay and Pacific Ocean, and I like that very much.  I also liked the tunnels, through which I walked veeeery slooooowly, looking for octopuses.  They're always the trickiest to find, and stuff themselves in amusingly tiny spaces!  Having the fish not just on either side of you, but above as well, really does let you get up close and personal.  There was even a small school of (I think) anchovies that you could observe swirling around all silver-like.  I had never really gotten to see a school in action like that, and it brought back fond memories of the bait balls from "Blue Planet," although (SPOILER ALERT!) it never really ends well for the poor fellas.

I also liked the touch tanks.  Come now, fellow adults - you're never too old to touch a shark, are you?  I stick my hand in there every chance I get.  Besides, rays in particular like to be pet, or so I hear.  What was also really impressive was the extent of creatures available for touching.  Sharks, rays, anemones, sea stars, sea cucumbers - I have to say that all those blow Boston's horseshoe crabs right out of the water.  Yes, that pun was so very intended it hurt.  I had a very nice discussion with a 7-year-old about touching anemones, and how sticky the tentacles are at first.  I say "at first," because you probably don't want to be touching them for too long at a time.  My new friend informed me that they will indeed sting you.

Everything is so well-arranged and cared-for, I just wish there were more of it!  The $17 you pay is definitely for quality instead of quantity, but all the same I feel it's a little steep.  If you combine the pricing and the size, there's not a ton of repeat-value, but there is some.  I'll wait a little while, but I'll be back.  Aquarium-elitist though I am, I also just love aquariums.  And Aquarium of the Bay is indeed a lovable place.
author: Becca S.

description:
This aquarium is A-OK.  It's not like going to the New England Aquarium in Boston, but it wasn't as bad as the one in Hawaii.  It's smaller than I thought it was going to be.  This place was PACKED...and I mean...PACKED with kids.  They all seemed to be having fun or getting lost.  Pay attention to your kids, people. ;)  

I think maybe the most fun, from watching the kids, was the level where you could pet the sharks and sting rays, and where the octopus was.  There is some little crawl space under the octopus tank and the kids were just having a blast there.  

As for me, it was just too crowded and chaotic. haha.  But if you have kids, I think they'll have fun.  $4 off your ticket if you have and show your Alcatraz Island tickets.  $3 off with military I.D.  $2 off if you have the "Fun Book" coupon.  To get this, check into Pier 39 on yelp.  Then go to the California Welcome Center on the 3rd floor and get your "fun book".  Coupon in there.  

I think my favorite part were the jellyfish. :)  I know, so simple.
author: R R.

description:
If you do go here, have low expectations. also, don't pay full price.
My family went through here in under 30 minutes.  The high let was my son petting a shark.  
I would rather not go again. Many other things I would like to do.
But if you do go be sure to get a discount.
author: Steve M.

description: Definitely not worth it. Brought my nephew here and it seemed run down a little but thought I'd still give it a shot. I was surprised at how small it was, especially for the cost; but what turned me off for good was the dead fish on the edges of the tunnel you walk through! So gross!!! So many better places to experience and spend your money at in the area.
author: Julie M.

description: Best aquarium I have ever been to! Awesome exhibits and the staff was super helpful in every question that I had.
author: Camille P.

description: My kids had a great time at the Aquarium!  They will definitely want to go back on our next trip/vacation to San Francisco!
author: Jessi S.

description: Great for kids to enjoy the otters & shark display, very good for getting some energy out of kids :)
author: Ritesh K.

description: Better than the Monterey Aquarium! It is smaller than a normal aquarium but there are friendly tour guides, tons of exotic animals, and their animal encounters section is great for kids and adults! Great aquarium.
author: Kristi P.

description:
It was between Monterey Bay Aquarium or Aquarium Of The Bay.  I chose Aquarium Of The Bay because I didn't want to drive two hous to Monterey Bay.  This aquarium has all the good stops for toddlers or little ones.  Adults know this place is just medior, but little kids don't know that.  As long as there are fishes in the water and they can touch a couple sting rays, they're happy.  

Overall a great location.  I love Pier 39.
author: Chris R.

description: I brought my kids here from South Bay to this Aquarium.Kids liked it a lot.Had an awesome walk in the tubes and tunnels.Thought it would be larger but still was pretty decent.
author: Sara K.

description: Had some nice exhibits. The walkthru tunnel aquariums were nice. Also liked the exhibits where you could actually touch the rays and starfish. Liked the otters but were sleeping. A little confusing to know the walk flow and if we missed anything. Decent value but probably not worth the $20+ fee.  Would have thought it would have been a great value for $12-&15.
author: Dave C.

description: A cool spot to visit. We went late in the day, the ticket guy hooked us up, have me a dis out for being a teacher. Not too many exhibits, so don't expect it to be like the Monterey bay aquarium. However the tunnels are really cool, we took our time and stood in them watching the fish and sharks. We didn't spend more than an hour an a half.
author: Mallory R.

description:
My mother taught me that if you can't say something nice don't say anything at all.  Well by not saying anything at all would not be nice.  

This place sucks; seriously it has got to be the worst Aquarium I've ever been too.  And with it being right on the bay you'd expect a lot more, something bigger with more fish maybe.  Don't waste your time or money it's not worth it not even if it's in your CityPass just skip it, I'm sure your time is worth more.
author: Me H.

description:
Save Your Money - Go to Monterrey

It's a great idea - having a good aquarium in San Francisco.  But, unfortunately, the facility is small and very poorly set up.  The movies were rather boring, and the exhibits tiny.  Just a taste of what you'd see in Monterrey.  

In addition, it's located at Pier 39, so be prepared to run the gauntlet of tourist traps and shop till you drop, as it is right there.  That might be good or bad, depending on your preferences.

The staff were very nice and knowledgeable, but it isn't a high quality aquarium like San Francisco deserves.  It's a start.  I hope it grows, improves, and gets bigger, but for now - unless you are "in the area" - save your money and drive to Monterrey, which is of course a world class aquarium - about 1.5 hours south of San Francisco.
author: Jason M.

description: Disappointing big time. The only reason it gets 2 stars is because the staff are pretty friendly. Otherwise, the place is run down, is very small, you can go through it at a snail's pace in 15 minutes. Not worth the price of admission at all. Skip this, save yourself time and money.
author: Rob E.

description: I was very disappointed at how small and basic the exhibits were.  Not worth the price-- even with the 'locals' or online discount.  Go to Monterey.
author: Celeste D.

description: It was a nice 30-45 minute endeavor, but the price of the admission is a little steep for the number of exhibits.    The jelly fish exhibits are the best.  I had no idea how many types of jelly fish there are and the various colors.  Very nice.
author: Laurie B.

description: i enjoyed my trip. The best location in the city,its convenient fascinating, clean but small. There is a spa-like music that serenades you while you watch. Definitely a place to see.
author: Nicole S.

description: This was the worst experience ever.  Crowded,  small,  stuffy. The animals looked sad and their tanks looked like they haven't been cleaned in years.  I saw a couple of dead fish floating around in the tunnel take.  It made me want to cry.  The land animal cages were a joke.  The chinchilla had no room??????? The otters looked stressed out.  There were no hand washing stations at the "petting pool" Really? ? Little kids nasty hands and chemical-laden sunscreen is contaminating the starfish environment. This aquarium is sad. I can't believe i paid 23 dollars per person to support this. Cal academy of the sciences was amazing to their animals.  Please support CAL ACADEMY instead. It's 100 per person but your there all day rather than 30 min.
author: Julie G.

description:
The SF Aquarium of the Bay is, while decent, limited and more geared towards smaller children.  The experience was fun while it lasted, bur the thing is, that was not very long.  Tunnels in the aquarium contained numerous species of water animals, along with some background information.  The atmosphere felt very touristy; for an aquarium, it was okay, with some nice views, pretty exhibits, and color, but lack of uniqueness.
     Experience:  Actually, the experience in the aquarium itself, while it lasted, was enjoyable.  The water tunnels were very picture worthy, and we rode on the elevators transitioning between exhibits.  The number of exhibits came to only ten or fewer.  It was quite unexpected when we ran into the gift shop when leaving the otter exhibit.  Somewhat nice water views make up for a lotof it, though.  Four star overall experience, but around two-and-a-half star duration.
     Duration:  Not very long; probably 1/2 hour to 1 hour, tops.  Only eight to ten exhibits that are still nice to stare at for a few minutes.
