     Atmosphere:  Why, yes.  The atmosphere...is good.  Don't get me wrong, there still is a lot to improve and remodel here, but it's ambient.  It feels just like an aquarium should: calm, peaceful, serene, relaxing. stress-free, picture-worthy, and most of all, beautiful to observe.
     Overall:  Aquarium of the Bay is nice overall, and the aquatic tunnel portions are A-OK.  Yet, the whole thing just feels somehow watered down.  If only it lasted longer, and the extras such as a movie and the gift shop were expanded upon, this place would have a chance at a four star rating.  That's not to say when we visit SF in the future we won't visit here (in fact, we probably will), but there's definitely room for expansion/improvement.

     3/5 stars
     Experience: 3.75/5
     Duration: 2.5/5
     Atmoshere: 3.75/5
author: Alex T.

description: great spot for kids, or a date during a nice day. cute shows, up close and personal, adorable exhibits and helpful zookeepers.
author: Mike V.

description:
I bought these groupons for 8 dollars each, originally 16 at the door.  Hey, saved 50% off ticket price, why not?  

The place isn't that big like our New England Aquarium, there are no penguins!!!

They stamp our wrist so we can go in and out til closing.  One trip through was enough though.  They have these 2 underground tubes, one for shallow water fish and the other deep water fish.

The water wasn't too clear and walking  through the tubes, you can get a headache from the enclosed area.  The part I did like was the screen they have before the tube showing three parts of an Octopus, how they think and how they can glide through everything.  

Another part I liked were the jellyfish, they were so beautiful..

The final part is the touch lab, all the kids usually love to touch the starfish and all, simple and quick, couldn't wait to get out of there for a smoke!  

Next time I will head to Monterey Aquarium to check out the swimmers there....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
This place is a pleasant experience, almost comparable to Monterey Bay but this place is closer, more affordable, and near the pier albeit smaller but it deserves a thumbs up still! 

Staff were nice and friendly and seemed to know what they're talking about. My favorite part was learning about the stingrays, going through the tunnel, and the starfish tidepool.
author: Tram N.

description: Definitely worth a visit. There are lot of fish tanks, my favorite were the anchovies and jelly fish. We spent around 2 hours here and saw a lot of sea creatures.
author: Cassidy M.

description:
I got this aquarium ticket for free when I went on a bay cruise.  At first I wasn't going to go, but it was a welcome break from the heat, so I decided, "why not?!"

The place is kind of small.  The pictures outside the building show all kinds of animals, but it is pretty much just fish.  They have one area  of underwater tubes that are probably the coolest thing here, but if you get even the slightest bit claustrophobic you will hate it.  There was a lady in there that was starting to freak out.

It's on Pier 39 and there are kids everywhere, and you are stuck in a glass tube that goes under a fish tank.  It can make anyone want to jump into the nearest shark tank.

They have a small "petting area", and I pet a starfish while I felt bad for all these animals that I'm sure the kids mercilessly poke at all day long.  

The whole thing took like 30-40 minutes to go through.  If I had actually paid for my ticket I would have been pissed.  The ticket prices are way overpriced for what it is. It's around $17 per person.  Far too much money.
author: Miss L.

description: It is a smallish aquarium - but we're used to the one at the Inner Harbor in Baltimore which is one of the best in the country (so I am told).  It's very entertaining, and you can enjoy everything and be in and out in a couple hours.  A great tourist attraction.  Kids loved the touch tank - maybe their favorite thing this whole vacation.
author: Vicky C.

description:
A great little aquariam perfect for keeping families entertained for an hour or two.  It is small but they have interesting exhibitions and a great tunnel to walk through. 

Our children thoroughly enjoyed themselves and an hour is more than enough for them.
author: Lottie R.

description:
This is a small aquarium with only a few exhibits, but it's cool because it has a focus on the life in the San Francisco Bay area. and, although its small, theres still a lot to see. They have 300 feet of tunnel tank showing you what it would be like to dive through the bay and California coast.

Also the staff is well trained and much more attentive than at other aquariums so you get a more personalized feel as you go through.

at $17 for adults and $8 for kids and seniors, it can be a little pricey if you just blaze through it, which could take 20 minutes. But if you're actually interested in marine life, its easy to spend well over 2 hours checking out all the life they have on exhibit.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Tunnels are awesome!  You get to see two of them! 

For such a tiny space I think they did a great job maximizing what you can see! 



And you should definately do the behind the scenes tour!  If you love Marine life, you should check this out!
author: Jenner B.

description: It was fun and I loved the touch pool even though I didn't get to touch the shark. I was expecting more creatures like giant sharks, dolphins, octopus, etc. I guess I was a little silly for expecting those things. But it was disappointing.
author: Trinity M.

description:
Just got back from SF for a little trip & went ahead & went here.  I skipped the Wax Museum & Ripley's Believe It or Not because I read reviews that they weren't great.  I should have skipped THIS too!  It only takes about 30 - 40 min to walk through it & one aquarium that was supposed to have the big octopus wasn't there!  It was disappointing for sure.  I went on a Wed, so the only good thing was that it wasn't crowded at all.

The Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, CA is a LOT bigger & better.
author: Rolena I.

description:
I haven't been to many aquariums before, but I would say this one was alright. They had the cool tunnel pathway which allows you to see the various creatures of the sea. It kind of makes you feel like you are up close with the animals. 

The whole tour seemed a little short, so that was the only thing I was a little bummed about. They didn't really have many exhibits as well either. The admission prices are a little expensive. I was expecting a little more.

If it was cheaper, I would go to it more. But it's just not worth the price in my opinion.
author: Dave K.

description:
I love this place. 

I love sting rays so intelligent and gentle and soft!

I would go back
author: Ms W.

description: For what it is, it's not bad. I've always had a fondness for the walking underwater tubes that this place has. Ever since Jaws 3, I've been hooked. =) It's a little expensive so my recommendation is to find the group-ons or coupons that are always online. You save $2 per person and that's easily something you can spend on knick nacks or all the wharf treats outside. Take your time through the exhibits, you never what you'll see.
author: Jon H.

description: Bought discount tickets through Gilt City, and still thought it was overpriced. Went through the entire aquarium in about 1/2 an hour! The only memorable thing was a CGI short on octopi and its prey - but I could have watched that on the Discovery Channel.
author: Gev M.

description: To see the jelly fish and hear the soothing mood music is nice. When I entered the tunnels to experience sharks and rays I was subjected not only to Christmas music (oh, come let us adore him) but the staff member with the squawking walky talky was singing the tunes off key. I understand Christmas crap in a department store, but was saddened to find it among the fishes. Is there no escape from the assault of Christmas?
author: Michael R.

description:
We came here cuz the Kid is mad about fish, any fish, live, dead you name it, he'll look at it.  We cashed our BOGO coupon for the Entertainment book and went in. 

Eh, it's a small aquarium.  Not much to look at.  It makes the temporary digs of the Academy of Science look like a palatial estate.  The Kid didn't care, he was looking at the fish.  $14/person is really the deal breaker.  You can finish everything up in 30 minutes (that's stretching it!) tops.  $6/hour parking at the Pier is also bad. 

However, I'm gonna tell you a little secret.  You know that AAA card in your wallet?  Take it to the Visitors Center on the second floor of Pier 39 and show it to the clerk.  You'll get a fun pack and a pass for 2-hour free parking at the Pier 39 garage.  So yeah, we just paid $14 for two hours of fun!  We got free parking.
author: Wendy H.

description: It's a neat little spot right by Pier 39 and since my sister and I were waiting for family members to get back from Alcatraz (I didn't get to go with them since tickets were sold out *tear*) we took her son to the aquarium. I haven't been to the aquarium in 10 years, so it was nice to see everything again. I got to touch a sting ray and pretty star fishes. =) It's a great place for little kids.
author: Nani V.

description:
This is a great place to visit when visiting San Francisco with kids, and say you find yourself in bad weather, or needing a respite from tacky wharf stuff or maybe you just like aquariums as our family does.  It's not a destination in itself, per se, but you'll come out feeling good! On a weekday before lunch it wasn't busy at all and our toddlers loved looking at the fish and checking out the extensive touch tanks with starfish, anemones and rays. Helpful staff makes it super approachable for kids. There is a fun otter exhibit at the end with otters swimming and playing right in front of you. It's the perfect size for kids - in and out in about an hour or 90 minutes, having learned something, experienced something, touched a fish or two. Really relaxing and nice.
Be sure to grab any tourist map and I bet it will have a discount coupon or ask at your hotel. There's also a locals discount for Bay Area folks - $4 off and I live in San Jose. Kids under 4 are free.
author: Honor R.

description:
Luckily I bought tickets to this aquarium from an online deal. So I essentially got a 2 for 1 deal. I would've been so upset if we had paid full price!

The tube is pretty cool - I give that to them. I was impressed by it and thought "maybe this SF tourist attraction is actually one worth visiting!" But it pretty much stopped there.  We went to one more floor and got to see a few things and pet some sea creatures, and that was it.  I was in disbelief at how small the place was.

Compared to the Monterey Bay Aquarium, the SF Aquarium is SO SAD!  It's great that it's here and all for us to visit, but really.... it's just not worth it. As one reviewer said below - in and out in 30 mins. (60 mins if you are like me and had to re-walk the whole place to make sure there really wasn't more to see.)

Visit this place once if you want, and then drive down to Monterey to really be wowed by sea creatures.
author: Mary D.

description: This is the worst aquarium EVER!!!!!  I came here on mother's day because some people from work mentioned that it was free for mom's on mother's day. It was $20 for my husband and free for me, but  $20 was a rip off.  I wouldn't have paid $5 to come here. Plus parking was $8. A complete waste of time and money! The aquarium was so disappointing. It was super small and we went through it in about 20 minutes. The tanks were small.  The displays were unimpressive. I should have known not to come to this Aquarium at Pier 39. This area is a tourist trap and should be avoided!
author: Jane S.

description: Even though it's a small(er) aquarium at the corner of Pier 39, they really have packed in quite a bit.  We were delighted by all the types of sea life on display, and the shark tunnels were pretty cool, too.  All the guides/employees were super helpful and friendly.  Highlight was the "hands on" experience for the last 1/3 of the aquarium, where we got a show from one of the cutest, attention hungry, rays ever. Loved it.   Show your AAA card at the ticket window for some $$ off.
author: Talar P.

description:
Great place to bring some kids to pick up chicks!!! Chicks dig real men who has their life together. I had to borrowed my pal's kids for the hour and them girls were all like "AWww! How sweet! You so nice!" And I was like, "yeah, so here's my phone." 

Going thru the underwater tunnel was cool. I felt like King Tritan.
author: Sonar L.

description: They do birthday parties... in theory. A few phone calls and a few emails and not a single call back in 2-3 weeks of trying to contact them. Really frustrating.
author: Bjorn S.

description: Nice place with friendly and knowledgable staff. The tunnel is awesome and the music adds to the experience tremendously however the place is tiny and not nearly worth the cost. It's more of a $12.99 price range experience.
author: Tali L.

description:
Not as impressed as I would have liked to have been so I won't call this a must visit. I visited it as I was driving through Monterey & dint want to do the 17 mile drive (again)

Although they do cover a wide variety of sea life, I guess the place is a little hotch-potch and the lay out is not convenient for visitors to cover everything efficiently. There are a lot of exhibits that are probably sponsored by companies which have *nothing* to do with aquatic life - that confused me & I skimmed through them. I like sharks and was hoping they have some section on them (that may not be reasonable but I was hoping for it )

Whats Good:
Touch sections allow you to touch things like sea weeds n other life (if your into that kind of stuff) 
Periodic events like movies & informative sessions are accesible for the curious ones.
Cafe & outdoor deck to the ocean is cool.

At 24$ adult general entry I think its a reasonable price but the closest parking was 15$ a day & its not very easy to get free parking around the area, (thats a separate issue though)
author: Mr. Y.

description:
Like many others have said, you can't compare this to other aquariums like Monterey Bay. I see it as something to do to kill some time  and spend the last of the vacation money before you leave. The price ($2 off w parking) was 16 for each adult and i dont remember how much the kids (3of them) were (one was free) . 
 The exhibits were neat but overall the place is small. The navigation is terrible when its crowded. We had to wait a while for an elevator and we got jammed up because they take pictures right before the elevators also. The kids were happy while we were there but the touch pools were crowded and people who don't keep an eye on their kids our make them wait their turn.  While it was somewhat entertaining, we probably wont visit it again when we return. it's at the pier so we expected it but we will save our money for Golden Gate park.
author: RL L.

description: Aquarium of the bay is a small, but fun place.  It has enough kinds of fish to keep you entertained. My favorite part was the jelly fish tank which changes colors and most of all the fish tank tunnel! It was really cool to get a view of the different fishes going through the tunnel. It's the only aquarium I've been to with that long of a tunnel. This is a great place to go locally if you want to see the fishes.
author: C G.

description: Disappointed. What they have is nice, but $26 for an aquarium that takes 45-60 minutes to walk through seem overpriced. I thought this would be much better than the mediocre Sea Life ones I've taken my kids too... But it wasn't, and definitely overpriced at $26 per adult. Would not do this again. Crowded, too.
author: Allan B.

description:
uhhhhh nice effort? It was OK. 

They had some pretty displays, a few vibrant fish, and a cute hedge hog. My favorite was the jelly fish! I can stare at jelly fish all day :P 

The aquarium is on the small side, nothing spectacular. It will give you something to do for about an hour... 

Unfortunately I felt sorry for most of the fish at this aquarium. There were times that the fish looked old, dead, and/or didn't have room to move :(
author: Jennie S.

description:
I wasn't that impressed with this aquarium. If you really want to spend your money wisely on seeing all sorts of aquatic life, visit the Academy of Science in Golden Gate Park.  This aquarium is very small and short for the amt of $$ you need to shell out in order to get in.

One positive thing that I did like was the underwater viewing area (Tunnel).  This was part of our citypass so we just checked it out while we were by Pier 39.
author: Mike D.

description: Great place to go to, watching all kinds of fish from sharks to HUGE seabass is greeat. There's also Jelly Fish that are so nice and calming in the eyes. This place is a must place to go to at Pier 39 but I wish it's alot bigger and quieter. There's kids running around everywhere screaming like there's no tomorrow so, try to go when its less busy other than that I would definitely go back to this place.
author: Angelica T.

description:
Although you can watch sharks, stingrays, starfishes, and other sea creatures through the clear acrylic tunnels in the Aquarium of the Bay, the overall experience here pales in comparison to the experience in the Monterey Bay Aquarium.  This aquarium is relatively small and took no more than 40 minutes to see the entire place.

However, one good thing about the Aquarium of the Bay is that it's located at Pier 39 and makes a nice weekday trip (hardly anyone inside) if you happen to be in the area.  I also found out that is quite easy to find discounted tickets (a non-discounted adult admission is $16.95).
author: Lupe M.

description:
This aquarium deserves better than 3 stars.  It is not huge, but we spent at least 2 hours here (3 adults and an 8 year old) looking at the thousands of fish (and really, how much time can you really spend staring at fish).  

The highlights are the two long glass tunnels which are crammed with fish you could find in the bay.  From schools of sardine to sharks and sea bass, they swim along and above you.  This you can't find in Monterey or at the Academy of Science, and it was great to not have to fight for a spot by the glass.  They do also have an octopus, I saw it in the large tunnel tank.  So I guess the other reviewer just didn't see it (it was hiding at the bottom in a crevice)

The touch pool was another highlight.  We got got to roll up our sleeves and pet sharks and rays.  There are also a number of other smaller tanks filled with feisty hermit crabs, technicolor tropical fish, and luminescent jellies.  Given this place is only a few bucks more than a movie and much more educational for kids, I would totally recommend visiting if you find yourself at Pier 39.  They have a AAA discount which gives $3 off adult tickets.
author: Aaron S.

description: My children have always wanted to know which sea creatures are in the bay.  They loved this place.  It was really cool.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I love aquariums and sea life, but this aquarium is not as great as the one in Monterey. Plus, when I was there, it was crowded and some of the employees in the touch areas were not very friendly. They were barking orders at the young kids who were trying to touch some of the sea life.
author: Jennifer T.

description: This is an interesting experience and has a very different layout than the Monterey Aquarium which is it's sister. The docents work in the elevators and tell you what you'll be seeing as they ferry you from floor to floor. The new otter habitat was well laid out and although we were there later in the day when they were sleeping, you could see that they had all sorts or water and land to play on. The big thrill was walking through the shark tunnel as they swim all around you. Totally worth coming down for!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Decided to finally check it out today and GROUPON had a deal..serendipity! 

Took the fam, and our kid enjoyed the sharks, the rockfish, and the jellyfish the most.
author: Francisco T.

description: I love the underwater tunnels and it's perfect for a toddler who has just learned to walk.  We lucked out on a day that was less crowded.  Not sure we would have had such a good time in a different situation.  I would bring my daughter here more often if the admission price wasn't so high for the amount of exhibits they have.  Luckily we went on Father's Day so my husband got in for free.  Didn't get to see the otter exhibit since it hadn't opened yet. It would have made the price a little more worth it but they increased their prices for the new exhibit.  Bah!  Oh well, I'll just have to wait for another discount day.
author: Nina L.

description:
Havent been to the aquarium in a LONG time so I decided to take my girlfriend to the aquarium for our 1 year anniversary. It was OK. Looks smaller compared to a few years ago. I havent been there since I was like 7

I had buy one get one free tickets. So that was always good. Regular ticket was like $!7 though. Got 2 of them for that price. So wasnt a bing ding in my wallet. I know Goldstar has tickets for about $12, get them there. Heres a lin

But anyways back to the review, the Aquarium was REALLY small and tiny. The Aquarium consisted of 4 sections. The first section had some fishes, and some info about different animals, next 2 sections were 2 long tunnles showing you the different fishes and sharks they got. Nothing too extravagant, some of the fishes WERE HUGE. and the last section was a little petting zoo where you can touch the rays and small sharks and fishes and stuff like that.

Then at the end which i hated the most they had not ONE but TWO gift shops to make you shop for their overpriced items. They had one small one at the end, which was also their exit. then they had ANOTHER one in another building as you exit. 

They also don't offer re admittance to the aquarium, so once you leave you cant come back in. Most museums in SF let you come in throughout the day but not this one. SO we stayed a little longer jsut to get our moneys worth.

Check it out if you can. Its not much but you can say you been there. Try finding specials or going for their combos to save money.
author: Daniel S.

description: It's a nice aquarium. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable. Would strongly recommend visiting during off-peak hours. We went on a weekday summer morning, and had the aquarium almost completely to ourselves! My son (who is hard to monitor at his age - 21 months), had lots of fun seeing the sea life, and walking through the tunnels and just observing. We were able to do the entire aquarium in about two hours, so wouldn't budget too much time for this. A great way to see this place if you are a local is with a sf fun pass (good for complimentary admission for two adults and two kids), available through your local library in limited quantities. As enjoyable as our experience was, I would be hardpressed to pay $21.95 per adult for this experience.
author: Wendy L.

description: Nice small Aquarium with a very cool underwater walkway. Great for Kids of all ages and adults too. If you park in the parking garage across the street they give you a coupon for $2 off each ticket Just FYI
author: DJ F.

description: I wasn't extremely impressed by the Aquarium, but I'm giving 5 stars for ZACK an employee there!  We won free tickets at the Aquarium's booth (Zack was running the booth) at a festival in Oakland and decided to go into the city the next weekend and make use of said tickets. While going through the exhibits, Zack recognized us from across a crowd and totally called out to us and signaled us over!  As a new resident of CA from the East Coast, it was more than heartwarming to have an employee recognize my boyfriend and I, out of the thousands of people that he saw at that festival!!  I hope someone at the Aquarium reads this and gives Zack props for being great at his job.  His enthusiasm and his knowledge about sea life was impressive and deserves merit.
author: Sydney H.

description:
LOVED the underwater tunnel. 

LOVED the 2 examples of jellyfish. 

LOVED the PG#E presentation on the hedgehog who kept pooping throughout the whole show... 

but after going the aquarium in monterey, nothing compares. 

and for $16.95 too? eh. 

that's the ONE thing i didn't love.
author: Milly S.

description: Went here Friday with my 1yr old and 7yr old and it was the highlight of our trip to Pier 39!  A nice woman (brown curly hair, light complexion) was nice enough to guide us through some of the more interesting spots like the shark tunnel!  My kids absolutely loved our time there and yes even learned quite a bit!  They loved touching the little rays and even a shark! Thank you so much for being such great hosts!  Hope to visit again some day...this is a can't miss in SF!
author: Norm M.

description:
3.5  

Kind of expensive if you don't get a discount deal, but still a nice little aquarium.  The exhibits are proportionally sized because this isn't the largest place you'll ever go.  Nice that it's nestled in Pier 39 so you can walk around after and take your time to enjoy.  The tube tunnel tank and the petting area make this worthwhile.
author: Brian Y.

description: I was pretty hyped up about going to the aquarium considering that the last one that I've been to was the Aquaurium of the Pacific in Long Beach, CA. Going to this one made me wonder whether or not I got bigger or the aquarium got smaller. Bombarded with little children, I tried my best to capture various images of the sea creatures without having a little kid photo bomb the opportunity. There were a few families that didn't listen to the staff members and took photographs using flash...and boy did that scare away just about everything.
author: Michelle H.

description:
This place was not as bad as I thought it was going to be. They had a decent amount of exhibits, but the main highlight was the underwater walk through aquarium. It was much larger than some aquariums have. 

For the price, it is a nice mix. I wouldn't pay more than $15 per head. You could be in and out in about 30-45 minutes.

Our 2 year old son loved it! I'd consider taking him back.
author: Adrian P.

description:
I've been wanting to check out the Aquarium of the Bay here in San Francisco for as long as I can remember. 

I love aquariums and being from San Diego I must admit I always have pretty high expectations for them. 

I will say that this place is not on the cheap side, the fact that it's located right at pier 39 probably doesn't help much in that department, but nevertheless I'm sure proceeds go to a good enough cause to make it worth a look. 

The aquarium is small, but surprisingly pretty cool. There are two floors, the bottom being the main attraction with two huge water tunnels, complete with sharks. There is also an interactive area where kids can touch some of the sea life. I did find all the facts pretty cool and interesting and I could definitely see myself bringing kids here. The jellyfish were spectacular. My only disappointment was that I did not get to encounter my favorite sea creature the grand octopus.

If you don't come with grand expectations and are looking for something fun to fill up part of your afternoon it's definitely worth the trip.
author: Liz C.

description: Eh so far  I like my aquarium of the pacific in Long Beach but it could be fun for the kiddies! I like the 360 giant tank, that was pretty cool.
author: Cindy M.

description: Tiny aquarium .. You can complete the trip in an hour.  It is part of my city pass so no regrets for not spending an extra dime. Killed a prefect hour with my daughter who enjoyed to the fullest.
author: Sunil K.

description: It's a nice aquarium, kept up and the aquatic/animal displays are nice. But it is pricey for the size (fairly small).
author: Will D.

description:
This aquarium is a little disappointing coming from Hawaii but it was still very neat to see how different aquariums set things up. Didn't have to much of a selection of things to view, but if you have never been anywhere before this will still be a great place to take the kids to  see everything. It's something additional and exciting on the side to do if you are spending the day at Pier 39. The reason why I am a FAN of this place is because they also have a BAY CRUISE! My husband and I purchased tickets that let us view the aquarium then go on this cruise and the cruise in itself was magical and I LOVED every second of it.

The Cruise picks you up at Pier 39 very close to the Aquarium and it takes a good hour to get through. It takes you down to the Golden Gate Bridge, then around Angel Island, very up close and personal with the Alcatraz Island (you can't walk down though), but it is close enough to see a lot of details and you are able to read the writing on the sign and walls. Then it takes you by the Bay Bridge and then you come back to the Pier. The Cruise is very detailed with historical events that took place including the importance of the two bridges and the history behind the Angel and Alcatraz Island. Of course Alcatraz caught more of my attention. My husband and I originally tried to go on the Alcatraz Tour but not buying tickets in advance the tour is sold out until September, so this cruise is the closest thing to it and I really enjoyed myself. I would take kids of any age to the aquarium, however for the Bay Cruise I would only take children ages 8 and up. It is very cold, can get quite rocky and they may not necessarily be interested in the historical talk.
author: Victoria C.

description: This place makes me sad.  We moved to the city about a year ago and recently went for a visit.  It was rough.  It is in a very touristy part of the city so there are tons of visitors that don't have good manners.  They were hosting a school (or several schools) field trip, which made it unbearable for us.  Kids running around like crazy people, grabbing creatures in the touch tank that they shouldn't be grabbing, taking flash photos of the fish in tanks.  We didn't see any staff or volunteers monitoring. Horrible.  Worst of all was the otter exhibit they've been shamelessly promoting all over the city. It is a VERY small section with little water, surrounded by glass.  The otters appear to have no escape from viewers (screaming kids banging on their glass enclosure) and they looked unhappy.  The exhibit is indoors.  No fresh air.  These are wild animals that need fresh air and sunlight.  The  woman on staff couldn't even tell us about the otters - where they came from, their ages, their story. I'm not talking about someone in the gift shop or front desk.  The person standing near the exhibit who is supposed to be there for questions. Educating the public on caring for our oceans and wildlife? Nope. Sad story. Not going back.  And the response below appears to be a typical PR response.  I really don't have any interest in hearing that the habitat meets regulation standards.  SeaWorld says that too, and nothing makes it OK to keep an Orca in a pool.  I'd say make your own judgement and research it before going.  I hope they improve things for the animals in their care.
author: Lisa C.

description: This aquarium is small but well kept and organized. It's neat to have a focus on the Bay specifically, to learn about the ecosystem underneath the beautiful views from the Wharf. My boyfriend has a thing for aquariums, so we always go if the city we're visiting has one, and while this was not the most impressive, we enjoyed it nonetheless. Because it only takes about an hour to go through, it's probably not worth a solo trip, but it's a good cornerstone to the Fisherman's Wharf experience. I enjoyed the sharks and jellyfish a lot.
author: Kristan H.

description:
Cute place, but kinda small.

We came here because it was part of our san francisco city pass. 

I did enjoy the underwater tunnel walk way. The touch pool was cool, but kinda the typical aquarium section.

The staff was very nice and friendly.

Definitely a nice place, but I don't know if I would pay much just to go here.
author: Leanne D.

description: All I can say after going here is, "That was it?" Save your money and go to the California Academy of Sciences instead. The aquarium there is just as big and you get all of the other exhibits as well.
author: Daniel H.

description: My boyfriend and I were supposed to go to Alcatraz one day but it was full so we ended up going to Aquarium of the Bay. I haven't been to an aquarium before so it was cool experience. Once we got in, we were given shark hats which was pretty nice of them. I wore it the whole time cause I felt like a little kid again. There were so many people inside that I wasn't able to look at all the fishes but that was probably because It was on the weekend. I was so amazed with the water tunnels filled with sharks and stingrays. One of my favorite exhibits was the jellyfishes because it reminded me of the movie 7 pounds. At the end of the tour, there was an interactive area for people to touch the animals like the Stingrays, chinchillas, etc.
author: Janice V.

description:
I am so pleased I went!! THANKs to Yelp and dear buddy Ann L who always is emailing me to advise me of events! The Aquarium of the Bay was worth every unpaid cent and now would gladly return and with friends to show them this grand place! I walked half a mile and was third in line when it opened 12,6mins later.  I showed them my DL with my North Beach address and though I had brought an official letter sent to my address, they didn't request it unlike the CaS neighborhood days when residents are requested to show two types of ID. 

I've never been within the Aquarium of the Bay so I didn't know what to expect but started snapping right away as the exhibits were so interesting, but I *really* wanted to see the jellyfish exhibit, which is an elevator-ride away. I don't know if it was designed this way or not, but to me (remember my California Academy of Science blah experience) their jellyfish was in a huge exhibit which wasn't cleaned, so the glass dirt ruined my pixs of the jellyfish there. Here it seemed the HUGE gorgeous jellyfish were UP AGAINST THE WALL/GLASS, and it's really breathtaking! I snapped only a thousand pixs - just kidding. It's certainly worth more and the glass was so clean, which I explained later to a girl I saw cleaning the glass of a dry exhibit. The other section I spent the most time was the tunnel with fish and more swimming to the left, to da right and even above you! I am sure glad many of these don't have private organs sticking out or there'd be some very upset parents and excited kids!!! hahahahaaa  I loved it and again, the glass was clean for the most part and allowed me to photograph great pixs! A wonderful experience!

PHOTOGRAPHICALLY SPEAKING: Don't take a tripod as it'll be more of a hinder than a help. There are several areas where one would certainly be helpful, but because of the dark areas and kids running about, you'll soon regret using a tripod. In my digital SLR, I just upped the ISO to an usable speed and/or brace thyself against something like a wall. The jellyfish and the tunnel offered the most interesting subjects but lighting is tricky in both exhibits. One thing that I did see was in the AWB the colors didn't come out correctly due to the mix of several light sources. One thing is to set your camera - if able - and use a foto with a light source captured within the AoB, and set that to be your custom white balance. NO flash photography of the octopus exhibit, and personally I don't think it should be allowed in the dark exhibits also. 

Many thanks to Aquarium of the Bay for having a SF residents' day ~ happy shooting!!!!
author: Tony L.

description:
Yah it's no Monterey. But it's still interesting, and something to do on the weekend. I'd never been before and thanks to my job for the complimentary tickets. 
I can say that I've been here, but wouldn't be mad if I'd never made it back....Monterey on the other hand is a different story! :)
author: Sharee g.

description:
I LOVE aquariums so of course I had to come to the Aquarium of the Bay! I think I've been here 2 or 3 times by now. I mean...pretty standard in terms of fish and sea life. The coolest part was just this one clear glass tunnel underwater where you would be surrounded by all these unique fish and sharks and watch them while being a part of their habitat. There's also a touch pool, but there weren't too many moving animals to touch. Maybe I just prefer touching things other than the standard starfish and sea urchins..

Overall though, it was really short, and I've always been able to complete the whole route within half an hour. Which kind of sucks considering how expensive admission is. One time I doubled through and that made the experience a lot better though.
author: Melody L.

description:
Visited this place recently and really enjoyed it!  Didn't go in expecting much based on the reviews here but I definitely feel that it deserves at least 4 stars (this coming from a family with a toddler).  

We have a membership to the zoo which allows us to come here for half off.  If my family of 4 had to pay any more than what we did, I'm not sure if it would be worth it.  

We came on a Saturday and fearing the possible crowds/tourists, we arrived right when it opened and we basically had the place to ourselves (there were maybe 2 other families there).  Sweet!  We got through the place in maybe 2 hours.  We went through both tunnels twice and spent a lot of time at the ray pools.  The kids loved it.  

Its not Monterey but it also doesn't cost that much either and this is closer to home.  I also scored free parking at the pier 39 garage (yelp this garage for instructions).  All in all a great experience.
author: Tina M.

description: Only come here if you get a deal online, it's not worth it to pay full price to come to this place, it's extremely small, but it's a nice little detour to get away from all the people on their pier.  Plus, I'm a sucker for aquariums. I like this place, and I have always found the tube exciting.  Really cool.  Some exhibits were kinda sad and boring, but to me, the jellyfish one did not disappoint! I can stare at those things for hours!
author: Meena N.

description:
2.5 Stars

I should have known as soon as I saw the building that this was another sad Aquarium. (Beats Scripps by far though!)

For the price they charge, it really should be as breath-taking as the Aquarium of the Pacific--but it isn't, by far. (In fact, CA Academy of Science had a much more exciting aquarium!)

Anyway, back to the fish--or lack there of. Where is all the life here?! I saw more fish in the gift store tank than in the entire aquarium. (I'm only half exaggerating, btw.)

I would definitely suggest that you're dying to see an aquarium, save your money and go to the CA Academy of Sciences. You'll be pleasantly surprised there, I'm sure!
author: Dee N.

description: I thought this was a great aquarium. I went by myself since my husband is here on business. It is right in the middle of Pier 39 so it's not like you are going to spend 2-3 hours here. You want an aquarium where you can go in for 45-60 minutes and be satisfied. The tunnels were the best part - I loved seeing the fish swimming all around and it was very relaxing compared to all of the tourists everywhere outside. Kids seemed to enjoy the petting room the most from what I could tell. I think you can save some money by buying tickets online in advance. It was cheaper than the Baltimore aquarium and way less crowded as far as tourist pier aquariums go (we didn't even end up going in there it was so crowded/overpriced!) so maybe people in CA are just not used to aquarium prices? Not sure... Don't think of it as admission, think of it as a donation to the aquarium if it makes you feel better? Anyways, definitely recommend this as a nice break to the touristy stuff after lunch or such.
author: Lizzy H.

description:
I have to agree with most of the reviewers here when they say that this place is too small and not quite worth the price. Here is a rundown of what to expect:

You walk into a rather big room with a handful of educational exhibits and tanks. Then you take an elevator down where you come to some more tanks with jellyfish and other stuff. Then you go through one curving glass tunnel, followed by a handful of more exhibits, then another curving glass tunnel which leads back to the elevators. You then take the elevator back up where you get to the 2 touch pools and a handful of other exhibits. That's it.

The place is still fun and educational. The glass tunnels were actually a great sight to see. Many interesting fish and sharks. The touch pools were good except that there was only about 4 rays and a shark, with 2 of the rays and the shark not feeling very playful and were just hanging out at the bottom. The other pool was full of starfish and well, once you touch one you pretty much have touched them all.

I was iffy on the last set of exhibits because they had non-marine animals on display (Chinchillas in an aquarium? I could go the a pet shop and see those.)

Well, this place is worth checking out but please try to get discounts because I have to agree that it is probably not worth the full price of admission.
author: Steve M.

description:
Mainly, this place is small and I think overpriced.  The underwater walkways were an interesting way to look at the fish, but kind of depressing too.  I overheard so many people talking about eating the fish- "wow, see that one, we could eat for a month off that one!"  "oh, i'm so hungry now."  "hey i think that one is named DINNER!"  etc.  Then when you walk out you are hit with a plethora of seafood restaurants.  

It took all of 1 hour to go through the whole place (and that's including buying our tickets and a stop in the bathroom and gift shop).
author: Ash B.

description:
booooooo!
The ads around the city have pictures of penguins, sea turtles, sea horses, other cool animals. This aquarium has none of those. no seals, no otters, it does have a tank full of garbage with a fish in it. The tunnels are alright, but I definitely have been to waaaaay cooler aquariums that were waaaaaay cheaper to enter. you can pet lil stingrays and the jelly fish are cool, that's the only reason why I gave two stars instead of one.
It's super tiny, really cramped and your out in 30 minutes tops.
Most of the fish look really depressed.
author: jane d.

description:
I took my great nephew to Aquarium of the Bay.  He's just 3 years old and I wasn't sure if it would be too much for him.

However, he loved it.  Upon entering the 'tunnel' he was a bit scared but quickly grew to love it.

He especially loved watching everybody else touch the darling baby stingrays.  They put half of their body out of the water like they're waving to everyone.

For a small aquarium, I think would recommend, especially for the tots!
author: patty h.

description: Honestly...not much to look at and you go through the whole aquarium fairly quickly. It's a little expensive to me for the price, but I understand they need the money to keep a place like this well-maintained. I do like the whole "under water" effect (where you walk in a hallway like this surrounded by glass and you can see the fish swimming above you). They don't really have that at Monterey Bay Aquarium, although that is clearly the better choice. There aren't as many species here either. BUT! Their touch-pool I believe is better than the Monterey Bay Aquarium in comparison because even with short arms like mines, I am able to touch the sting rays and sharks without drowning. A lot of friendly employees everywhere incase you need them for anything. I could hear a couple of tour guides giving out information and facts about the sea creatures. Also, there was someone to take your picture if you'd like to purchase them at the end. Pretty neat. Overall, an okay experience.
author: Thanh B.

description: I don't remember, but I think I bought 2 for 1 tickets on groupon. A cute place to visit and the staff are very friendly. I don't think there is an aquarium in the san jose so have to support local. I love the shark tunnel. If you are taking your time it will probably take 45 mintues to walk thourgh.
author: Thu L.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS FOR MY WEDDING IN THE FARRALON ROOM ON APRIL 2012.  I would highly recommend this venue for a small event.  All staff made the event run smoothly and the venue is beautiful.  we used the patio to have our cocktail event.  The had few rules like other events, we did not have to purchase insurance and the all the staff working that night were wonderful to our guests. 
 I have nothing but praise for all the conversations I had with meghan ford.
author: Natalia E.

description: I was kind of disappointed to be honest.  You start by seeing jelly fish and other fish. Then you take an elevator to a walk through tunnel aquarium (which for me, I have seen better) There was no "wow" factor for me. It consisted mostly of starfish and some large to small fish. It had few stingrays and like 1 shark. You then take the elevator again to the "hands on" exhibit. Now here is where they redeem themselves. You could touch a variety of stingrays, including baby ones along with small sharks. There are other "hands on" exhibits as well. Lastly, there are advertisements for their otter exhibit. They are all over Fisherman's Warf. However, the hype dramatically over sold it. My heart sank to find out that they only have 2 otters in a medium sized glass enclosure. One was sleeping...and the other hiding. The whole aquarium itself was pretty...but not worth the price.
author: Melissa P.

description: just love the tunnels!  can't wait to go back and see the river otters again!
author: Paulette M.

description: This is a pretty puny aquarium considering this is the Bay Area! I was pretty disappointed and wanted my $20 back by the end. The whole thing took about 30 minutes to walk through- and that was with stopping to look at fishes. It was super packed and the place is REALLY in size so it was hard to enjoy anything. Even the gift shop was tiny. They did give guests today complimentary movie tickets, which was nice of them. The walkthrough tunnels are pretty cool, but I've seen FAR more impressive walkthrough tunnels. There weren't even any employees standing around to ask questions to. I should have listened to the reviews and saved my time and money.
author: R R.

description: The aquarium was insanely small. For $16 tickets the place is 3stories, but its really 1 just 3 very small levels stacked on top. The tunnels you could walk through were awesome, there were 3 small ones, the touch pools were small but ok. I would give it 3stars if it wasn't for the rudest mass of 100s of kids piled into this place that really ruin it. Also you are forever in the way of someone's shitty tourist point-and-shoot camera video recording *come on you will never watch that* i had a good time because i was with my loved one but i felt bad that he paid for both our overpriced tickets, if it was half the price it would be worth it- but it's not. Spend the extra $6 per ticket to go to the Academy of Sciences aqaurium, it would be worth it
author: Brittainie B.

description: It's OK.   I think we did the entire aquarium in an hour or under.  But my son loved it, but he's 4 and honestly kids don't really care or know the difference bt good and great.  I'd go here if you are at Fisherman's Wharf and are looking to kill a bit of time, but if you're going to be going to the California Academy of Sciences, I'd save my $$ cuz there's an aquarium there too and it's SOOOO much better!
author: Esther Y.

description:
Came here acouple days ago and I actually laughed.
The aquarium is more like a small fish store.. Its 3 floors but each floor is only so big. Their "best" animal are 3 small otters. I only came here because of the Citypass and did not have time to go to the Monterey Aquarium. The Aquarium was clean and the staff were very nice but the aquarium itself was lacking. There was some fish, a few sharks, some sting rays, a couple touch pools and that was about it. The only cool things about the aquarium was the underwater walk in the fish tank. Would not recommend if you are on a budget. Way too expensive for what it is.

If you really want to go to an aquarium plan a daytrip to the Monterey Bay Aquarium (1-2 hours outside SF)
author: Ryan L.

description:
Oh Aquarium of the Bay, I was so disappointed. 

We decided to go here because we were running out of things to do but still had a lot of time to kill. For an aquarium that's in San Francisco, it was alright. I wish they had more exhibits and animals for us to see. The sharks were amazing and so were the stingrays ( remember use one finger only! ) The girl at the gift shop was kinda monotone and she seemed really uninterested with her job.
author: ROCKKSTARR h.

description: This place is nice, but on the small side and totally packed owing to its location on Pier 39, so I probably would have been disappointed had I paid the full price.  Still interesting due to its focus on SF Bay, but if I'm town again I think I'd rather go to the California Academy of Sciences aquarium.
author: Mike W.

description: After reading the reviews here we had lowered expectations.  We went with a 2 and 5 year old and thoroughly enjoyed it.  The tanks are great, the tunnels under the larger tank were great for the kids, and the touch pools were also interesting.  We spent about an hour and a half moving pretty slowly.  You could do it in an hour or stretch it to two hours but hard to do more than that.  If you are a member of a zoo or aquarium check to see if you can get half off with your membership through the Association of Zoos and Aquariums.
author: Dan W.

description:
TOTAL RIP OFF!!!
Tour was only 15 min.  What a waste of money.  My kids cried they were so dissatisfied.   Don't waste your money!   Visit the California Academy of Science in Golden Gate Park, it is high quality, not a low quality side show.
author: Zachary R.

description: While I liked my visit to the Aquarium of the Bay, I felt it was kind of small.  There were a few cool exhibits, but.. I don't know.  We spent probably 1-2 hours there. Wasn't much to see.  If you've been in one aquarium, you've been in all.
author: Emily S.

description:
If you are planning to go to Science Museum, you can skip this one,
Nothing special here at Aquarium of the Bay.
author: chao-ying w.

description: Very overpriced, and not much to see.  Save your cash for a real aquarium.  I visited about 10 years ago and this place seems to have gone downhill.  The moving sidewalk through the aquariums was broken. Plus the collection of fish is pretty slim and quite bland now.  My kids enjoyed the touch pools, but after getting wet, all the paper towel dispensers were empty.  Not well run.
author: Jeff G.

description: Came back using a free pass from our local library.  Great size for the toddler/preschool set.  Come early (around 10) and you'll have a much more enjoyable visit.  We came back after lunch for round 2 and it was considerably more crowded.
author: Chris K.

description:
We just had our company holiday party here.

It is BEAUTIFUL at night!!

Plenty of things to see and look at. The exhibits are small but awesome. There is even a touch pool! The staff is really friendly. A bit of a weird place to get to the entrance after hours.

It's was very nice!
author: Pamela R.

description:
This is a pretty small aquarium and the conveyor belts push you through it pretty quickly underneath in the lower levels, but my kids always seem to enjoy it a lot and it's a nice well-kept aquarium.

It doesn't stand out as a great aquarium, but a nice little place to visit for a short time. A bit pricey though for what it is...
author: D T.

description:
Initially, my boyfriend and I wanted to go to Alcatraz but tickets were sold out.. so we went for the next thing on the Pier.. the Aquarium of the Bay.

We came here during Christmas (2008) season, so they had a lot of Christmas trees decorated with sea creature ornaments.. pretty different.

Small aquarium but it was fun. I was too scared to touch the batrays/stingrays and the leopard sharks so my boyfriend did. All I touched was a starfish and it still freaked me out. Blehhh. I expected a lot more, like a bigger aquarium or something but it was still fun.
author: Jessica R.

description:
I loved this aquarium! At first I got really claustrophobic because I'd never been in a tunnel surrounded by water & fish like that, but once I got over the initial fear, I really enjoyed myself! I loved watching all the fish swim around us. 

They also have an interactive area where I got to pet a very friendly skate, who was so cute & very puppy like lol! I also touched a starfish, sea urchin, & a leopard shark. Very cool!

Great aquarium, I cant wait to take my daughter! =]
author: Monique R.

description:
You will not be spending a lot of time in this aquarium, because it is fairly small. The only best part is the underwater tunnel glide path, which you may have to go through twice from back to back. And they do have few interesting exhibits here and there. At the end you will enter Touch the Bay exhibit, where you can touch friendly rays. And that is always a great experience for kids.

Do avoid coming here on a busy weekend when there are too many tourists. But f I were you, I would invest the money for a ticket at the CAoS instead.
author: Zha L.

description:
The following is an exact transference of the experience going to the aquarium and putting that experience into a similarly framed textualized experience:

Water here, animals, elevator, bees, inside gift shop, bye, outside gift shop.

Short? Not horribly descriptive? Exactly.

P,S, Biggest problem: they claim to have octopi but no one knew where. Despite having a mini ante chamber dedicated to them.
author: Mitchell M.

description: We had a nice time at this 3-level aquarium.  Unkown to us, the price is $3.00 off per person if you're a AAA member and show your card so we ended up paying $12.95 per person (we just had to show one card for both discounts).  They had a lot of different types of fish brought in from the bay as well as 7-fin sharks and stingrays.  It's well organized and the staff is friendly and informative.  If you've been to places like the Monterey Aquarium then this would be on a much smaller scale but still worth seeing for the price.
author: Ruthie V.

description:
Oh look, honey!  It's the Fish Tunnel From Hell.

Kind of like an MRI with a mold condition, only the with ten times the claustrophobic vibe on account of the all the bloated tourists sharing the stale, scarce air with you.

About as fun as being locked in a Nazi submarine for three hours, but without the art direction of "Das Boot". And instead of German, everyone's speaking English with a midwestern accent (no subtitles).

Admission might possibly be considered close to reasonable if it were to include an extra large hit of PCP, the effects of which would be the only thing that could make this experience suck more.

One star for those poor, cute little fish. One more star for my night terrors.
author: Tsada K.

description:
I came here on vacation last year. It was just ok. The best part of the aquarium is the touch pools. I also saw a chinchilla there (very cute!) but my biggest gripe about this place is that it was expensive ($16) and small! The underwater area was very short. It was cool to see the sharks but felt like the exhibit wasn't big enough.

Also, why were there three gift shops? Some of that vast expanse could have been another tank of jellyfish or something.

The staff was nice and knowledgable. The octopus display was very cool. I don't think I'd come back here next time I'm in town though
author: Valerie B.

description: Overpriced, not much to it. I was babysitting an 11-year-old, and her response was, "Is this it?" I'd pay 10 bucks for this but no more.
author: Jax R.

description:
If you are hands on, want to touch everything in sight kinda kid at heart, this is a really cool place to do that. I came here with my cousin and my niece and we spent a considerable amount of time petting the leopard sharks (scary for a scaredy cat like me) & the bat rays (velvety smooth, they are pretty friendly & put on a good show of splashing you once in a while.) 

In the aquarium, we saw the "finding nemo" fish, jelly fish that are graceful & mesmerizing & fish that are straight up fugly, but still interesting to watch.

The star of the show is the tunnel. You can either walk at your own pace or step on the moving belt that takes you through. Admittedly, the tunnel is not very long, but you get to see tons of sea life in action. I love staring up, open mouthed, to see a SHARK pass a few feet over my head. 

The price is $16 for adults, which is a bit steep, but given the area (touristy Fisherman's Wharf) I wouldn't expect a deal. There are bigger, better aquariums in SF (the zoo, Academy of Sciences, etc) but if you are at/near the Wharf, you might as well check it out.
author: Fancypants X.

description: It was pretty small and overpriced. $18 per person and we were done in 60 minutes. To compare, the zoo was $15 and we spent hours there. I would skip it, there's nothing here that can't be found at the Monterey Aquarium.
author: Sami S.

description: My nephews 1st birthday was here and it was pretty neat. He enjoyed it and the adults enjoyed it as well. The squid is awesome. And the tunnel is really cool but I wish they had more. It's not even close to what you get at the Monterey Bay Aquarium but it was cute and I wouldnt refuse to go again.
author: John C.

description:
I liked the aquarium. True, it's no Monterey Bay, but for the decent price and tunnel thing it was worth it for me. It's about the same price as a movie these days without the extras for popcorn and soda. Also, look for coupons around the Wharf, you can usually get $2.00 off on admission.

It doesn't take that long to go through, but what you do see is pretty cool. Yes, the fishes from the bay area are indeed ugly, but it is kinda neat looking at the bay's eco-system. The petting tanks with the sting rays and leopard sharks, is pretty cool too.
author: Robin K.

description:
Yes, it's a tourist trap and yes, it's expensive for what it is, BUT you can almost always get some kind of deal and this aquarium is very cool for what it is--a small aquarium. Go during the off season when it's not packed with tourists and put some of your favorite music on your iPod while watching fish swimming around and above you.

The aquarium is well kept. It is clean, well lit and the unusual layout of the tank gives the fish plenty of room to swim around.

True, it's not the Monterey Bay Aquarium or even the Academy of Sciences, but it's good for what it is.
author: John R.

description: Took my son, hubby, brother in law and kids here on a Saturday morning. I had bought discounted tickets on TravelZoo, $9 each and my son is under age 3, so he was free. The aquarium is small, but huge to our toddler! He loved it! The sting rays and turtles were his faves. I think the regular price $18 each is way too high, but I would definetely return for the discounted price. I was very happy we went early. It wasnt crowded and we could walk at our own pace, letting the kids enjoy it all!
author: kati m.

description: Nice place to take your little ones, big ones will get board easy but its still pretty cool for the price.  The walk thru is very cool and the fact you can really touch the fish in the touch pool is nice.  Take the kids have lunce at the pier and play tourist for a day can be a great outing
author: Shirley W.

description:
Lame.  I wanted to go to Monterey yesterday but I was thwarted.  I came here instead to get my aquarium fix.

At least they have an octopus.  That's what the second star is for: the octopus is pretty awesome.  And they have her in this weird pink-lit tank, which kind of makes her look like an Old West saloon girl among the rest of the kind of dumb exhibits.

Oh yeah, there WAS one other cool part: the ray and shark petting tank.  I don't know if the rays do this every day, but when I was there, they would breach the water and poke their little faces out, like they were competing for attention or trying to get a better look at people.  Super-cute!  For rays, at least.  As cute as stingrays can possibly get.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description: It's a bit pricey for such a small aquarium, in the end you're left saying "that's it?" I wouldn't go back and I don't recommend anyone going. You pretty much go through the whole thing in 20min.
author: Irma R.

description:
Just your average run of the mill aquarium. We've been to the one in Long Beach which seemed to offer a lot more. The best part was the tunnel where you felt like you were actually swimming with the sharks and other creatures. 

I think kids would enjoy it a lot more than us two 20-somethings did.
author: Chrim K.

description: This is one of my favorite places in the world. Okay, maybe I'm biased because I used to volunteer there, but still love it! It's not quite as glamorous as some of the other aquariums in the area, and doesn't house as many exotic fish, but the purpose of it is to display the diversity of aquatic life in the bay...and that it does. They recently acquired 3 new octopi, and last I heard, they also had 7 sevengill sharks, which are really magnificent to see in person. Most of the creatures are displayed in tunnels so it feels like you're walking under the bay. Lotsa fun...been inside the tanks a whole buncha times, but it's always still cool to do the walk through. Love this place.
author: Janelle L.

description: For an aquarium this place was really lacking. Only reason we went was because it was included in our SFCitypass. The only thing this place had over the CA academy of sciences was the tunnel. Might be better for kids with a shorter attention span who would melt down at the sight of a real museum.
author: Laura N.

description: Great Location for a event!!  Best view! Christina & Nicole, thank you for all the details to prep the event and working things out with us. Breanne went above and beyond to take care of us. Even trying to fix the slide show that was not her job. Breanne you live up to your cool hair! You rock:)
author: Suzanne G.

description:
This place did change a lot ever since I came here when I was a kindergartner. My little cousin has never been here before so I brought her here when it was in April, we were in Fisherman's Wharf Area anyways. I remember there was this whole exhibits about the leopard shark and there was this bridge that you can walk on and there is this pond-ish area where the leopard sharks swam free in. 

+:There is a walkway and there is a moving walk way soo if you ever want to walk ahead you just step right off of the walk way. All of the workers were very knowledgeable about where the animals came from. It turns out that they do not keep the animals for more then several months, after several months they would be released into the Pacific Ocean. The petting tanks were so cool! You can touch starfishes, sting rays, sharks, and I forgot about one more marine animal.

-: Not really much to see. May be if I were still a little kid I would like this more.
author: Janet Z.

description: You can see sharks, touch rays, and hand feed the critters in the tidal pool.  The staff are crazy about their job and interesting. And yet, it's sadly out of date, and there's the crap hawking Pier 39 element that makes a local shudder.
author: Lempi M.

description: This is our second time coming here. This time it was special due to it being our son's birthday. He got a shark crown, and was super excited the whole time! I really love their Jelly fish section, they are just such amazing creatures. The under water tunnel is great, makes you feel so close to all the fish, almost like if you can touch them. But I would have to say that the best part is the touching exhibit. My son had a blast touching bat rays and baby sharks! He honestly would not move from this exhibit. All in all we had a great time.
author: Flower P.

description: This is the absolute worst excuse for an aquarium EVER it's a huge worthless tourist trap!!! Don't even waste the 15 or 20 minutes it takes to go through it just to see like 3 different types of fish.
author: Kelly J.

description: Who would have thought that the Seattle Aquarium is the better of the two!  This is an extremely small aquarium consisting on mainly two underwater tunnels.  It is a tourists trap and it is not worth spending the money or the time to go there.  If you really want to go to an aquarium in the SF area, go to the one at the California Academy of Sciences.
author: Jean P.

description: It wasn't the most stellar aquarium and there isn't anything too unique about this place. It's a place featuring fish from around that can be found in and around San Francisco. Having said that, we did have a pretty good time. Despite being a fairly small aquarium, the tunnel was pretty cool and full of some pretty neat fish. The staff was friendly and knowledgeable. The otters (really the main attraction) were sleeping by the time we got to them, but that isn't exactly the aquarium's fault - otters gotta sleep sometime.
author: E E.

description: First time coming here and it was more fun than I anticipated.  I was told I shouldn't have my camera flash on for the octopus tank because they are sensitive to light.  I later saw many people taking pictures with flash... at least 10.  They should have a sign clearly posted for the benefit of their animals.
author: Victor L.

description: For the price of a family membership vs. a one day pass, go for the membership and if you can afford it, upgrade to include the magic show - Timothy Noonan does not disappoint and was enjoyable for adults and children of all ages. The exhibits were well done and worth every penny for the tickets. Our only disappointment was missing the three giant squid which are said to sometimes move around. The Sea Otters were adorable, but inactive and napping all day. Staff is young and enthusiastic about making sure you enjoy the features in order and as designed. Great date with family or with friends.
author: Jenn D.

description: I love aquariums, but I was pretty disappointed with this one. For $15, they say you can spend about an hour touring it, but I walked through it in about 30 minutes, if not less. (I also spent like 5 minutes in the bathroom washing my hands.) There is a little room in the back which is really a joke. There are papers and pennies on the table with an activity that tells you to guess how many drops of water can fit onto a penny, and then they give you a dropper and a penny to actually sit there and figure out the exact number. Because we can't just Google it. There is also a tub with starfish and sea cucumbers which you can stick your finger in to pet the sea animals. It's sad, but the part I enjoyed the most was walking through a gift shop you must go through to get to the entrance, where there stood a huge statue of Spongebob Squarepants.
author: Cheryl L.

description: ugh...what a total waste of money... that was the saddest aquarium I have ever been to...trust me, skip it and check out the one in Monterey
author: Tiffany H.

description:
If I could give you no star, I would.

I got free tickets and thank god for that, i would have been pissed if i had to pay 15 dollars for a dirty, smelly lazy place like this, and yea the fish in this aquarium, it would be more interesting if you row out in the bay yourself.

The kids are playing with the poor fishes and it smells more like diaper than an aquarium, i will never ever go there again.

I have more free tickets if you want?
author: cecilia k.

description: Lame.  There are only a few exhibits and it's really small.  The staff is helpful and knowledgeable.  It wasn't super expensive though, and it did give us a deal on a bay tour which was cool.  I have no need to ever go back.
author: J. H.

description:
The aquarium is small compared with some, but I liked it better than many much larger aquariums.  It was plenty big enough for us to spend an hour and a half happily, and the long, winding, underwater tunnels were like nothing I have seen elsewhere.  (Other aquariums sometimes have tunnels, but nothing like this.)  

One thing that may not be obvious:  This is a *great* aquarium for a toddler in a stroller, because all the exhibits are visible from the stroller.   In many aquariums you will get tired from holding the kid up to see into the tanks.  Here everything is visible from toddler eye-level, and my toddler had a great view from the stroller.   Check out the tank that features the bottom-dwelling fish, for example.  I imagine that this might be a benefit for someone in a wheelchair also.

They had the best-displayed octopus I  have ever seen.  Usually aquarium octopuses are hiding in some crevice and you cannot get a good look at them.  This aquarium's octopus was a Giant Pacific Octopus and it was huge and perfectly visible.
author: Sudo N.

description:
It's a bit confusing to me why people complain about the size of this aquarium, and completely miss the fact the purveyors of this establishment have done an awesome job building an aquarium on pier already cramped with retail and restaurants. The multiple story design is a great way utilize space, and the elevator ride down to the underwater tunnels gives you a sense of descending to depths of the bay. 

Another thing that endears to me to Aquarium of the Bay, is that they take an active role in conservation, and public awareness in regards to the state of our oceans and their inhabitants. The employees are without exception passionate and knowledgeable about the aquatic life in their care, and are quick to answer any questions you may have.

While Aquarium of the Bay may not be as big and built up as the Monterey Bay Aquarium, it does what it sets out to do, and that is to provide a "fish eye" view of life in the San Francisco Bay.
author: C P.

description:
I used to work at the Aquarium of the Bay so take that for what you will with my 5 star review, but I really love and miss this place, and wanted to clear up some things written here in reviews.

Firstly, it is a relatively small aquarium, I'll admit that.  However, if you make it through here in 20 minutes then I'm afraid you're not really looking, listening, and discovering what the aquarium has to offer!  There are thousands of fish in there!  Also, check the time board for presentations going on all day!  There are live feedings every day and presentations going on ALL the time that guests miss!  Don't miss them! I used to feed the bat rays in the touch pools every day and talk all about how they live and eat and people seemed to really enjoy it!

Also, some folks mentioned things about fish "just floating" or "just swimming around" and even "dead" and "belly up."  The Aquarium of the Bay has vets and husbandry staff on every day that dive in the main tunnel tanks to check on the animals, making sure they're happy and healthy.  The fish that these folks are referring to as dead or floating are actually a type of fish called "Rock Fish." Their behavior is to do just that, look like rocks!  They're very common in the bay!  They have poison in those barbs on their backs!  THEY'RE SO COOL!  Other injuries you might spot are animals the aquarium has found in the wild and rehabilitated (like Lenny the White Sturgeon, who lost his whiskers and has difficulty searching for food in the wild) or injuries due to common behaviors in the wild (such as female Leopard Sharks getting their fins bit during mating season).

Lastly someone mentioned the leopard sharks in the touch pools being "drugged" and motionless and "boring", they're not drugged, and that's actually a good thing that they're still for the benefit of the sharks, that means they're very calm.  Those sharks are very young, and when they get excited or scared, they could thrash around and possibly jump out of the tanks and injure themselves.  The aquarium has to have smaller/shallower tanks so the little ones can touch the animals, but that also entails having very calm, relaxed young sharks.

Hope that clears up some things.  If this is viewed as an advertisement because I am a former employee, then that's understandable I guess.  I just wanted to clear up some misinformation.  

Remember that aquariums are for you to view the animals, not for the animals to give you a song and dance routine.  They're wild creatures, and deserve our curiosity and wonder based on their own merits, even if they look like rocks, heh heh.
author: Becky G.

description: Great lil spot on the pier, staff were friendly but not over friendly great looking exhibits and some huge sharks and fish. Good visit for a rainy day!
author: Samuel M.

description:
It's been a long time since I've stepped foot inside of an aquarium.  If not for our holiday party, I would have easily overlook this one too, especially with Academy of Science so close by and the infamous Monterey Bay Aquarium within an hour drive.

This aquarium is very small but the space is utilized perfectly.  Lots of cool exhibits, my favorite being the jelly fishes.  Somehow the only thing I can think of, however, is the movie Seven Pounds.  I really enjoyed the tunnel on the first floor.  It's quite refreshing to watch all the fish swim by and able to see the underside.  Our group especially enjoyed the domes that allowed you to stick your head into the fish tanks.  Oh and they have this pool where you can pet sting rays!  Again, someone mentioned the crocodile hunter and no one decided to stick their hand in the water.

I probably won't return as I've sort of "been there done that" but it's a great place for anyone who's looking for a change of pace.  A good place for a 1st date too!
author: Jenn G.

description:
I enjoyed my visit to the Aquarium of the Bay this past weekend. I never even thought of going to the aquarium on past visits to San Francisco because other have been expensive and disappointing. 
I was delighted! I truly never expected an aquarium in a tourist area to be such a good representative of indigenous sea life, nor to be so educational. There were a number of activities for preschool - elementary aged children and amusing photo ops like an aquarium with a bubble from the bottom so children (and myself) could have my picture taken inside the aquarium. The staff was knowledgeable, twice I asked a question that they couldn't answer, so they went and got the answer, and found me to tell me what I wanted to know! That is rare customer service! Thank you!!

They have two smaller aquariums that contain two different kinds of jellyfish- that were in pristine condition. Absolutely beautiful! The lighting is excellent and the water is clean enough that you can really see them... see through them... watch them move inches from you. Mesmerizing.

The glass tube was surprisingly long and gave a long opportunity to watch the behavior of the fish. There is a moving walkway for those who just want a quick view and a stationary walkway for those like myself who want to linger and watch the behavior of the animals. (Sea World does not offer an opportunity to go at your own speed!)
The schools of silver fish (sardines) that make shapes in the movie "Finding Nemo", they really swim together in a bunch like that (of course they don't really mimic faces). I've never been to an aquarium that had large schools of fish that allow you to see how they act together! Fascinating!

My absolute favorite was the petting grotto... I got to pet a bat ray! The bat ray's were friendly and not stressed out. What a treat! There are also small shark to pet, healthy sea anemone, sea cucumber, a variety of healthy looking starfish to touch. There is a honey bee exhibit that is pretty interesting too!

All in all, the message about protecting the planet and its creatures was consistent but not political, and backed up by sea life that is well cared for- you will not feel guilty enjoying this aquarium, the animals are well kept!

I see reviews of people who were disappointed... maybe they were expecting the Shamu show? I'm guessing they tromped through with the energy of the city and didn't take time to see all the little surprises throughout the building from start to finish! 

My thanks to Aquarium Of The Bay for a lovely afternoon! Next time I will do the behind the scenes tour too!
author: Julie A.

description: If you wanna waste a half hour then this is the place for you. I dont why San Fran settles for the bottom of the barrel when it comes to their zoo and aquarium. The only thing I think that was worth while was the touch pool. Pretty disappointing. This is just another tourist trap. Seriously.
author: Lonnie G.

description:
Don't waste your time or hard earned $.  Why?  Many dead fish in the tank, questionable safety for little ones around the "petting" ponds. 

The whole experience lasts about 20 minutes and leaves you asking "is that it?"
author: James D.

description: If you're already at Pier 39, its a fine place to stop.  If you want a really good aquarium go to the Academy of Science.  Yes the Academy is relatively expensive but you get soooo much more.
author: Beckie L.

description:
We had free tickets and only had to pay $7 for my son. 
Its a nice little aquarium, but nothing like Monterey. 
I think we were in and out in less then 20minutes.
author: Charles C.

description:
This place is so jammed back on a Saturday, but what do you expect from a touristy area. 

There are friendly people who work here who are glad to answer any of your questions. 

Lots of cool photo opportunities and you can get up close and personal with the sea creatures of the bay area. 
 
The exhibits are pretty cool, but why add lizards/chinchillas/bees in the mix? Sort of strange....
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Ehhhh, thanks, but no thanks.

This aquarium is comparable to any other aquarium.  It seems big from the outside since it's two floors, but it's actually pretty tiny.  It's more of a tourist trap than anything else, but I'd say it's worth stopping by at for an hour or so if you've purchased the "City Pass" -- just in order to get your moneys worth for the City Pass.

Some things this aquarium has going for it are...
 - the two walk-through tunnels.  It's a pretty cool experience to see fish swimming overhead, but other than that it lacks a lot of other interesting exhibits.  
- there's also a few touch tanks where you can pet baby manta-rays and baby sharks.
- super friendly staff :) which can always help to enhance an experience.

One of the weird things about this "aquarium" was the bee exhibit (not sure how bees are an aquatic animal, but whatevs.)  There was also a chinchilla exhibit thrown in there too.

Anyway, overall, again -- if you're going in order to get your moneys worth for the City Pass -- go ahead, if you have time.  If you're actually gonna pay for the admission -- don't bother.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
