Eh, it was ok...definitely not worth $16 to get in. Fortunately, we got free passes from my work to go, otherwise, we wouldn't spend that kind of money on it.

The place is nice, but way too packed. This is probably a great place to bring your kids, but please, don't let them run around the place without supervision. We were in and out in about 15 minutes and that was us taking our time and going thru the tunnels twice!

The concept is nice....you are basically under water as the fish in the ocean swim by you. There is two tunnels you could walk through, first tunnel is in the more shallow part of the ocean, the second is deeper into the ocean, with more bigger fish and sharks there.

If we have kids some day, I might consider bringing them....but then again, I probably would spend a little extra and take them to the Monterrey Bay Aquarium instead.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Aquarium of the Bay:

You are an aquarium that focuses on the fish of the San Francisco Bay. But San Francisco fish are ugly. You need some color. The San Francisco Bay Area is a community of immigrants, from all over the planet. Why not make your fish selection reflect this? 

You gave me a bag of free fossilized shark's teeth when I visited. In fact, you gave these to every visitor that day. Why? Did you think somebody who didn't already want to see a bunch of fish would suddenly be enticed because the big banner outside that read   "Today Only! Free Shark's Teeth with Every Admission!" would change their mind? What is wrong with you?

You have Little Nemo references. I don't care if there ARE little kids running around your halls who have been brainwashed by Disney. You are an aquarium. Do you think that zoos put signs on their elephants: "This is Dumbo". On their lions: "This is Simba". They do not. Because little kids are more excited by the fact that they are in the presence of real, live animals than they are the fact that the real, live animals in their presence resemble Disney cartoons.

You play smooth jazz. Throughout the entire aquarium. When you're on a conveyor belt completely encased in a tube looking at big ass fish swim right over your head, smooth jazz is not right. Play Brian Eno. Ask the sushi chefs at Hanabi for some recommendations. Just, please stop playing that stuff. The fish hate it.

You have to take elevators between exhibits, and you have to wait for an elevator operator. Why? We can all press the buttons ourselves. We are stupid, but not that stupid. And do you think the elevator operators like their job? Listening to smooth jazz, pressing buttons with arrows on them, fake smiling, in fluorescent light for 8 hours a day? 

You have brochures for sleepovers. For little kids. This scares me, the fact that a few hours before my arrival, twenty twelve-year-old girls could have been having a pillow fight and eating Fruity Pebbles on the ground where I stand to look at fish. That's fucked up. For the fish, too. Do you think they can sleep when there are dozens of whiners wearing pink pajamas and squealing?
author: Ben P.

description:
This aquarium was a delightful break from all the sideshow rip-offs on Pier 39.  I'd heard it was jenky and small.  However, I think it was every bit as high quality as the Monterey Aquarium -- just much smaller.  I absolutely LOVED the tunnels where the bat rays and sharks swim right over your head.  My nephew, boyfriend and I spent an hour in the tunnel, watching in delight, and talking about every single fish.  My nephew is still talking about getting to pet a real shark!  They let kids touch small leopard sharks.  He bragged about it to every kid he met at the zoo, the next day.

This is a nice little aquarium.  Well done, well put together, and provided a great evening for the three of us.  Unlike many museum-style attractions, it actually stays open until 8pm.
author: Amy A.

description:
I like this place better than the Monterrey Bay Aquarium.  I know, it's total blasphemy, but I can handle Georgians better than I can handle screaming 3 year olds, and while the Aquarium of the Bay is packed full of the former, Monterrey Bay Aquarium is packed full of the latter.

The moving tunnel o' fish is really neat.  One warning: the curved ceiling distorts things ever so slightly, so if things seem to bend and flex while the swim over you, tell your inner ear that it's an optical delusion, and to stop trying to make you barf.  And don't PM me to tell me it's supposed to be optical ILLusion.  I know that, and my need to explain the joke to you is ruining it for everyone else.  Is that what you wanted?  Well, now it's ruined.  I hope you're happy.

All in all, the Aquarium of the Bay does a very good job with the limited space they have.  Admission is also reasonable.  Anyone who lives in the city should go at least once.  Also: great place to go with out-of-town relatives.  Especially if they're from Georgia, because I have it on good and repeated authority that Georgians find this place keeeeeewwll.  Their word, not mine.
author: Ben P.

description: Not worth $40 per person.  Enjoyed visuals and Open Sea exhibit but it was only significant exhibit to warrant tix price
author: Mike R.

description:
Even though this aquarium is small - I LOOOOVED the tunnels.  I specifically took my family here on a Thursday so that we could catch the shark feeding.  The first time we went through the tunnels, we were busy taking pictures of the sharks and bat rays.  We had time to kill before the shark feeding, so we got our hands stamped and wandered around before coming back.  The second time we went through the underground tunnels, we just simply enjoyed looking at large variety of fish and being slightly creeped out by the sharks that were swimming right up at us.  

Normal ticket price is $15.95, but you can get a $2 coupon from any of those SF tourist map books.  It's actually great to go back through the exhibits twice because you miss stuff the first time around.  Right now (May '09) there is a new exhibit of huuuge jellyfish and a ginormous octopus too.  Overall, a fun experience!
author: Diana N.

description:
The tubes under the water were pretty cool and there were some cool creatures that I wasn't expecting but this is definitely not one of the best aquariums out there. It's decent and you can go through it in a couple of hours or less depending on how much time you spend in the touchy feely area.

We used a greenzebra coupon so we were half off. I wouldn't want to pay more than than since we're locals and can wait for a deal if we wanted to go.
author: Glenn G.

description: Went there yesterday for the very first time. Nice set up. Couple of things to see. Like the sharks, jelly fish,octopus and all sorts of fish. Took out one star because the place is very small and there can be more done to provide a better experience to patrons. Otherwise great place to go to for a family outing. Nice restaurants nearby also.
author: Ronald S.

description: Decent exhibits but horrible walking traffic design/stairs/elevator situation, i.e. go to top floor then basement then middle floor. Earlier I said no drinking fountains, there are 2, at the very end haha.
author: T A.

description: Are you for real? FOR REAL? This is so tiny of an aquarium! Have you seen a smaller one before? I honestly dont think the price for admission is worth it. From what I remember it only seems like three rooms. There's the underwater tunnel which is the best part.. and probably the main thing in there. Small petting area too
author: Veranna N.

description: If you've been to the Monterey Aquarium or another world class place you'll be disappointed but it was still a fun little outing. Had a half price pass for $9 each which I felt was fair--had I paid $18 a person this review would be a different story. Although like we said, sometimes it's nice to tour a smaller place like this rather than an overwhelming all day experience.  The tunnels with people movers were pretty cool. The octopus was hella cool though I kind of felt bad for him, he was pretty big and in a pretty small space. God, aren't some animals strange? We were tripping out on the jellyfish, octopus, turtles, etc. The world is an amazing place which such varied species. I sound high but am not :)
author: D R.

description:
I have to confess, I am Aquarium spoiled. Atlanta, New Orleans, Long Beach- all first rate experiences. This just felt, well, a little inferior. Old. Dated. Tired. Dark.
But I LOVE the Aquarium, and I want more people to visit, so I feel compelled to give it 4-stars!

Must sees:
The JELLYFISH!! 
Awesome sharks!

So, go! Spend your money at the Aquarium! And maybe one day we'll have shiny, new facilities worthy of our great creatures of the deep!
author: Carnley P.

description:
I took my first grade class here.  They made us wait outside for 45 minutes in the rain and the cold for our tour even though we had a reservation.  They would NOT let us wait in the lobby.  So I had 20 wet, miserable, crying, whining, 6 year olds on my hands.  It was supposed to be FUN. 

The place is great for kids once you get inside, but for me, this was totally overshadowed by their terrible treatment of us.
author: Katie E.

description: I had to be in the city for a short time Tuesday morning.  Visited the Aquarium while I was up there.  It was a nice experience.  What made it so was the employees.  All were smiling, friendly, knowledgeable and helpful.  They engaged us with great info and banter that made the experience!
author: Greer T.

description:
Just took my 15 m.o. there today with a couple of buddies. Was not sure what they will take from this trip, but we had the free passes from the local library - so even with the expense of the parking, it was worth checking it out and we mad e a nice little trip out of it. 
What we liked is: it is small enough that you can go through it all and not feel overwhelmed and you don't feel like you are missing something; it has several tanks with different creature and it is quite colorful; it has a petting room at the very end; the moving part of the walkway was convenient for the strollers and fun for the toddlers.
Not so great: it is not cheap if you  go as a family  especially with kids over 3 ( check out your library for free passes, also if you park in the parking lot right across from pier 39 the parking ticket usually has a discount coupon). It is not that big (it was good for us) but if you compare to the Monterrey, it is a much smaller place. Parking is expensive (unless you are patient enough to look for street parking).

If you have a young child and wonder if it's too early - I think it is not! Kids under 3 are free, so it's worth it and they really are fascinated but all the underwater life!
author: Eva D.

description:
This is like Monterey Bay Aquariums little sister who ran away to the big city to sell her body where the tourists hang out. It can still give you a good time, but watch out cause you can catch something, like "Annoying Tourists Disease". Be sure to wear protection when you go through the tunnel.
Wait for the high class Steinhart Aquarium when they open, at least you might catch a less contagious disease like "Annoying School Children Syndrome"
author: Brian J.

description: The only reason that I gave this 3 stars instead of 2 is because they do have a pretty cool tunnel type arrangement where you can walk through and see fish swimming above your head. The rest of this place is mediocre at best. It's tiny and high priced, I suggest visiting monterrey bay aquarium over this any day.
author: Ashley A.

description:
This place is amazing....  The Aquarium has two HUGE crystal clear tunnels that you can see the fish swimming around.  The second tunnel is the best (this is where you can see the sharks).   You really become face-to-face with a diverse array of creatures (its like your swimming with them).

After the tunnel you can then go to the top floor where there are a  few shallow pools.  In these shallow pools you can touch live bat rays, leopard sharks, skates and several different type of star fish...  THIS PLACE IS GREAT FOR EVERYONE...  Great for locals and tourist.
author: kristy g.

description:
if i had the option to give 0 stars or even negative stars this place would def be it..

i loveee aquariums and was pretty excited to check it out since i've never been..sooo disappointing. it's so tiny and cramped inside that our group was in and out of there in 30 min maybe an hr tops-and we were taking our time! there's a teeny tunnel to walk through and depressing looking fishies swimming around. the jellyfish and touch pool were ok. i wouldn't come here again or recommend this place to anyone.. so glad none of us had to pay that day.
author: Raquel T.

description: I really loved the two walk through tunnels. It was very cool to see sharks and other giant fish swim right next to/over you. However, that's pretty much all this aquarium is. Two tunnels, two small jelly fish tanks and an area that includes two aquatic spaces where you can actually touch some animals. This space is intermingled with various non-aquatic animals to check out as well. It took 45 minutes to get through this place and cost $30 for two people. Kinda-sorta a rip-off.
author: Hannah F.

description:
I went to the aquarium with a friend and her child.
I bought a Groupon for 2.  It was easy to get in.  Once you are in - you find out pretty quick how small the place is.  I agree with previous reviews on the underwhelming aspect of this facility.

Positives:
Great location - got a chance to hang out at Pier 39 - it had been about 7 or 8 years
Liked the jellyfish
Liked the tunnel o fish

Negatives:
Don't allow strollers inside - have a "parking lot" for strollers at the front door
SMALL!
Not much to see

Because it was Groupon - it was ok - but I would not pay $15.95 to enter...
author: Square P.

description:
There were not many unique animals here but it did depict the local animals quite well including a hands on portion allowing you to "pet" a shark and bat ray! 

This is geared towards children and tourism and not something you would visit more than once. 

They also have many visual demonstrations of the destructive effects happening in the bay (such as oil contamination) without offering an action of response...more like "here is what it is, take it or leave it." 

We were able to take advantage of discounts through the library which made the event worth while. Their ticket prices were pretty high from what I remembered on the sign. 

Overall, if you haven't seen fish, nor been to an aquarium, then give this a shot, otherwise...move on elsewhere.
author: Michael K.

description:
You are kidding, right? $14.95 per adult for 35 minutes worth of exploration? As my dad would say, "Does that include vaseline?" 

Allow me to sum up the experience for you:

1) Pay more than it costs to get into the Academy of Sciences, and make your way into the first series of exhibits [1 minute]

2) Dig the "Sardine Typhoon", check out the two other fish tanks, watch some videos and dig on some maps [8 minutes]

3) Ride the Elevator of Doom(c)(tm) down to the lower level. [2 minutes, including wait]

4) Marvel at the tunnel of fish as you either walk through it or ride the people mover that will carry your lazy ass through it. Enjoy the sensation of seasickness as the warp of the tunnel messes with your sense of balance. [6 minutes]

5) Feel the increase in your sense of wonder as you arrive oh so quickly at the end of the tunnel, returned already to the Elevator of Doom(c)(tm). [1 minute]

6) Ride up to the top floor where you can finally touch stuff. Like bat rays and leopard sharks. [16 minutes]

7) Exit through the over-priced gift shop, straight on to over-priced Pier 39. [1 minute]

8) Check your watch: "35 minutes! We're making great time! Let's head over to the Wax Museum and see if we can make it an even $100/hour!"

They should at least offer some sort of discount for bay area residents. Because even though Little Q loves this place, I won't be taking him to another local aquarium until the Academy of Sciences reopens.

The "Catch of the Day" at Aquarium of the Bay is tourist dollars.  Don't believe the tripe.
author: Greg Q.

description:
I love not waiting, I love no crowds, I love being able to find parking! I love being able to stay at an exhibit for however long you want to.  I love being on vacation! 

So my family and a close family friend decided to take the kids to San Francisco to visit the California Academy of Sciences.  Of course the day we planned ended up being a Wachovia Wednesday, so I anticipated a crowd.  Realizing that there would be traffic in the morning we left San Jose before 830 in hopes that traffic would have subsided a bit.  Well we were stuck on 19th for more than 30 minutes, and as we approached the park within 6 blocks or so, it was evident that we were going to be facing some traffic to enter the area.  After one attempt at passing through, and the kids restless and antsy we decided to make an impromptu detour to the Pier.  

It was the best decision we made all week.  No crowds, no parking problems, and an aquarium we have never visited.  Of course I didn't anticipate very much, and when expectations are low, simple surprises can definitely make your day.  Right we entered our ocean loving son when into "Aquarium Guide" mode making sure each and every one of us were educated about the sea creatures.  Below in the under water tunnels the treads were not working so we were free to walk as slow as we pleased.  The boy was in heaven.  

Thinking that the tour was done after the tunnels, it was a nice surprise to  see the touch pools at the end of the exhibit.  This place has the best touch pools.  They've got rays and sharks, and we had no crowds to fight.   Lots of fun.  I just wish we had more time, we definitely wanted to make another way around before leaving the city. 

A little steep on the price for such a small establishment, but I would like to visit here again.
author: Sheryl L.

description: This is a very small aquarium but its also not that expensive. I enjoyed going here they really hi-light the sea life that is in the San Francisco bay which is nice. It doesnt take long to get through the aquarium but again you arent paying 30+ like in Monterey. Check them out but dont go there expecting what you get at the Monterey Bay aquarium.
author: Kristin E.

description: Outstanding experience! I thought the exhibits were very cool and the staff knowledgeable, friendly and courteous. My kids also loved the spot and we plan another adventure very soon!
author: Jimmy W.

description: Beautiful, awesome, way too small, way too expensive. Nothing unusual, nothing I haven't seen before, but boy I was disappointed  way to expensive for a maybe 15 min tour with no tour guy. And your usual fish / creatures.....:(
author: Mia L.

description:
Definitely one of the smallest aquariums I have ever been too but pretty fun anyway. The upstairs exhibit is pretty mediocre, just some salt water fish tanks with a bunch of fish I have seen before and can probably buy at your local pet store. The lower floor has 2 big tanks of jelly fish that are pretty cool (and very hypnotic to watch) and a tunnel aquarium you can walk through. The tunnel is not very big but there were some pretty cool fish in there, lots of leopard sharks and these enormous sea bass. The high light of the aquarium, for me, was the little petting tank when you go back upstairs. They have baby leopard sharks, bat rays and skate that you can touch. 

Kind of pricey for such a small place but walk into any hotel in the area and grab a brochure for it and you can get $2 off admission for adults and $1 off for children.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Underwater world is silent and this aquarium is a complete opposite. I wasn't even able to see because of all the noise kids and adults around you produce, the tube echo quadrupled the noise. It would only worth if no one there. 
Oh! I figured out a solution, one needs earplugs. They should offer it with the ticket :)
author: Irina N.

description:
Unfortunately my hours spent staring at the fish tank screensaver have not made me a fish tank connoisseur, so I may not be qualified for an expert review.  Instead, my rating is based on how much time one can kill at the aquarium.

This aquarium is tiny and did not offer much information for the curious.  Too much of the ooo and ahhh factor was dependent on not so interesting video installations.  However, I did become temporarily mesmerized by the rotating cloud of sardines.  This lasted until one of my friends reminded me of the free dinner that brought me to the Aquarium in the first place.

The full immersion tank in the basement is pretty cool ~ but is void of interactivity.  There is a petting zoo of sorts, but I didn't feel like contaminating my hands, as free dinner was getting cold.  One of my less germaphobic friends won some free schwag by answering some trivia while feeling up some fish; the schwag was so exciting that I can't quite remember what it was.  

In short, the Aquarium is a great place to go if you happen to be in the area and your college alumni organization is offering free admission and free dinner.
author: Vikash G.

description:
For a shark lovers, this is the place to go.

For sushi lovers, don't you want to see the actual fish of the sashimi you crave?

You can touch star fish and sea urchin at the open pool area.

Yes, the place is tiny, but it's nice to have the aquarium experience w/o driving to Monterey.

Easiest way to get there is to take the F line up.  It drops you right out front.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
OK, it's not the biggest or best aquarium ever, but it's great that so many people who are visiting the otherwise carbon copy shops and restaurants along the piers get a chance to see ocean life.  We all need to connect with out oceans more before it's too late.

I love walking through the tube.  I end up going around a few times to make it worth my while.  

My advice - join one of the aquariums that has reciprocal or discounted memberships to other aquariums so you can see a new one where ever you visit.  Really, a lot of these aquariums are overpriced in my book, but my only consolation is that I know I'm supporting something good and will keep us in touch with our oceans enough so that we don't completely destroy them.  I hope.
author: Surf R.

description:
My hubby and I took the kids for a mini-vacation in San Francisco last weekend (coincidentally the worst weather of the season).  On our second day, after naps all around, we headed to the aquarium.  I had heard so-so things from a friend and read the reviews here so I wasn't expecting much.  

I LOVE that they stay open into the evening -- when it's been raining for two days straight and the kids (almost 5 and almost 2) are antsy after nap, it is wonderful to have a dry place to go.  

There weren't a lot of other people there so we had the run of the place.  We only stayed for about 40 minutes (a pretty good value with half off tickets with our Sacramento Zoo membership) because the bigger kid was freaked out by the tunnels and didn't want to touch anything.  The very next morning, she was begging to go back so the trauma was short lived.  

While I wouldn't make a special trip just for the aquarium, I would go again.
author: Katherine C.

description: I have been curious about aquarium for quite some time and whether my boys would like the adventure. So once I got the tickets at half price, I decided to visit the venue. The aquarium itself is very small, there are 2 medium length underwater tunnels, I have seen better tunnels in New Zealand and Australia, preceded by the jellyfish display and it sends with a hands on experience with jelly fish and some indigenous mammals exhibit. My boys, being the hyperactive boys they are, was amused with the experience. They liked the overall exhibits but at the end of the show, they asked if there were more. Clearly I felt the same. It is very, very small. And it is way overpriced for the standard ticket rates. So go there if the tickets are half priced or if you are absolutely bored to death at the pier.
author: Masud S.

description:
Was "OK"  {I was bored}, kids liked it. 
very small, u can do the whole thing in less than an hour, depending on ages of kids.  
Steep ticket price for what u get, i think it's worth half (or less than half) of what they charge.  Purchase from dinning establishment for discount prices.
author: LINDA R.

description:
Small place and a bit underwhelming considering the ticket price. I guess it's okay for its size... I might have been spoiled though, as my last trips were to the Beijing Aquarium and Shedd Aquarium. 

The whole place takes about 30-40 minutes to go through. The best parts for me were the jellyfish and hedgehogs. It would be good to bring young relatives/children to for a "first time" marine experience, since they have a shorter attention span and are much more easily awed. Plus things tend to look a lot bigger a shinier when you're still under 4 feet.
author: Cindy L.

description:
We've visited Pier 39 multiple times without ever stepping into Aquarium of the Bay, as it looked tiny and charged high admission prices, and we've visited and appreciated Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, California Academy of Sciences, CuriOdyssey, Marine Science Institute & Seaworld San Diego. Recently, however, I have changed my mind believing that each place has its own beauty. So We took our almost 4-yr-old here hoping to spend 2 hours and we were pleasantly surprised.

With the help of illustrations, we identified many sea creatures, like various sharks (I explained how eating fish fins destroy these fish and we should never do that), school of sardines that my child loves to eat, bass that we spot at Ranch 99, rock fish that we just had the other day, funny-looking sheephead, sea cucumber, halibut sold at Costco, and counted tree frogs. We touched star fish, anemone, turtle, but it was difficult for my child to touch the bat ray or shark as the touch pool was too deep and there were too few swimming around (she got a bit annoyed, but that was fine since we can always touch them elsewhere). She was so excited to see 2 divers transferring sand from bottom of the shark tank to the window sill and she followed them all the way till they exited a small wooden door. She was also happy to stand on the walkway. As we admired the tranquil medusa, I mentioned to my child that plastic bottles appear like jellyfish to many fish and the fish will swallow the plastic trash and then die. I also commented that the many dead gulls, clams & crabs we found at Halfmoon bay probably died from pollution.

The otters hardly moved during our visit, which was disappointing. We should probably visit CuriOdyssey again to look at the otters. Nonetheless, my child was keenly interested in drawing otter paws with stencil and we spent a whole minute persuading her to finally move on to other exhibits.

The opossum and chinchillas appear to be sleeping throughout our visit. I wonder if they're healthy.

All the staff were knowledgeable and nice. I also learnt the easy way to tell the gender in adult turtles, as well as temperature-dependent sex determination in turtles. My child, however, was not at all intrigued.

All kids enjoyed sticking their head into a big transparent ball inside a tank (which lies outside one of the elevators). My child actually went in many times. The glass/plastic created some distortion making them look smaller. I too climbed underneath to see through the ball. However, I suspect looking through that material simulates wearing a pair of prescription glasses. So I took my child away immediately.

Last but not least, we find the bathroom properly designed: hand controlled toilet flush that doesn't surprise you with an unpredictable loud flush, a sturdy step stool that will not slide for young children, NO 150 decibel hand dryers (those drive me crazy), automatic dispenser for paper towels. My child also loved hugging the plush toys at the gift shop.

We came on a Sunday and it became really crowded later on. We stayed for 3 hours but had to leave because parking was so expensive (I printed a ticket through my local library) and it was already past the nap time for my child. Aquarium of Bay also hosts a free educational display for sea lions but we didn't have time to look. Overall, we enjoyed this little gem and so did at least 85% of visitors we met. It'll be a sure hit with families with children. I'd come back more often if we didn't have to drive for 1hr each way and pay steep parking fees or admission fees.
author: Paris C.

description: I really did like this place. But I feel that it was waaaaay more expensive then it needed to be. Its NOT that big of a place. I do like the underground area where you can look at all the fish and marine life.  I also liked the little pond area where you can pet a small shark and stingrays. Other then that, there isn't much to see here. Save your money :(
author: Trisha H.

description: My boyfriend brought me here while we vacationed in SF, we are both originally from the bay area but I had never been here. I really loved it! It's so cool to walk through and see all the fish and sharks, We got to touch different sea life. It's not a huge aquarium but it is worth the money and the kids in the place seemed to be loving it. I like it, it's low key and not crazy overwhelming for young children.
author: Chelsea M.

description: I love the jellyfish here. That's the main reason why I go. The tank just looks amazing. This is a great family spot. It's small so you can usually go through and see everything without someone getting too bored or tired. The staff is very nice and knowledgeable. The price is a bit high, but it is very easy to find coupons or discount tickets online.
author: Felix K.

description: Wanted to spend a nice afternoon with the family but oh man, it was so crowded. I did expect that for a Saturday but they did not handle this very well. First, only one elevator was in service so it was quite a wait to go down then once down, the belt was turned off so you're stuck for a while waiting for people to be done taking group pictures. Then off course, if you had to wait a while to go down with the elevator, you'll have to wait a while to go up and continue the tour.
author: Lu E.

description:
Unfortunately, how can this place rank when we've all probably had the opportunity and good fortune of seeing the Monterey Bay Aquarium? That said, I thought this little place was very cool with the tunnel effect. You literally get to see the under belly of sharks and stingrays as they swim over your head. You feel like you're in the middle (bottom) of a fish tank, and that's unique.

It is very small though and you can go through it and be done in 15 minutes flat. My 6 year old was duly unimpressed.  I liked it more than she did.
author: Erin O.

description:
I really wish I didn't have to give this place only two stars, but it is impossible to like this place that much when you've been to other aquariums as wonderful as Monterey Bay.

This place is itty bitty, but does do a good job of covering the marine life that resides specifically in the SF bay.  Going down and walking through the aquarium tube surrounded by rockfish and 7 gill sharks was probably one of the better moments I had there.  The only redeeming thing about my aquarium trip is going in the morning when no one was there and not having to fight little kids to touch the rays and leopard sharks.  The rays actually seemed happy to see me!
author: Allegra I.

description: We actually enjoy this small aquarium VERY very much. Of course we like the price (much less expensive than Monterey Bay). If you are a AAA member OR have a membership to any of the local zoos (like Happy Hollow or SF Zoo) you get a 50% discount. It is dedicated to the sea life in and around the SF bay. THAT is what makes it cool. Its location at Pier 39 is nice too because you can pretty much make a day of a visit. The under water tunnels are soooo so cool. We brought our daughter when she was 5 months old... she never looked down! Since then, we go about once if not twice a year. Sure, it hasn't changed much but it is still a nice hour to two hours spent. We enjoy the touch pools much like everyone else. The staff are kind and the people who go are usually going to see what is there, not as a tourist experience (like better known places). This is worth a visit the next time you are on this side of SF.
author: Christina T.

description:
Aquarium of the Bay is a nice place to go, especially if you have small children.  There's three levels that offer general insight about various fish and sea life.  The tunnel is a pretty cool area where you can admire the different types of fish, starfish, leopard sharks, and other animals.  On the top level, they have a very small area that contains painted sea life on canvas... pretty nice if you appreciate that stuff.  Also, they have a place where you get to touch the animals such as the sting ray and the leopard shark.  

The employees are knowledgeable, informative, and open to any questions you have.  

All in all, this place is great for people of all ages!

PS: The prices are extremely affordable and pretty much worth it!

$14.95 for adults minus $2.00 from the coupon in the booklet they give you when you purchase your fare at the cable car booth.  Coupon is good for up to 6 guests.
author: Christine D.

description:
okay, so i saw some things that i didnt want to see. and it was a bit small. however, i love the overhead aquarium, where you can see giant fish and sharks swim above you. at then end of the exhibit, you head to the touch pool, where they have sting rays, leopard sharks and a pool with sea urchins (owwwie), star fish and sea cucumbers. 

we went 30 mins before the entrance closed and got a 2fer deal :)
author: terra d.

description:
I'm an aquarium guy. I love them. I've been to most of the important ones in the US, and the Aquarium of the Bay isn't a bad aquarium, it's just a lovely little commercial aquarium that has melded itself into the Pier 39 world of touristy restaurants, shops and attractions.

The tunnel is the highlight and I love looking at the Leopard sharks and I think a 7-gill that swims really close to the top of the tunnel. I love these tunnel experiences and this one was better than most. The octopus was awesome, and I'm a freak for 'em anyhow. I thought that the jellyfish exhibit was really nice and made me feel like I was getting something from Jellyfish since I missed the Monterrey Bay Aquarium's exhibit. 

It's awfully pricey, but it's located in the heart of Tourist town, so I don't think we can expect much better. I'd say it's a good place to bring out-of-town guests, but if you're a hard core Aqua fiend, you're  better off at one of the three others in the bay area.
author: Rev. Dr. Christopher J. G.

description: I loved this place.  It's pricey for a little aquarium, but what I loved was how much I learned about the Bay water life.  It made me aware of the incredible life that exist under the surface of the Bay.  It was surprising to me because I always see the bay as an extension of the citys that surround it.  They also do a lot of education as to keeping the bay clean and vital.  Really enjoyed this stop
author: Poem G.

description: The best part, touching bat rays and baby sharks!  I bought my ticket on goldstar.com, so it was $21 for 2 of us, which I thought was a good deal.  The first floor that you start on kinda made me sad, the fish were in such small tanks ;( But the next floor was the tunnel which was really cool and we ended up being there during the feeding so we got to learn more about them.  The top floor is where you got to touch the animals, super cool.  A good experience for sure.
author: Megan L.

description: Waste of time and money. For the price you have to pay, there is very little to see. Only good for young children because everything is new and exciting for them. The only good attraction in here is the otters and even the San Francisco zoo has them including way more animals so save your money on the aquarium and go to the zoo instead. I am so disappointed. If I had known I would not pay for this. You can finish walking through the whole aquarium in less than 20-30 minutes. How sad. Go to pier 39 instead for free and watch the sea lions that are far more interesting!!! They also have an opossum which can anyone tell me what in the world that has to do with the AQUARIUM?!
author: Chris H.

description: I took my friends daughter for her birthday and she enjoyed it she loved touching the animals it was overall ok experience glad i got the tickets on discount because if i would have paid full price i would have been mad.It is very small and the first floor you practically just walk through in 2 minutes you can finish the whole place in half an hour
author: Ana L.

description: The exhibits are pretty cool, but this has got to be the most claustrophobic aquarium I've ever seen. It's not entirely their fault, since the place gets insanely crowded on the weekends and they only have so much space to work with, but you'd think that at some point they'd try to move to a larger venue where you can actually move around...
author: Kathleen P.

description: Obviously not as good as the Monterey aquarium, but it has the great tunnels you can through.  Worth the admission just to walk through the tunnels. Has a fun touch pool with rays, and plus it is in the city so there is plenty to do before and after.  Not too big, and a lot of fun.
author: Kris P.

description:
I loved every minute there. The fish and animals were amazing. Those animals and fish live well there, they are treated very good!
You can find rare "things" living there. How life of other livings is mysterious.
author: Jenna F.

description: This aquarium focuses on the sea life that lives in the San Francisco bay. It took us about an hour to go through the exhibits and it was well worth our time. The first display as you enter is a cylindrical floor to ceiling tank filled with smelt swimming around and around, what an amazing site. We saw bright blue eels, octopus, sharks, skates, rays, just to name a few. My favorite area had to be the various jelly fish, the lighting and way they are displayed. It was mesmerizing to watch these beautiful creatures floating in the water. The walk through tunnel is amazing with the fish swimming overhead.  There were huge star fish stuck to the glass as we passed under them and some extremely large fish and rays swimming around us. There are two supervised touch pools where you can touch starfish, sea cucumbers and juvenile rays. Definitely a place for all ages to enjoy.
author: Cindy P.

description:
I got free tickets, but you can get $2 off coupon by typing in aquarium.
http://www.baycityguide.com/coupons.html.  
     If you arrive after 10am, you can go to the Visitor's center with a triple A card and get the coupon book, or there was an employee handing coupons out further down the strip by Boudin's at around 11.
     This place opens at 9am on Sat and we were the only ones there for 30 min, the tourist buses start arriving at 10am-noon.  We found a prime spot at 8:45am metered parking in front of Pier 33, short walk to Pier 39.
     Again, arriving early was great because no kids when you want to take photos, peace and quiet.
      The workers were knowledgeable and not intrusive.  The shark tunnel was really cool.  You get to touch a stingray, shark, or starfish.  Most of the feedings and special animal shows start after 11am when most of the crowds are.
     Yes it is small, but I had a great time, maybe because it was not crowded and it was free.
author: David K.

description: Well, I want to really say that the place is not too bad, but yeah... it is rather sad. I went there with an 8 year old and went around three times until we both got really bored. The place is really small and there were a few things that were under construction. Good thing, I went there with my bay area resident discount which made it not too bad. My best part is the underwater "dive". Pretty cool, but I wish the automatic runway was working when I was there!  Maybe I would follow everyone suggestion to go to the one in Monterey.. seems to be much better deal!
author: Daisy S.

description: This aquarium is really nice. The animals were great, especially the tunnel, which was a very cool experience. Also, they had some guides there that answered all my questions about the exhibit. A great experience, I would go again.
author: claire l.

description:
came here on thanksgiving. with help of "groupon", the tix here were half-price. it was well worth that price, but probably not worth the full price. the workers here were very nice and informative.

the first stop had various tanks with some cool fish in them. the anchovies stood out to me. they looked delicious! the jelly fish were also very cool. 

the next floor was the tunnel area. you basically ride on this slow-ass walking escalator, through a tunnel, and are surrounded by various fish. giant sea bass, sharks, devil rays, you name em. cool idea. 

the last stop was the best. they had cath's favorite, the hedgehog, and luckily they had a demonstration at the time we arrived! he was adorable and took shits comparable to that of a full-sized cat. it was ridiculous. they also had an old friend(california king snake) that i absolutely adored. i miss "joker"! add some interactive touching of sting rays, and it's all good.
author: Andrew T.

description: It's a small aquarium, I like the idea of preserving the bay. I've never paid full price, so its felt "worth it" but I can't justify paying full price for such a small place.
author: Barbara B.

description: The Aquarium is just okay!  Definitely better than most I have been but there is nothing extremely special about it. We did get to see a shark feeding but since they feed them regularly it was nothing exciting. We just went yesterday and there is nothing that I will truly remember forever. The kids will love it!
author: Rosie M.

description: I have only been to this aquarium with a 2 year old, so I guess this review is from a 2 year old perspective. For her size and attention span this place was just right. Everything was just her height, nothing was too scary and it was just hands on enough. Baby Sophia probably would have been satisfied just observing the fish in the first room you walk into when you enter the aquarium. She ran from tank to tank mesmerized by all the different fish. Next, the only part of the aquarium that got a little scary for a two year old was the walk along the people mover in the tunnel. Some of the big fish were just too much. Oh and the people feeding/cleaning the tank really set her over the edge. Luckily after the tunnel comes hands on time and then time to get the hell out of there.
author: Kathleen E.

description: This place was cool.  I liked the shark exhibit where you walk through the tunnel and they are swimming all around you.  The jellyfish were very beautiful to watch.  The coolest part is being able to pet the rays and touch the starfish.  I think they need to add something more though.  It was a little dull.
author: Ashley W.

description:
We got free passes to go in. It was impressive for the first 15 minutes, but don't think we would go back. Seeing it once was fine. Probably great for kids and tourists from ar

It's not the Monterey Bay Aquarium or the California Academy of Sciences.

Nice to go around once, but not likely to return. Probably really nice for tourists to bring small children or for those who do not live anywhere close to the ocean.
author: Martha G.

description:
Pretty disappointed with my visit here.  Especially the price you have to pay to enter.  Luckily, my wife and I had a coupon for buy one and get the second ticket free.  We only spend maybe a total of 30 minutes at the most, so it tells you the size of this aquarium.  The Long Beach aquarium took us well over 2 hours.

Positive note:  "The 300 feet of crystal clear acrylic tunnel" and Staff.
author: Wenzel A.

description:
We went with free tickets and on a week day--so it was a wonderful experience.  I read a few reviews here that said it took under an hour to tour the whole aquarium but it us 2.5 hours, going at a moderate pace.

It seemed like people really liked the octopus, but I thought the tank was pretty small and barren.  

The tunnel was well signed and fun to go through slowly.  It is the most unique feature of the aquarium compared to others I have visited.

It was weird that the aquarium had a special room about geckos, but I think geiko must have donated it...they could have done a better job explaining why it was in the aquarium.

The touch tank was fun--the sting rays were very excited and active.

The people who volunteered there were very nice and informative.

Bottom line: Don't come here comparing it to Monetary (which is a big research aquarium).  The Aquarium of the Bay is a small educational aquarium with a conservation message.
author: Dana K.

description:
meh.

it's an ok aquarium that takes about a half hour to see. i like the fact that all the marine animals are local (except one tank), but don't really get why there are non-native land animals. aquarium of the BAY? hmm. the tunnels are a cool experience, but not worth spending the now $16.95 ticket price. the behind the scenes tour was my favorite part. about an hour tour which covers all the things the aquarists are doing all day long. plus, the holding tanks and the tops of the tunnels. thankfully, they don't go way overboard with that price ($21.95/includes admission). that's the way to go if you're going to go at all.
author: Meredith K.

description: Water was so dirty it was hard to see the fish.  It takes about twenty minutes to go through.  Check out the Exploratorium down the street.
author: M J.

description:
This aquarium is overpriced and is a complete piece of junk. There is a tiny aquarium followed by 2 walkways. This isn't so bad, but you will be done before you know it. After this comes a small petting area. Thats it.. At $15 bucks for an adult ticket, this aquarium is way too overpriced and you will get done in under 30 minutes.

Skip, skip, skip. Complete piece of junk.
author: Hareesh N.

description:
:o/
I must say, for $15 per person, I expected a bit more water. Some of the tanks below were undergoing maintenance and the short tunnels were umm, a bit too short... you'll see the same fish circling around you...and as you mumble to yourself, "this is it?" I swear you can hear the fish on the other side of the glass gurgling, "thisspth isth it-th??" I will say however, the employees are kind...and although it only takes 30 minutes or less to spend the 15 dollar ticket- the facility is nice enough to allow cameras...so perhaps you can get your $15 worth of photos or video? The elevator is fun...(blink-blink)  ;o)
author: Regi R.

description:
this Aquarium features local marine life of the San Francisco Bay- especially sharks. 
The best part for me is the long acrylic tunnels with 7 gill sharks but there are some new exhibits that are also interesting.  
Strong points: local marine life.

Stronger point- the AOB- now owned by the Bay Institute will be developing new outreach programs in bay habitat and marine life education.  Watch for the Shaktoberfest Celebrate the shark event this october.
author: David M.

description:
alas. attended a private event there last night (we paid $50/person for 3 hours??); if it wasn't for the fabulous company and open bar, i would've been sadly disappointed. after going through the tunnel o fish, twas nice but begged the question, that's it??? 
there are 3 touch tanks and the view of the bay's pretty nice, but save your money and head to the monterey aquarium.
author: Jasmine W.

description:
Went here for an SF Weekly event/party. Was lots of fun. Granted, it wasnt the typical Aquarium of the Bay experience. The aquarium is a bit small. But it was fun getting to touch the fish and walking around with a drink in my hand!

:-)
author: Art A.

description:
Well, it ain't no old school Steinhart, or Monterey Bay Aquarium, that's for sure.  But enough to see and touch to keep my son happy.  

There was an opportunity to touch bat rays, sharks and stingrays, all of which I am sure are totally stressed out from the lack of privacy.

An elevator takes you down to the basement, which is actually a large tank with a Brita filter attached to the real ocean surrounding it.  Still, this was not enough for many of the fish in the tank to buy a ticket to sideways heaven.  Kinda neat-o to take the conveyor belt underneath the glass of the tank, much like most modern aquariums these days.

Overall it felt like a one-time experience with a Pier 39 markup on the tickets.  This touristy aspect, and the dead fish in the tunnel tank, cheapened the experience and drew my sadness at the lives these fish must live at the expense of our curiosity.
author: Wayne Q.

description:
It is a rather small aquarium, but great for its location. It also fulfilled our aquarium needs when our daughter was younger.

Unfortunately their moving walkways squeak really loud, which frightened our daughter. And sometimes they don't even work.

It is awesome though that you get to touch the sharks and the rays (not so sure they feel the same way).

It is small enough, yet varied enough for younger children.
author: Mona O.

description:
One of the smaller aquariums I've ever been too, but they made up for it in really great displays and information. We could have spent all day looking at the starfish that were attached to the tunnel walls, the sharks, all of the fish...

I was looking forward to the "interactive" area, but it was overrun by children (I guess, to be expected) and I couldn't get near anything. 

Would I do it again? Probably not, but I'm glad I went!
author: Mindy W.

description: This aquarium makes our local aquarium (Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach) look like Sea World. The entry fee is about $15 dollars so it isn't too bad. It took us approximately 30 minutes to walk through the entire place. I give kudos for cleanliness, other than that..ridiculous.
author: Victoria I.

description:
Another koo place to check out with the fam.
If you like underwater creatures this place has em.
Traveling through the underwater tube is pretty sweet as well, seeing if you never been underwater surrounded by sea creatures.

Koo place, check it out sometime.
author: Storm S.

description:
I'm a nerd. Ok. Since I got that out of the way, I can start my review.

This aquarium is very small compared to Monterey Aquarium or Long Beach's Aquarium. But if you part in the parking structure across the street from the Aquarium, you will receive (I think) 5$ off an adult ticket on the back of your parking pass. So overall 20$ for two people is not bad at all. I wouldn't say that this should be a day event, maybe half a day after you walk around the warf. It is a nice, and most of the time, overlooked fascinating Aquarium. I really enjoyed my time here. They even have a touchpool so you can get all wet playing with star fish and sting rays!!
author: Steph C.

description:
Worst part of my trip to San Francisco.
Dead fish, $14 ticket, renovations going on... awesome.
The underwater tunnel was very cool not literally took me 10 minutes to walk through and that was it. I would suggest walking further along the pier and visiting the sea lions for a better time.
author: Joann P.

description: We knew this was a small place and we knew it was a "tourist" area but we like aquariums so we went.  There was one kick a** employee who was awesome to talk to and was exceptionally informative.  I was able to pet the baby rays and Henry the Octopus was really cool to watch.  We paid the extra for the behind the scenes tour - totally worth it.  Our guide was the same quirky super awesome employee we kept running into at the other exhibits - both her and Henry really made this a great stop on our SF trip!
author: Milissa S.

description: It's really neat to go underneath the glass tunnel and see all the fishes but it is rather small and short for $16 a person.
author: Shaun S.

description: This place is great for fat people like me.  You don' have to walk and there are plenty of places to sit.  As long as u can fit your fat ass in the elevator and the aquarium tunnel this is a fatty's dream.  The entire fish tank on the second floor has a moving walkway.  Its freakin awesome if you have to carry 500lbs on your belly.  The only thing you need to do is hold your fat ass up.  Once you get tired from standing while the moving walkway moves you around you can sit down at the 1000s or benches they have around the aquarium.  The aquarium is probably 800 sqaure feet.  I know for fat asses thats big.  Its tough to just turn let alone try to walk around a 800 sq foot place.  The good thing is you can be done in 15 minutes.  If you spent $20 to check this place out you got jacked.  Check out travelzoo.com for $8 tickets.  Its arguably worth $8.  I'd maybe pay $5 and get 2 double double cheeseburgers.
author: Fatty A.

description:
I know call me a trapped tourist, but I really liked the TUNNEL the best. Never experienced that kindof swimming with the fish kind of experience and it was wonderful.

We had guests in from Japan and thought this would be a fun experience and since we hadn't done anything here before, we could play tourist with them. 

Hey...the Academy of Science rocks, but they do NOT have a water tunnel so you can swim with the mini sharks of the bay...
author: miriam b.

description:
l'll have to agree with the majority here. It's $14.95 for about 40 minutes of exploration - TOPS! I read every friggen sign and watched every friggen video. The shark tank looked boring and the fishes didn't do anything but swim around. They've got to stage this thing better. Do some live feeding or something, dang it! The great finale is that you get to touch some starfish and drugged up sharks. These sharks weren't even moving. It's not exciting to touch a shark and not feel like your life's in danger, dammit! For all I know, it was probably made out of rubber. 

There's an octopus in this thing but you'd probably wouldn't notice. The thing was hiding in the corner and if it wasn't for the people crowding for a look at it, I wouldn't have noticed. The sharks were bland, I forgot they were sharks. I wish they had something 30 feet long and could feed it live sea lions.
author: Johnny N.

description:
This is not the Monterey Bay Aquarium.
Some interesting exhibits--we did get to actually touch some Sting Rays, which behaved almost like pets. We also like starfish, plus I think we even saw Dory and Nemo in a tank, too. 
And walking through water in a plexiglass Tunnel is always cool, because when I looked up, I was surprised to see a human(?) in a scuba outfit cleaning the glass. It waved at me. Friendly staff, too. 
PS: We saw everything in less than 30 minutes and probably wouldn't have gone, except we found greatly discounted tickets.
author: Bev M.

description: Its great fun for kids - specially the touch pools and the sharks.  Its in Fisherman's wharf - so you can have a day of fun both both the kids and the parents.
author: B D.

description:
I know people will gush over the aquarium in Monterey rather than Aquarium of the Bay but this one isn't the bad in-law of aquariums.  Yes, Monterey Aquarium is larger, has more exhibits, and in a somewhat less hectic area but let's look at the WHOLE experience.

MONTEREY
* $29.95/per adult ticket
* $18/per child
* Parking around $5 - 10 (street meter is almost impossible)
* Long lines to get in
* Extremely crowded (sometimes you can't get good looks at fish or other exhibits due to overcrowding)
* Large amounts of various exhibits
* Cannery Row with various shops of places to eat

AQUARIUM OF THE BAY
* $16.00/per adult ticket
* $8.00/per child 3-11
(or family rate of $39.95 for 2 adults and 2 children)
* Parking FREE to $15 (shops at PIER validate 2 hour FREE parking if you buy something)
* No long lines to get in
* Not as crowded
* Various exhibits (including numerous hands on)
* It's at Fisherman's Wharf so talk about things to do afterward!!!!

In this recession, I want to find places to go that pique my interest but also don't PEAK my budget. I get less for 2 adults and 2 kids here than just 1 adult and 1 kid in Monterey and walking access to one of the greatest cities without moving my car! We keep finding Aquarium of the Bay coupons in various publications. Don't sleep on this place, it has excellent exhibits, lots of starfish, rays, fish, jellyfish, and even some marine life to touch so you can watch your mom or girlfriend get squeamish. It also has a winding underwater aquarium that allows you to see and follow sharks, rays, jellyfish, and various other marine life all while being ushered on a very slowly moving conveyor belt, which you can step off and on. How cool is that for those who like to feel like they're moon-walking. =) You can then step out and see the Pacific roll in, including any marine life it brings with it, and nice areas to just enjoy the ocean. 

Overall, I've been to both and keep coming back here. If you have kids, hey I don't blame you for going to Monterey once however, after all the pushing and shoving, feeling cramped that kinda kills the trip then you will see why we love this place along with the Pier.
author: Mike D.

description:
Although it's expensive and tiny I give it three stars...I went with some friends and saw the employees being very kind to an elderly woman, answering her many questions about the different fish even though she started one conversation by saying something like," is that a ray or a skate?...I ate a skate once with butter, it was tasty!"

Yup, nice gets stars in my book :)

I personally have mixed feelings about the tunnel aquarium thingy - it's amazing to be under the fish like that, yet, I wonder how safe it is to be in an area predicted to have a massive earthquake and be standing under a large glass structure filled with water??

 REALLY glad I had a coupon, and I enjoyed watching the seals for free after :)
author: Murry t.

description: My boyfriend & I thought the aquarium was way over priced for how small it is. $15.95 an adult at $7.00 a child. We were in and out in about 20 minutes. We would have lingered a little longer but it was so crowded and small (especially in the underwater tunnels) that we had a hard time seeing things and people are so rude!! The aquaruim would be smart to only allow a certain amount of people through at a time and not charge as much. On the bright side the Pier 39 shops and restaurants were great!
author: JENNA J.

description: Nice daytrip. I did it as part of the Go SF Card when I had a friend visiting. The water-surrounded tunnel and opportunity to pet sharks/rays is nice.
author: Sarah B.

description: Took my almost 5yr old twins here. It was absolutely awesome!  They both loved it. It was fun seeing them enjoy, there was so much to see. I liked that the moving pathway was not working. We spent a lot of time in both "tunnels" as my daughters called them. We switched sides often, there were not too many people too. Looking forward to go again.
author: Nand P.

description:
Aquarium by the bay... My little cousins were pumping this place up like it was some kind of fish heaven or some shit.... Whack. They advertise 2 so called underwater aquariums so I expected to go under some real sea water and see the fish in their natural habitat swimming around in the bay. Instead, I was stuck in this damn cylinder shaped tunnel which ended up giving me a fatty headache from the distorted angles and view I got from the rounded shape of the glass that I had to keep looking thro to see the damn fish. Oh yea.. and not to mention, there were hella fish looking like they were ready to check out or already fukin dead. Floaters are not what kids need to be seeing, even though they are just some fukin fish. 

15 buks per person for a walk through that lasted about 15 minutes. Not to mention the 6 bucks we had to pay for parking.
author: Winston K.

description: Based on the previous reviews, you'd think this was a tiny place; far from it, this is a solid three story aquarium.  It's well organized and has everything from two touch tanks to two long "tunnel" aquariums, plus dozens of individual tanks with fascinating wildlife.  For a decent tourist attraction, this was a great place to take the kids.
author: Alex G.

description: Nice little aquarium. I suggest going here before rippleys or your kids may look a little bored, but they did enjoy.
author: Dustin W.

description: Average aquarium. Didn't really have much to offer in comparison to other aquariums up and down the coast of California. Biggest attraction of the aquarium was the tunnels visitors walk through through a large aquarium. Other than that, you can fly through the aquarium really fast.
author: Samantha B.

description:
It was ok. Nothing special. I thought it was overpriced for what you saw. Judging from their website I was expecting more and for it to be larger.  I also anticipated more tropical fish and well more fish in general.  

Overall I would tell friends and family to skip it. But if you want to go, go just to say you've been there and done the touristy thing at the Warf.
author: Stephanie K.

description: This would be a great place for tourist around SF...but for someone from the Bay Area, this wasn't worth the admission price they charge. Thanks to Groupon.com for the 50% off discount = $8. Although, I must say, the cool part of this would be walking under the tunnel seeing the sharks and starfishes, etc...and also being able to touch the sting rays. It's a small aquarium and I was done in less than an hour.
author: Ellie S.

description:
a nice place to visit..a fantastic venue for a party! the only place in san francisco where u can touch a shark!

PLACE: i've always been curious to check this place out & finally got an opportunity to at the sf weekly holiday party. what a great place for a party! i was psyched to be able to touch a manta ray (so soft & slimey!!) & a baby shark (i started screaming)! it's a scaled-down version of the monterey bay aquarium, but i thought it did a good job of covering all the bases one would expect out of an aquarium visit. walking through the tubes where sharks & huge fishes swim overhead was otherworldly, & i giggled at the starfish stuck to the tube, posed as if they were pleading to get out.

DECOR: kinda drab with all the tan flooring & walls, but the aquatic scenes require u to use ur imagination & lose urself in the exhibits. i kept getting lost in the layout, which was a bit confusing.

BATHROOM: normal

OVERALL: a nice place to take visitors or to go on a fun date (along w/the exploratorium & academy of sciences), especially if they love the ocean & it's creatures!
author: miss b.

description: Walking through the entire aquarium took a pitifully short amount of time. They have some nice exhibits but it's too small and crowded to be worth it. The aquarium is pretty expensive for what it is so I recommend saving your money for a  trip to Monterey Bay Aquarium.
author: Erin G.

description: Aquarium of the Bay  is located at pier 39 it looks small but its actually really big!! its a great place for a family to explore the sea !! we seen fishies we never  even seen before!!  my daughter had a great time seeing all the colorful fish!!
author: Joely L.

description: I was asking about buying tickets.  The woman at the booth by Fisherman's Wharf was fuming at me when I was asking questions.  I just want to warn others that this place is hiring rude, in a hurry sales people who really want you out of their hair.  I was shocked and we decided not to go to the aquarium.
author: ann s.

description: The place is family friendly, and the place has a variety of fish, sea lions, and other sea life. The place is clean and organized, and the people there care about wildlife and sealife. The place is a couple of stories tall and is part of Pier 39. Parking can be easy if you pay in a parking lot. There are many great restuarants right by the aquarium. This place may be smaller than Monterey Bay Acquarium, but it is a great place to go to. I have been here on many field trips in the past.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: $15.95 is a bit pricey for this smallish aquarium, but not unreasonable.  At the end I let out a "that's it?!"  The shark tank is too small and boring for all of its occupants :(  I saw a big bite in one shark's tail area with red flesh streaming!!  Cool but sad.  I wish there were "no flash photography" signs up and employees regulating.  Old people have no technological common sense.  I want a hedgehog.  Why are non ocean animals at an aquarium?
author: Yuka K.

description: Just ok. The place is small and very expensive to enter. The tanks need to be cleaned more often. It is was cheaper, cleaner and larger it would be pretty good.
author: C W.

description:
I won't be coming back to the Aquarium of the Bay. There were maybe 2 things that are cool about this place - the sharks and the chinchillas. Yah, they have chinchillas at an Aquarium. Go figure. 

Anyways....too many kids, boogers, diapers, sticky fingers, crying, spilling bottles, crowding elevators and grubby hands ALL OVER THE GLASS. I totally commiserated with the stressed-out octopus that wouldn't come out of his hiding spot. If I lived in that hellhole, I would do the same thing.

Besides all of the above, the place is small and doesn't have enough cool animals to warrant a return.
author: Nicole W.

description: I was not impressed with this Aquarium. It was something I was looking forward to on a recent trip and was let down. Don't get me wrong it is cute, and has some really cool sea-life, however it is really small. They do however have one of the longest underwater tunnels I have seen, and a great hands on tide pool. I was able to feed a starfish which was pretty cool. It's not a bad place, just however not worth the admission they are charging.
author: Zak P.

description: A small impressive aquarium.  They have a 50% discount for Happy Hollow members.  Great area where you can touch the fish and a rolling walkway with the aquarium all around you, filled with...well fish and sharks and stuff.  They even have divers that answer questions and talk about the sealife.  Good for a couple of hours of entertainment on your wharf experience.
author: Matthew P.

description: Sort of a small aquarium, but great place for little kids.  They have a petting zone for the starfish, sting rays, etc.  Kids and adults will adore that place alike.  Admission is definitely pricey.  The exit is the gift shop, but it seems like a fire hazard because it can get super crowded.
author: Anne N.

description: This aquarium was quite small compared to others I'd been to. There wasn't as much variety of sea creatures as I would of thought. I actually found it a little boring and a waste of my money. I'll make sure to make my next aquarium visit over in Monterey.
author: Linndsey A.

description: I would much rather visit an aquarium that was bigger.  This place was small and dark.  This place is a complete tourist trap, I would recommend Monteray Bay Aquarium to spend your tourist money.
author: Katelyn A.

description: I was a little disappointed by this place.  Its really a few tanks and then two tunnels to walk thru that are very dark.  I did get a few good pictures.  Its expensive for how small it is.  From what I have heard about Monterey, I am planning a trip down there.
author: Tiffany P.

description: What a rip off!  only 2 small floor of exhibits.  1 floor is the tunnel that you can look out to see some fishes, another floor is 3 little you can touch ponds.  That's all!  $14 a ticket? Don't even go there!
author: L X.

description: The place isn't worth the price of what it is, but I got in for free so I don't care. The aquarium was cool, but I wish it was a little bit bigger. It was too small and short so I felt that the place wasn't worth its price. I am really glad i didn't need to pay to get in. YA!
author: Sonlay V.

description: a fun aquarium located right at pier 39. a pleasant distraction for the afternoon, great displays, a large touch pool and tide pool (feed the starfish and anemones by hand!). a fun underwater tunnel and all your standard aquarium displays as well as a few non-aquatic residents (like a hedgehog!) good for groups and families with children.
author: Justin H.

description: I love wild life, environment sustainability, and fun! If those are also your cup of tea, the this is the place to go. wether you are a local of a tourist looking for something unique try it! The staff is very friendly and caring. Also now, if you visit and it's your birthday, make sure to tell the staff, you get a birthday pin. When a staff see's you, you get a smile and happy birthday! :)
author: Chris M.

description:
the ONLY reason this gets 2 stars rather than 1 is because you can touch sting rays and small sharks

other than that, I could probably have a more satisfying experience staring at the fish tank in any chinatown restaurant... and then at least you get to eat it

problem solved
author: PJ M.

description:
Sorry, but I liked this place. All you aquarium haters - I'm not sure why.

The jellyfish exhibits were nice and the hundreds of feet of tunnel were pretty cool. I really liked touching the leopard sharks and the rays, that's certainly not something you get to do every day.

This place is a kind of small. I'm not complaining about the price (I have no idea what it is) since I got the City Pass. Would recommend - go to this before the CalAcademy.

Add a few penguins and this place would be AWESOME!
author: Jeffrey L.

description: Hello, rip-off.  This walk-through in 5 minutes "aquarium" is more of a giant fish tank.  Don't be fooled, this establishment will eat your money faster than its two sharks on hand will catch their lunch.
author: Liza W.

description: I love looking at fishes and animal.. I love walking through the tunnel where you stand and it glades and you look up, you can see fishes, shark, etc.. At the end I get to touch a baby shark and sanddab.. exciting experience.. great place to bring  a girl on a date..
author: Lily T.

description:
Great place to take kids- i took my five year old neice out for the day. We started at the Aquarium which was perfect for her- they have three awesome exhibits: 

Discover the Bay:  you learn about the creatures that call the Bay their home.

Under the Bay:  A moving walkway  takes you through two crystal clear tunnels- you'll seeI schools of anchovies, colorful sea stars, sea rays, and sharks.

Touch the Bay: live bat rays, leopard sharks, and tide pool animals. It was fun to be able to touch these awesome animals.

So much fun for kids!
author: Ashley N.

description: Sure, it is small...and sure if focuses on the fish of the San Fran Bay but it is lively and fun.  Went here a few weeks ago with my mom, step dad, and Paul while doing the touristy things at Fisherman's Wharf.  We had a lot of fun.  I loved the walk through exhibit where the fish are above you and on both sides of you.  We spent a lot of time in there.  Of course it isn't the aquarium in Monterey but I wasn't really expecting it to be.  We spent quite a bit of time watching the sea life swim all around us and we enjoyed ourselves.  It was the perfect outing for when your parents are meeting your fiance for the first time!  Gave us a lot to talk about.  The touch pools are pretty neat too.  It wasn't super crowded and it was nice to get away from the hoards of tourists outside at the Wharf....All in all, good time but don't expect to be WOW'd
author: Z Z.

description:
lame.

no, really.  "we're located in the tourist-hell of pier 39 so we can afford to be lame with so many new rubes to rip-off", lame.

small and lousy selection of fish, kept in dark, uninteresting, and poorly cleaned tanks.  whoopie.  nothing like a "docent" employee to be seen -- just excessively bored and indifferent employees in the elevator who (weird) are just there to push the buttons and yawn between floors.

I visited this place when it first opened.  the walk-through aquarium tunnel was novel then... but that was about it.  since then, the place has obviously been poorly maintained and slid downhill into the insipid gutter of other pier 39 rip-offs.

skip it and go watch the seals for free!  at least you'll know where the bad smell is coming from :-P

better yet -- point yourself southward and hit-up the monterey bay aquarium.    that's an experience you won't soon forget.
author: Mark B.

description:
if you've been to the aquarium in singapore on sentosa island, then no aquariums could really compare... 
or even the monterey bay one for that matter...
this one is like the littlest sister of them all... or so it seems...
i guess it fits in with the small big city environment of san francisco.
and it's a billion times better than going to the sorry place they call a zoo in the outer sunset...
if you have a little kid you need to entertain, this would be a good place to take them :)
author: charlotte s.

description: Hmmm....$14 adult/ $7child. We had discount tickets. I took my niece and nephew there. It's small but we knew that already. There is a moving walkway so you really can't take your time. There is a small touch pool. I think we were done in less than 25 minutes. Sucks. That is one place I won't go to again. And the people who work there didn't seem too enthused. I know I shouldn't compare...and granted the location will attract first timers.
author: Winane L.

description: Well worth the time and money though not as large  or scientific as the larger alternative sites in the area.  As a SF resident, I was skeptical that an aquarium at a popular tourist destination would be worth the money compared the Cal. Academy of Science and even the Monterrey Aquarium if you had the time to visit it. I heard some good things so took a 3 and 7 year old to visit. We all loved the fish tunnel with many varieties swimming inches away. It was like being a diver rather than watching the fish bowl like most aquariums. In the middle of the week we had the first tunnel to ourselves but had to share the shark tunnel with some school groups which vastly increased the noise level. Other display areas were more typical  and smaller with more school groups and noise. A good choice for a two hour visit. If you want more time, varieties and science, try the others mentioned above. Cal. Academy of Science has many other subjects beyond water life. .
author: joe g.

description: I'm not sure if this place deserves 3 stars, but I'm gonna be generous because I had great company that day.  The place was a lot smaller than expected.  Admission prices are much too high for the quality of this Aquarium site.  I do have to say though that the staff was quite friendly and approachable.  What made it fun and worthwhile was the company, and getting to take some great pictures.  So if you're gonna shell out $14 per person to get in, you better make sure to bring some damn good entertaining people.  Because you can only get so much fun out of those starfish (no offense to the starfish).
author: Sara D.

description: Pleasant way to spend some time.  It is labeled Aquarium but there are other critters on display, bees and spiders for example.  Staff was friendly.  It was clean, a real plus, and the location was ideal for a quick trip through.  We have been to larger ones but I would not have expected it to be super big considering the location.  It appeared to be very kid friendly.
author: Helen H.

description: Very overpriced for what it is! Really not worth the money. We were through in about 25 minutes. The staff was very nice and helpful which is always a plus.  One thing that really bothered me was that the area where you can touch the sea life was up way too high for the three year old I went with. Even when I was holding him up dangling him over the edge of the pools he still couldn't reach the sharks or stingrays.
author: B. C.

description: It's a pretty small and fascinating Aquarium. Unfrotunately ,they don't provide enough information on the observed species. It doesnt' really compare to the amazing Aquarium in Eilat, Israel, which I believe it's based on (design wise). The entrance fee is a tad high, but it's okay, considering that it's located in a touristy area. The whole tour is just a bit short and I would've liked to read more about the many fascinating underwater monsters that are just waiting for the sea level to rise, to eat us alive!!!!!!!!!
author: Roger W.

description: big rip off...I'd stay away from such tourist trap (in future :)..). Been there done that (yelp wasn;t there that time guyzz!!!) If you really want to see an aquarium, go visit monetery.
author: Neelesh V.

description: How can you not love it?!  OK, maybe if you're expecting some ginormous aquarium the size of the Monterey Bay one with floor to ceiling windows fully equipped with bigger name recognition and accordingly higher admission prices.  On the other hand, the Aquarium of the Bay is more intimate and, well, scary.  While I kept thinking about, "what if an earthquake struck right now" the entire time in the underwater tube room downstairs, we all had ourselves a great time at the aquarium.  Yes, my sister and nine-month old niece also loved it!  Very easy to stare at all the fishies and sharks when they're directly above you, only separated from you by the thick and hopefully earthquake-proofed glass.  -1 star because after all the hype about the giant octopus that lives in a tank between the two tunnels...s/he wasn't even there!  Big disappointment!  Oh well, we saw others in the tunnel anyways.  But still.
author: T. O.

description: Weak. Don't expect Sea World or the Maui Ocean Center here. Not enough color. The aquarium is really small. Unless they expand...I mean really really expand...I don't think I'll be visiting it again any time soon. There are only 3 exhibits here...the best one is the tidepool. I touched a shark...which is crazy cuz I have the biggest phobia of sharks. Biggest phobia. I mean...they were little tiny leopard sharks...but still...sticking my hand in that tidepool was crazy enough for me. I also touched some stingrays...which was cool, but I started thinking about Steve Irwin and kinda got freaked out. I also had fun playing with the sea stars...starfish...I call 'em. So what...sea stars, starfish...it's all the same sh*t, no? My friend kept correcting me...it was kinda annoying. Anyway, at this aquarium...you're not allowed to pick 'em up. I don't know why...they let you pick 'em up in Maui as long as you keep 'em in your hand in the water. Still...I picked 'em up secretly. Sssshhh...don't tell.
author: Caroline Y.

description: I can't speak for the aquarium, because I actually didn't go inside, even though we had free entrance for a work function (too busy setting up and cleaning up).
